Beautiful nebulous orange colour with a fizzy white head and fair lacing. Aroma is perfect: the spicy fruitiness is seductively inviting. Deep maltiness, full body. A bit unbalanced, alcohol is dominating the palate, numbing. Sweet, warming aftertaste.

Pours a cloudy orange coloured beer. Very thick creamy head. Smells quite hoppy and a little fruity, mostly dried fruits. Very full pleasing mouthfeeling, quite some gas. A bitter full taste, a little spicy and some alcoholsweetness. Aftertaste is dry and a little spicy with some sour.

This was really good but considering how much I love abbey tripels, I wasnt as impressed for its style. Pours a dark orange with a medium head. The aroma was fruits and malts with a hint of alcohol. The taste is almost the same as the smell but a little more bold and complex.

The aroma is orange peel and some nice spicy yeast. Sweet n fizzy; mild and really outstanding.

The appearance is golden/amber. Beautiful white foam. Thick lace. Beautiful lace in fact. Textbook.

Spicy orange flavor; fizzy champagne. Nice thick, spiced malt. Belgian to the fullest. Heavy yeast, moreso than even most Belgians.

Feels very creamy and thick; fizzy. Thick and nice; a major bite on the way down. A tremendously drinkable brew. Spicy and with a bite.

bottle to chalice, looks brilliant and hazy with a well-retained with cap speckled with brown sediment. Aroma is apricots and tangerines, light bread and yeast, coriander. Lovely flavors of citrus, spice, sweet bread and pungent yeast. Body is sticky with a smooth medium viscosity mouthfeel. Excellent belgian strong ale.

It was hard to see in bar lighting, but it appeared light golden,  bit cloudy. No head (I think that the bartender forgoes good pouring technique for maximum glass filling). Minimal lacing.  Smelled fruity. A tad malty. Quite an alcohol kick  Tastes fruity (raisin, plum) with a tad of citrus. Though its a bit hidden, the alcohol lets you know its there.

Pretty tasty as an after dinner drink. At 10%, itll knock you off your a$$ if you drink many. It reminds me of a fruitcake with a shot.

Pours a hazy, deep orange with a nice, dense long-lasting top. Definitely score for appearance. Smell is fresh and yeasty, with floral tones and a bit of booze. Taste is very intense, with a boozy interface underlining a significant maltiness as well as hints of herbs, resin and a bit of clove in the background. Maybe a tad bit boozy; its 10 % but Ive seen it covered up better than this. Despite this flaw, the Maredsous 10 is a well-made tripel.

Ködös borostyán sárga színe van aminek tetején egy vattaszerű piszkosfehér hab fekszik ami lassan eltűnik a pohár falán felhőszerű nyomokat hagyva.Illatában az erős fűszerezettség tűnik fel amiben a szegfűszeg dominál.Érezni rajta az élesztőt és az alkohol csípősséget is.Ízében a mandarin és ananász gyümölcsös íze a vezető vonal.Fehér bors,szegfűszeg,koriander,élesztő és a komló is szerepet kap.Az alkoholt végig érezni ebben az olajos testű italban,ami elég gazdag apró buborékokban.Utóíze keserédes,kissé csípős és hosszan tart.Téli hidegben nagyon kellemes melegítő sör.

Pours golden brown with a thick white head. Aroma is of apples, rasins, spruce, pine - very hoppy but nice and sweet at the same time. Taste is strong on the hops and first but has a subtle sweetness to it as well. The ending is a little on the alcohol side but also nice and bitter. Very smooth.
Has a dark brownish color with a big thick head. The aroma and taste is a little fruity, but lingers very nicely on the tounge quite a long time. The mouth feel isnt too big, but very nice.

Bottle consumed at the Sharp Edge Bistro last week. 11.2 oz bottle poured into a snifter.

A-The body is a hazy dark gold-almost copper colored. Looked great but much darker than most tripels I have come across. More along the lines of some Grand Crus or Strong Belgian Amber Ales (which I really think deserve their own style category on this website).

S-Nose is full of exotic fruits. Mango, apricot, maybe some peach, and maybe some pineapple. Behind this is the scent of sweet bready yeast and a phenolic presence.

T-Taste is similar to the smell. Lots of exotic fruits can be tasted upfront (see above). Behind this is a sweet bready yeast backbone. A slight floral hop presence emerges as the other flavors intensify. Then the big, slightly bitter alcohol presence emerges. What lingers is an alcohol heat along with a faint resemblance of the other flavors mentioned.

P- Nice medium-weight smooth yeasty mouthfeel.

O- Decent beer overall with good flavors and mouthfeel...but it got too boozy toward the end of the glass. Though this is a tripel...it has more Belgian Amber flavors than Belgain Pale flavors to me. Very nice...check the date and do some aging on this one though.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-30-2008 21:19:50

Clear reddish amber pour with a 1.5 finger white head that last nicely. Pillowy and savory looking. The aroma is quite spicy with hige notes of clove and banana. Yeast character presents in the form of fruity dough- angel food cake to be precise. Very reminiscent of the 6. The flavor is floral, fruity and spicy. Lots of clove and a bit of graininess, but overall, the crisp, citrusy fruit character prevails. The yeast character seems to be largely taken over by a nice warming booze note, but is still present. The palate is very effervescent and pillowy, with a medium body and a super crisp, nicely attenuated finish.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear amber/orange with a white head.  Nose is sweet, fruity, and spicy with honey, vanilla, some orange and grapefruit citrus.  Taste is complex.  Nice sweetness, lots of spice, fruity, and some slight hoppy bitterness.  Finish begins sweet before drying out with more bitter spiciness.  Good stuff.

(Bottle into tulip - sampled 3/13/10)  I am in love!!  Pours a beautiful dark orange with a one and a half finger head that stuck around for most of the glass leaving some beautiful lacing on the way.  The nose is what you expect from most abbeys -- orange, banana, coriander, etc.  I was pleasantly surprised to also find a nice strong sweetness there brought out by some honey and toffee.  The taste does not disappoint either!  There is truth in the advertising the aromas made and the spice or the coriander and some pepper is balanced delightfully by the honey-like sweetness.  This is the aftertaste that lingers and beckons that next sip!  An exquisite example of the style with a delightful variation on the norm.

750ml bottle. Huge creamed head on a pretty, hazed honey body. nose of subtle clove, honeycomb, pine. taste is sparkling, smooth, creamy grain and malt. A bit of sweetness, touch of honey, plenty of clove. champagne like overall, a bit too much sweet/sparkle for me.
Pours a bright golden yellow color. Aromas of hops, fruit, and a little yeast. Has a light fruity taste, with some yeasty notes, and a good hop flavor.

Hazy deep orange body with lasting off-white head. Aroma is grass, herbal and caramel/toffee . Warm alcoholic bittersweetness; moderately yeasty, slightly fruity and citric notes. Medium- to full-bodied, smooth oily texture. Finish is bitter and kind of reminds me of burnt malt. Some dark notes in this one; not bad, but not exactly my kind of tripel, I personally enjoy them lighter and a tad more drinkable.
Bottled. Golden with thin head. Aroma is malty toffee sweetness, and bread, and caramels. Malty and sweet, lightly fruity. Grass bitter finish that stings lightly.

330 ml bottle. Dark golden body with a big frothy white head. Aroma is not really strong, but pleasant with fruit, spices and some alcohol, gives a sweet feeling. Flavor is sweet sugar, fruity, spicy and warming alcohol. Extremely easy drinkable and goes also very well with food. A really nice version of a triple.

330 mL bottle from the LCBO, served in a branded Trappist glass. Pours a hazy orange with a tall, frothy white head. Head mostly stays and leaves impressive lace. Floral aromas are dominant, along with biscuit malts and spice. There is also a fair bit of yeast and some hops on the nose. Flavour begins moderately sweet but dries out towards the finish. Peppery alcohol enters through the middle. Yeast is present throughout. Finish is moderate in length, dry and spicy with a fair bit of alcohol. Decent overall, but nowhere near as complex as Id like in a tripel of 10% ABV. 2010-03-19

A dark blonde with a big frothy head (beautiful). A big flowery smell, a little perfumed with Belgian Hops, earthy yeast and biscuity malt. Strong and Attractive. Taste is a large chewy malt with even more flowery notes, a little raisin and fruitiness. Some Honey sweetness present, and great warming alcohol in the finish. BIG, POWERFUL, GREAT :)

(bottle) pours a hazy golden-amber colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of herbal hops, powdered sugar, light pineapple and grainy pale malts. flavour is quite the same, full-bodied and fruity, with lively carbonation and an alcoholic-warming finish.

Bottle. Copper colored with a half-inch of creamy white head. Aroma is tart fruit and caramel malt. Flavor begins with toffee and toasted malt sweetness along with some orange peel and vanilla. It follows with a strong yeasty presence and spiciness. It finishes dry and doughy with an almost overpoweringly warm alcohol burn. Nice balance between sweet and spicy although a lower ABV would have enhanced the flavors even more.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2010 definitely one of the best triples out there... insanely complex aroma, with lots of yeast, malt, lots of fuit and even some chocolat/nut... there is some alchohol too, but in a good way.... the texture and body of this beer reminds me of something much darker, yet its still very fresh and lively... tough is also something that comes to mind when drinking this... insane thing is that i can buy this stuff right from the supermarket....

Bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy deep golden with a lingering fluffy white head. Aroma is a bit candyish, lightly fruity, some yeast, quite perfumey a bit underwhelming. Flavor starts with some lemon and citric characteristics, picking up some candy and slight off metallic flavors. Finishes dry and crisp with a hint of bitterness. Medium to full body and a soft carbonation. Not my favorite trippel, kind of odd, refreshing though.

Very good beer.  Pours golden with a straw colored head.  The head lasts quite a bit, and enhances the aromas.  The body of this brew is pretty solid, but overall a little too much sweetness.  Doesnt quite compare to the Chimay version, but not much does . . .  Overall a very good Beer.

My first rating, opened on Edgeworth Day.  Poured from a corked 25.4 ounce bottle into a Sam Adams beer glass (laser etched bottom, shape similar to a Coke glass).  Floral, champagne-ish scent, pouring with a thick, creamy head that persisted for many minutes before settling with medium lacing left behind.  Lightly hazy amber color.  Taste reminded me of champagne and apples, with a medium heavy alcohol presence.  Body is creamy and only slightly on the thin side.  Overall, I found it enjoyable and warming. It was my first Tripel, and I plan to visit this one again.

Poured a darker gold out of the bottle, nice white head that hangs around with nice lacing.  Aroma is dominated by yeast and citrus fruits.  Taste is sweet with a dry finish, not as crisp as I expected. Nice light body feel. More complexity as the beer warmed, hard to tell this was 10%.  Nice.

There is a light sour vanilla aroma with some banana and licorice root. The color is golden red sunset with a medium lacing and consistent foamy head. The flavors are sweet, sour, and strong ale smooth booziness.

330ml Bottle: Pours pumpkin in colour, started off with a nice thick white head but quickly dissipated to almost nothing, albeit some nice lacing left behind. Sweet caramel aroma with black pepper, citrus fruits, alcohol, and prunes. By far the smoothest of the three, and providing a rather pronounced hop slam as compared to the others. Unfortunately the bitterness is a bit nondescript, and its all a bit light on the mouthfeel. Still, a nice subtle sweetness, bready, peppery, lemon and a lot of booze. I like it, but I actually preferred the 8.
pours a nice copper colour with a nice light creamy head which leaves a excellent lacing. taste a little malty flavour with a sweet alc. aftertaste  little dark smooth vanilla oak maybe
Nice abbey beer. sweet with a citrus note. citrus, alcohol, vanilla,

Bottle at home. Pours a beautiful hazy coppery orange with a thick, foamy, rocky white head that leaves excellent lacing. Delicate aroma of citrus, spices and some grass. Nice flavor of spices, grass, floral notes and with a definite alcohol presence. Creamy texture and lively carbonation. A very nice tripel.

Mmmmm, so nice. Served with a HUGE, foamy, frothy, fluffy, cream colored head that lasts a long time and a load of clumpy lace. Aroma is very malty, a bit roasty, caramel, toffee, perfume, spice, alcohol, and a little floral. Taste is similar with bittersweetness standing out along with the alcohol. Great body and carbonation. Easier to drink than one might think considering the richness and strength.  Finish is medium in length but nice.

750, corked and baled. Pours a crystal clear dark gold with a towering, fluffy, unmanageable platinum blond head. Decent rings of eggy lace on the way down. Big stale cooked sugar nose, has a bit of a synthetic/processed tinge to the sugariness. Creamy medium body with plenty of soft, subtle, tight carb. Green apples, caramel, sweet cream, and some lactic tartness on the mid-palate. Lingering fruity finish. Nice stuff. I can remember flipping over this beer on draft about five years ago, and have never found the same satisfaction from it in package of any size. Havent happened to see it on draft since then, either. Maybe the future holds a proper faucet pour of it, but, for now, the rate will have to be from under the cork.

Candi sugar and sweet malts on the nose with floral honey notes.  Pours blonde with a thick white head.  Floral and sweet, malty with honey notes, candi sugar, with spicy yeast characteristics.  Not bad but somewhat  one dimensional.
een mooie middelmatig donkere amber kleur met een dikke witte kraag. een zoete volle smaak, lichte caramel smaak. een fijne verfrissende en ook zoete na smaak.

slightly hazy amber in the Brewery selected goblet.  Decent amount of lacing.  Alcohol aroma that gets a littler stronger after warming.  Cidery off taste on the palate.  This Tripel is one of my least favorites.
Really disappointed by this one. The flavors ok, but leaves an unpleasant sort of aftertaste after a bit. One glass was enough for me.

Pours hazy amber with a decent head and nice lacing.
Malty aroma.
Heavy sweet flavor with little hops.  
Overall very nice.  Well-balanced.

Bottle at home.
Slight hazy amber with a tall white head, excellent lacings. Aroma heavy malty (caramel, light fruits), light hoppy. Flavor heavy sweet, light bitter. Full body, warming.

On tap at the englander. Pours golden orange with a white head. Aroma is spicy with apples, pears, plums, and caramel. The flavor is complex, with the same fruitiness and spiciness, but with a very bitter citrus peel finish. Very nicely balanced with a sweet caramel like effect on the palate. Medium bodied with nice lacing on the glass.

( 750ml bottle thanks to BA zdk9) Very dark pour that is golden/burnt orange color with a HUGE 3 finger head. Recedes slowly and lacing is awesome. Smells very sweet, extremely boozy, and not a lot of fruit coming through. Lots of caramel, some toastiness and the alcohol almost burns my nose. Very alcoholic taste with caramel, roasted malt. Mouthfel is nicely carbonated, perfectly oily and thick enough to warrant a high rating. More of a Belgian strong to me than a tripel.
Draft @ Ginger Man. Amber pour with white head. Alcohol, citrus, fruits, belgian sugars and yeasts. Warming is moderate.
Orange coloured beer with a small white head. Sweet malty aroma. Flavor is sweet, fruity and alcoholic. Very powerfull brew. (Bottle 33cl)

Aroma is strong with hints of clove and strong alchol presence is detected.  Beer is a beautiful medium copper with a nice white head.  Taste has citrus notes which can be tasted in the back of the throat.  Beer is dominated by an alchol presence.  Palate is nice, coming across somewhat dry with good carbonation for the sytle.  Overall the beer was middle of the road for me, I wouldnt spend what I did for another bottle in the future

UPDATED: APR 19, 2012 Bottle. Candied malt aroma. Golden Body with medium, lasting head.  Flavor begins sweet with floral notes, hints of barley, caramel and yeast.  Also can taste a little orange, pine with a bitter finish.  Alcohol is well hidden, excellent, complex beer.

Sweet bready yeast aroma with whiff of alcohol that messed up my sense of smell. Light transparent (enuf to see bubbles) orange with small white head that laces as it thins. Dry but sweet refreshing (enuf to forget its 10%) bready yeast. Dry clean aftertaste (here comes the alcohol).
750ml bottle. Poured out dark gold with white head. Smelled of yeast and fruit. Taste is very yeasty with an appreciable amount of alcohol. Finish is warm. It was tasty. I would drink again happily.
Somewhat Boozy malty fairly sweet triple that avoids the harsher chemically bitterness some triples have. Very good, surprisingly easy to drink given its abv.

Golden, light brown pour with medium foamy head, quickly dissipates.
Strong hoppy aroma, bitter and sour.
flavour of malts, some hops, slightly sweet.
Nice beer, but not a favorite somehow.

large off white head. good lacing. mostly diminishing. flat thin amber body. aroma: caramel, honey, pessego em calda, very fruity. if: heavy sweet moderate bitter. ff: moderate bitter moderate sweet. long duration. palate: medium body, creamy texture, medium carbonation and moderate alcoholic and metallic finish. gosto bem frutado. aquecimento alcoolico. leves toques mel e malte no paladar. 110s.  R$ 21.
Pours out a dark golden color with a white head that lingers. Flavor is very complex, but the alcohol is most apparent, which isnt necessarily a bad thing here. Very crisp finish.

330 ml stubby bottle

Poured a honey gold color, with about a 1 1/2" foam head.
This beer went down pretty good for a triple beer.
Leaves you with a pretty good buzz.
I will defiantly be buying this one again.

750ml bottle. POurs hazy amber with a big fluffy head. Long head retention, extensive lacing. Nose very yeasty and spicy. Hints of alcohol and and fruits. Taste is very yeasty with an appreciable amount of alcohol. Finish is warm and spicy. Some alcohol and fruits also. A bit too much alcohol for my taste. Really nice beer overall.

75cl bottle. This pours an orange amber colour with a fair sized white head. The aroma is spiced raisins with an alcohol nose. Flavours of raisins and spice. For the ABV this is an easy beer to drink. Overall this is an excellent tripple.

On tap at Au Fut et a mesure, Lille, 12th Dec 09. Golden orange with a little bit of head. Gentle aroma - very hard to pick up. On the tongue there is a pronounced bitterness. Alcoholic heat at the back of the throat. Dry finish. Not as good as I hoped it would be.

Poured hazy amber with a big head made up of loose foamy bubbles, I found this beer to be rather delicious with its light sweetness. The hops are not overly done and there is a slight fruit note to the beer. All and all an enjoyable beer.

With a swing and miss on Maredsous 8, I was slightly hesitant about giving this one a go but in the end it was really a damn good beer.  It poured out of the stubby bottle a dark, cloudy orange body, a thick 2" creamy off-white head and beautiful lacing.  The head had really impressive staying power too.  Coming off the top of this thick head were huge wages of alcohol, flowers, honey, shortbread cookies, and light pitted fruit.  Spicy bread notes, banana, alcohol, with a honey-like finish.  The only thing negative to find was the overbearing carbonation found in many Belgian style beers and while some work well, this was manageable but it could have been worse.  The beer really worked well over-all and is a nice beer to show someone the style of a tripel.
Pretty great tripel.  Aroma is sweet and yeasty.  Pours a golden amber.  Taste is quite sweet with yeast and malt.  I small bitterness in the aftertaste.  Good beer.
Bottle. Pours yellow with large off-white head. Flavor is sugar sweetness with a big spice bite. Not my favorite Tripel.

750mL. Pours a clear yellow with a large, off-white head that has good retention and lacing. Aroma is macro-ish: grainy, sweet, a bit musty, corn., white sugar. Taste is earthy, lots of spice, some graininess, frosted corn flakes. Very different than I was expecting. Simple, clean, not too yeasty, sweet.
750 ml bottle. Clear copper pour with thin white head. Boozy yeasty aromas with a lot of grain and spice. Dry grainy taste with a nice warm spicy/peppery finale. Nice and warming.
Low on flavor. Dry aftertaste, some hoppines. Nice warming alcohol. Not a very special beer.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 Pours a dark orange with a medium head. The aroma was fruits and malts with a hint of alcohol. The taste is almost the same as the smell but a little more bold. It has a very nice depth and just enough complexity... made me wish I had another. This is a Tripel but I thought it had that extra something dark beers have. Great beer.

Pours from the stubby 11.2 oz bottle a hazy orangeish gold color with the typical HUGE Belgian head that settles into very thick collar.  The carbonation is also typical of a Belgian...what seems like millions of tiny bubbles race to the underside of the head of foam that remains.  Wonderful aroma...peaches, apricot, and hone come to mind.  The first sip has a dry, spicy, peppery note that belies the sweet, fruity aroma.  Mouthfeel is light and tingly from the carbonation.  There is an odd bitterness on the swallow, a somewhat "chemical" note that lingers after the swallow and takes a couple of points off of the total enjoyment.  (Note:  upon further review, that taste may be from the yeast sediment.  In the interest of fairness, ill have to pour another one at another time, sans sediment, and see how it stacks up.)  There really isnt much hint of the 10% abv...no harshness or alcohol burn.  That makes this a slightly dangerous brew in the sense that it could sneak up on you & bite you if youre not careful.  Overall, a good triple, but not quite good enough to call one of my favorites.

750mL bottle for the third or fourth time.  Pours golden with a nice, thick head that leaves good lacing the whole way.  Smell is sweet, yet pretty standard for most tripels.  Taste is spicy, carbonated, and sweet.  A little too much alcohol left on the palate but still good.
Big sale at a local off-sale. Nice rick flavor. Fruit and spice, creamy and sweet but with a fairly dry finish.

Amber colour with a nice head, malty aroma, liquorice and malt taste, I have read lots of reviews of this beer with many varied description of the taste, well to me it tasted like a good, strong, Abbey beer should taste, it was very nice indeed.

Bottle served in a tulip. Best before 06/2011. Well within that window. Clear rich honey in color with a large foamy off-white head. Strikingly similar in appearance to the delicious IPA I just quaffed. A little more carbonation and better head retention. Great lacing. Pilsner nose. Oh, wait theres more. Doughy, light bubblegum. Gaining momentum now. Lacks the sweetness of most belgians. Flavor is a doughy and mildly sweet and mildly bitter. Mild all-around actually. Light-medium body, some carbonation. Oily, bitter, alcohol finish. Not great.

A clear amber orange with an off white foam with some spotty lacing and falling in different spots faster than others.  Aroma is musty, some fruitiness, biscuit, bready.  Taste is fruity still but more apples, pears, caramels, dried fruits, raisins, prunes.  Then an unfortunate wash of alcohol just ruins it.

Astringent, bittersweet with a lot of alcohol. The sweetness is cloying for me, like drinking honey. 
Might have been the batch, or just me.

note from 8/3. @ Tylers Apex. Goos aroma, sweet, little tart. Fruity, apple, kind of a sherry thing, mineral water. Brownish orange color, good head and lace. Sweet and spiced flavor, Candied sugar, little yeasty spice. Thick body, creamy oily mouthfeel, dry finish. Good brew, Really rich flavor, which was my favorite part, nice sweet spice thing going on.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle from Mr Lawrence wine merchants, Brockley. Pours a clear amber colour with a good long lasting white head.Excellent carbonation.  Aromas of malts, toast, grapefruit, tangerine, quite herby. Heavy citrus burst in the taste with flavours of brown sugar, malts, apple, pear. Finishes hoppy, sweet and bitter. Very nice tripel.

Bottle. Large fluffy head. Brown, slightly unclear body. Quite fresh aroma of hops and malts. A little like traditional christmas beer. Sweet malty flavour, sweet from the alcohol I guess. Like a lager with much alcohol. (At home, 04.09.09)

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2010 Initial rating (11/20/09): Great looking beer -- it is opaque, resembles an unpasteurized apple cider. Deep golds. Lingering head -- sticks to the glass, but quite white in color. Smells of a tincture of alcohol, but also fermenting golden apples near fallen brown leaves in an orchard. Palate is full and satisfying -- almost bold, but not overwhelming. Quite sweet, anticipates a tang that never arrives. Detectable yeast and faint alcohol, but these add to the rustic quality of the beer. Almost creamy, traces of brandy, too.

Re-rating (10/2/10): Golden amber color. Translucent. Good lacing. Dried plum (prune), some cedar, sour cherry, and white pepper on the nose. Taste is sour cherry, some blackberry, apples, cedar, caramel, and even a yam-like quality. Rich. Palate is hot, nice carbonation, lithe -- finish is sweet and almost cloying. Too much for my tastes.

The aroma of roasted bread and malt, also some hints of alcohol (wine). the head is small, white and creamy-milky with a short duration. The body is dark red. The taste is light bitter and malty, like the aroma also a little bit like a red wine. The body is medium strong, creamy and with a lively carbonation.

Golden color and very long lasting white foamy head.  Nose almost like brandy.  Fruity and candy like taste with a tickling tartness on the tongue.  Alcohol warmth and distinct alcohol notes in the taste. Sweet fruity finish.
Better, but still have soemthing missing. I like the orange peel taste and the foam.

Om tap at the Blue Monkey.  Earthy and muddy on the nose, with some barnyard tendencies.  A distinctive and different tripel that has spice and subtle hop notes.  Not my favorite, but a decent beverage.
Great Tripel. Not a favorite of the style, but one I would recommend. On tap at RNH

Bottle.  Pours a honey amber with big fluffy off-white head.  Aroma and flavor is of spices and sweet candied fruits.  Though it has a high alcohol content, it doesnt taste quite as strong as I expected.  Not bad!

Pours manuka honey with a big cloudy head. The aroma is sweet, malts, and astringent alcohol, grappa, light fruit. The flavour is prominently yeasty, with a good malty baseline, light apple, and pear,  some boozy sweetness, in a good way, ends on a medium dry bitter note. The abv really works for this beer. My favorite of the Maresous. Among one of my favorite Triples.

330ml bottle, Trappist glass.  Hazy, orange-amber hue, impressive large foamy head with creamy top diminishes to lasting thin creamy off white head with excellent lacing.  Complex sweet fruity and spicy aromas some banana some raisin.  Flavour is also complex; moderately sweet very fruity and moderately bitter spicy flavour. Warm dry woody bitter finish rounds off the initial sweetness.  Very very enjoyable!

Beautiful amber coloured beer with a tall, pretty head. Hazy and unclear. Full-bodied, rather fruity with a pleasant soft hop-touch. Extremely easy to drink in spite of the high alcohol. A very warming strong abbey beer
Nice hazy golden color. Not as sweet as some tripels (which is a plus in my book). Nice smooth flavor with some hops, some spice, almost a weizen flavor to it. Very nice beer.
golden/copper pour with foamy white head.  lacing.  freshly baked bread, light spice, fig aroma.  flavor much the same.  alcohol a bit harsh.  light sourness.

Bottle 33. Golden hazy ale. A typical tripple, with an unbelievable hops flavour neer to Duvel king of. Quite alcoolic, the aroma took some astringent notes from wheat (but is seems there is no wheat in it!).

750ml bottle poured into plastic cups at a Halloween party, therefore Im unable to comment on the appearance.  I was disappointed that this wasnt a better abbey ale.  Although the flavor was pleasant, it was very weak.  High alcohol content was noticeable.

This is a lighter, highly drinkable, yet complex and interesting tripel.

This is deep gold with a huge, airy, off-white head that shrinks slowly, leaving some decent lace.

Aroma is light fruit, grapes and grape juice, with wine, hints of herbs and bread, metal, faintly reminsicent of a maibock.

The taste is similar, but more interesting and complex, with lemon, white/green grapes, hints of raisin, herbs, bread crust, alcohol, with a bread-grain aftertaste. Body is light but complex, zesty, lively, crisp, and interesting.  it is highly drinkable.
Golden amber brew with a creamy head. Sweet citrusy flavor with a drier finish. the high alcohol level comes through as warmth rather than harshness. Will be going out to buy more soon.
Pours a cloudy golden color w nice white lacing. Malty, raisin, spice aroma.  Tastes just like it smells, raisins and spice. For a high etoh content beer its very easy to drink. A well brewed beer.

Bottle. Pours a golden color with a nice white head. Aroma is very fruity, spicy, yeasty with notes of orange, citrus and banana, some mild grassiness. Flavour is malty, fruity and spicy with clear orange-like notes, citrus, and warming alcohol. Light bitterness in the finish. Quite lively carbonation. Mediumbodied.

Bottle. Deep golden colour with a medium-sized white head. The aroma is banana, malt, spices and some fruity hops. Malty flavour with some sweetness and notes of spices, yeast and fruits. Very smooth mouthfeel. A good tripel.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy, amber color with a large, frothy off-white head.  Aromas of bananas, flowers, light lime, and a hint of sage.  Lively mouth feel with a crisp start and then a lively, creamy finish.  Very unique for a Belgium beer.  Flavors of bananas, yeast, grapefruit, and some lemon as a light finish.  Fantastic beer, probably the best Belgium I have had.  Definitely purchase this on a regular basis.

Enjoyed from an 11.2oz bottle in a tulip glass.  The beer pours a deep yellow to almost amber with a merangue-like head that lasts through the beers entire consumption.  The nose is curious, giving notes of clove and pilsner sweetness, more like a German hefeweizen than an abbey tripel.  Some yeast character was also present, but it seemed rough and unrefined, especially in relation to other stylistic benchmark beers.  The palate is somewhat insipid, and lacks complexity.  A touch of malt sweetness, strong carbonation, and more clove character.  Overall, a disappointment.

bottle 33 cl; Nice deep golden colour with a coarse foam that rapidly disappears. The smell is caramel, sweet and spicy (reminds me of koreander) and the taste is initially sweet but afterwards a little malty and bitter. The aftertaste is sticky and bitter. An average triple.

Pours into a chalice with a storm of bubbles and a huge fluffy head, looks perfectly appetizing to me. Aroma is citrus and hops, some orange peel, tinge of alcohol but given the percentage its not nearly as noticeable as one would expect. Taste is a combination of malts, alcohol, hops, nicely combined and quite drinkable and refreshing, but not really overly complex. Quite liked this one, especially as an everyday beer.

A dark gold, light brown pour with an ample white head that was kind of creamy, kind of rocky and produced good lacing.  The aroma was faint yeast, spice and crisp apple.  The flavor was the same with some alcohol heat noticed.  Almost medium bodied, nicely carbonated.  Enjoyable.
Dark brown with thick head that dissipates.  Very malty with a punch of alcohol to go with it.  A little dry almost.
Dark gold/brown pour.  Lots of fruity esters.  banana, yeast, spice, sweet bread, raisin, and a bit of earth and pepper.  Sweet beer, not my thing right now.  Nothing exceptional, but still good.

33 cl bottle. Deep golden color with huge airy, white head. Aroma has typical spicy tripel character with slight vanilla hints
 and fruity esters. The flavor has nice and complex, sweet fruity profile with phenolic banana feel, nice crisp, peppery alcoholic mouthfeel. Very good balance between the fruity malt tones and the dry hop bitterness.
Lovely smooth body, oily texture, bone dry, peppery finish. Solid tripel.
I dont have a clue what kind of hops used in the Maredsous brews, but i found quite dry and hoppy all of them.

25.09.2009, 0,33l Bottle as Maredsous tripel. Brown colour with thick white head. A little hazy. Smell of yeast. Aroma is strong malty with an instant alcohol strength. Very rich aroma, Sweet, bitter, fruits and spices. Very nice. ྰ.10.2004. Smaksrik og god øl med syrlig sitrus preg. Bitterheten er kanskje litt skarp, ellers svært god)

Sampled at a craft beer tasting at Curlys Bar and Grill in Glen Ellyn, IL.. Poured a hazy, deep golden hue with a very modest, foamy, off white head that immediately diminished to a small ring and film, leaving some light, clingy strands and streaks of lacing. The aroma was spice, a touch of fruit sweetness, and vinous notes. The flavor presented a more intense vinous nature, light sweetness, smooth, warming alcohol, and a subtle dryness to the finish.

Kind of a gusher, pours medium peachy gold with a tall, orangish beige head that fades to a chunky 1-2 fingers in a couple of minutes and holds there. Aroma is caramel, grass, lightly toasted malt, bready yeast, some dusty apple and other light fruit notes come out as it warms, a little ethanol as well, but not too much, especially for 10%abv. Flavor is yeasty bread, apple, orange marmalade, sweet pear, green raisins, dusty toasted grain, sweet grass, light pepper and sweet floral notes. Finish is yeasty bread, salted sweet orange and a little spice. Palate is medium bodied, slightly oily and even a little creamy in the middle with an active, yet soft carbonation and lightly dry finish, nice! Overall this is probably better than your average tripel, the only thing that I really thought stood out was the mouthfeel, which was great.

300 ml bottle; clear dark orange-amber with thick, eggy white head; apples and juicy fruit; silky smooth with medium body and slight fizz; fruit, yeast and pears; nose seems sharp at first with intense sugar and fruit; finishes with a dry sweetness; a very nice triple with plenty of sugary sweetness, fruit and touch of spice w/o becoming to syrupy and flat
Orange colour with a nice, fruity aroma. Sweet taste with a fruity flavour, mainly pear, plus some spice. 10% alcohol well disguised, this is definitely a good un.
Very thick feeling, sweet aroma, tastes a little of bread, raisins and citrus, coats the throat.  Not as good as the 8, but still very good.
medium body, thick feel, average carbonation, long finish, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium sweetness.

pours a fairly clear light orange with rocky yellowish head.
aroma is very subtle, lemon peel, peach candy, and a discernable hop bitterness. definitely some belgian dark fruit in there, but very mellow.
similar candy flavor, but very dry. medium/thin body and high carbonation -- both good with the flavor.
long dry and slightly astringent finish.
the label has just changed and its called Maredsous Triple now.  Golden colour

Pours a cloudy golden orange color with a thin foamy off-white head. Spicy aroma with hints of crisp light fruits, apple, pear, white grape, wheat and slightly sour citrus notes. Very carbonated followed by crisp fruit and alcohol taste with a slightly bitter finish. Alcohol very well masked with pear, apple, spice and sweet alcohol notes.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2011 Julios Belgian Beer Festival. Sample. By the time I got to this one I was seeing double. Rating it to keep track but dont have any particulars. My notes tell me that this one one of the better tripels tasted at the fest so need to do some followup tastings.

12/11 - Retasted from a bottle. Sticking with initial rating

on tap at maxs brick oven in paducah, ky. This is up there on my list of tripels. Great flavor, smooth and not overly carbonated as some belgians can be. It was sweet up front and all the way through. Such a great belgian, im looking forward to trying some other ones from this brewery.
Colore arancio velato con schiuma bianca e spumosa.Laroma è di caramello,agrumi, frutta scura e prugne.Sapore di caramello,malto e ancora frutta scura.Ottima!

330 ml bottle.  As it warms it just keeps getting better.  Right up there with the Chimays and the St. Bernardus and just below the Westverleven and Rocheforts.   If you like good beer you will enjoy this one.
Bottle. Pours hazy orange body with white head that lingers. Aroma is spice and alcohol. Taste is smooth, alcohol sting slightly, some spice.

330mL bottle into an abbey glass.  The pour is deep red/orange/brown with glints of yellow shining through and a creamy off-white head.  The aroma reminds of citrus fruits, dark fruits and prunes, caramel, butterscotch, and baking bread all at once.  The flavor leans at first towards an almost sour citrus blend then coats with malt, caramel, and darker fruits.  This beer is quite thick and sticks all over the mouth but still with nice carbonation.

I will always remember the timeless advocate of beer, Michael Jackson, when quaffing a Maredsous abbey ale. Self-proclaimed as his favorite brewery of abbey ales, it was easy to understand why after supping on their Tripel which has aged beautifully. As much as I love Belgian beers, I cant pick a favorite. Just when I think Ive made up my mind, I think of another Belgian beer I love and the cycle starts all over again. Meh. Im not even going to try anymore. In fact, enough of this blathering. I have a Maredsous Tripel to lavish praise upon.


As I slowly pour the liquid contents from her bottle into my chalice, my face glows as the sun descends from her heavenly throne to settle into my glass. Were there ever more brilliant hues of amber, garnet, blood-orange, and gold to grace a beer glass? As she reaches the top of my glass, a velveteen head of white foam preens most mighty before humbly leaving a scattered network of lace in memoriam. Just as her visage shines high noon from my glass, so too does her nose. Sweet, doughy, yeasty, spiced, and bursting with tropical fruits dangling plump from their limbs. Applesauce with cinnamon sprinkles and cooked apples, juicy and lip-coating to be sure. Oranges and mango exude ripeness even as bunches of herbs exude their own aromatics. Her alcohol warmth is sweet, melting into fruits, warm yeasty dough, and spices perfectly. A kiss of honey and life is bliss. With a nose as rich as this, so too must be her body. Thick and creamy dances with soft and effervescent every quaff of the way. Honey coats my lips as oranges and mangos melt in my mouth, not in my hand. Their juices trickle along the sides of my mouth while honey and cinnamon-sugar sprinkles join the fray. The meat of her palate is all sweet tropical fruits, dough, and spice while her finish is warm and dry. I can definitely start to feel her alcohol warmth as my chest and cheeks develop a pleasant glow. My breath is all about fresh herbs and then suddenly, sooner than I wished, my glass is empty.


A rich palate leads to a rich soul. Even the simplest of beers can have a rich palate, though there is usually nothing simple about quaffing a Belgian tripel. The Maredsous Tripel, aka the Maredsous 10, is an excellent abbey tripel. Considering they are brewed by Duval-Moortgat, this comes as little surprise. Make sure to note the best-buy date on the back, and enjoy anytime before then. Ive had fresh and aged; both are beautifully in their own subtly different ways.

didnt notice anything special in aroma

gold/bronze color with off white head with the longest lacing of any beer I have had.

perfect palate; complex and smooth tasting with carbonation and some spiciness (to me).

In my top 5!!!

Appearance:  Pours a cloudy yellow gold with a fluffy sudsy white head.

Aroma:  Banana, spices (cloves and corriandor) and other scents associated with Tripel yeast. As it warms up, there are vanilla notes that come through.

Taste:  A huge burst of fruity yeast, some dry malt, and a fruity finish with a little bit of spicy hop bite in the fnish.

Mouthfeel: Thick.

Overall: Average.

This is really nice. Possibly accentuated by the record daytime temps today... =)  Pours a golden amber - color of a good DIPA - with a classic (huge) Belgian head. Aroma has lemon zest, black pepper, some butterscotch, and other spices (coriander). Flavor pulls through with an effervescent maltiness and some surprisingly present hops - very crisp, nice and refreshing. I like this one quite a bit better than I thought I would. A bit boozy, though.
(bottle) golden with off-white head; faint malty aroma; faint and dull flavour with predominant alcohol; once again one of my least favourite Belgians
Nicely balanced, bitter throughout with a bot of lemon and pepper in the background.  Nice example of the style.
Bottle. Weak aroma. Golden colour, slightly hazy. At first quite alcoholic flavour, but it turns warming and pleasant. Medium sweetness and maltiness. Dry aftertaste. Way overpriced
Flaske: Flot udseende trippel med et lille skumhoved. Meget kraftig parfumeret og god smag. Desværre ikke så megen karbonering hvilket gør alkoholen en tand for mærkbar. God nonetheless.

Purchased 750ML bottle @ Liquor Barn in Redding, CA. Color: Deep golden- I like tripels in this color. Bouquet: Has aroma of butterscotch, mango. Flavor: Alcohol come in, but not too abrupt. Coriander, citrus. Palate / finish: slight hop dryness and deep mailtiness. This is one of my fave triples of all time.

bronzeish golden color, offwhite head smells malty,fruity(oranges,lemons, a bit like peaches)  bittersweet ,bitteralmonds, corriander-like spicyness 
tasts bittersweet, of corriander, malty, fruity (oranges,lemons, a bit like peaches)  aftertaste spicy, citrus, warm alcohol, bittersweet

11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours a nice amber color with a creamy, white head.  It has a lighter nose than I was expecting with slight vinous notes, a bit of earth, and yeast.  Medium-high carbonation with a medium mouthfeel and a good bit of dryness.  Boozy fruit, candy sweetness, and a little hop note.  The alcohol is pretty well hidden in this one.  Medium finish.  Overall it is okay, but no big wow factor here.

750 ml bottle. A hazy pale amber beer with a medium sized and persistent white head. The aroma is malty, with some fruitiness, some hops and a hint of alcohol. The flavour has a quite high sweetness, with some acidity and bitterness. Spicier and hoppier than in the aroma. Medium to full body, lively carbonation, long finish with medium bitterness, quite alcoholic. Quite satisfacting, but I expected more.

Birthday present thanks to a friend of mine, Lauren
Pours with a clear, dark golden hue with a small white head that is mostly diminishing. Bottle was a fozzer when first opened. 
Aroma is of yeast, bread, alcohol, hops, and very malty.
Flavor has a lot of alcohol in the beginning, light sour in the middle, and a yeasty, light bitter ending.
Medium mouthfeel with lively carbonation.

Bottle - 330ml. Superb hazy amber/orange body with low carbonation and an average lasting off-white foamy/creamy head. Nice malty/hoppy aroma with grainy and yeasty hints. Alcohol is perfectly hidden. Very well balanced taste carries fruity and yeasty notes. Texture is soft. Bittersweet finish is long and warming. Very good example of and Abbey Tripel.

Pouered in my Chimay chalice. A hazy dep golden hue with a very creamy layer of foam resting on top. Laces the glass well. Yeasty and peppery with a smooth yet well carbonated body. Some fruit is noticable also alcohol. Flavor lacks a bit. Not bad but much better Tripels to be had.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Aroma is nice and malty, colour a reasonably light clear amber - nice head retention - smooth mouthfeel - flavour is good, lots of sweet maltiness, definately a yeasty fruit character, alcohol just about apparent, dry finish - after taste is the best part.

Tap - dark for a trippel with a translucent orange hue.  Average head with moderate carbonation.  Dry, spicy and fruity.

from Hamiltons

750ml bottle. Extremely smooth. The first time I tried this beer I compared it to the quality of a fine wine and I stand by that sentiment. A nice orange coloured beer, perfect amount of carbonation, a very memorable beer. The bottle it comes in is extremely interesting too!

330 mL bottle from Hillcrest Whole Foods (San Diego, CA).  Pours a dark amber color, bordering on light brown.  The very big white head is composed of some rather large bubbles, but reduces to a steady one centimeter or so.  Aroma of bread, musty and mildly sweet malts, banana, light spice.  Flavor is malty and lightly sweet with some lemon and a bit of pepper.  The finish has light alcohol and a noticeable hoppy bitterness.

Found a 750 mL bottle of this brew. Pours a slightly cloudy golden with a very thick white head. Aroma is good deal of pilsner malt with a very light spice, bread and lemon. Flavor follows a good bread presence, slight clove flavor, light straw ending.  This beer has to have a HUGE OG because it has almost NO alcohol flavor and is very sweet and seemingly a low attenuated beer. Not an ounce of dryness in the finish which is kinda odd for a Tripel. Great lacing on the glass from this brew. Overall a very good brew but kinda miss the dryness and crisper feel of a tripel from this beer.
Nice golden colour, totally clear, with a small white head that disperses quickly.  Honey and spice flavours.  Drinks extremely well.
Smells citrusy and slightly fruity. Tasty, salty?, palate not overly complex. Tastes very dry. Overall, very run of the mill for a Belgian, though that still is good.

REMEDIAL STUPORS !
Strong Tripel enjoyed in the fading sunshine of the balcony. The pour was pert and amber with an average head. Strong smell and as 10%ers go this one tasted stronger. Im a big fan of tripels but this seemed to lack some of the characters of others. Hard to define definite flavours other than the taste of spice

Location:
Rating is from Feb 09, from a bottle I believe I got it at Nroms
Overall Impression: 
Pretty enjoyable beer. Pours a nice golden color with plenty of head. Your wouldnt necessarily guess that its 10% from the taste, but it has a noticeable alcohol kick.

Poured a deep orange color with a nice frothy white head that left a bit of lacing. Spicy fruity aromas and flavors with a slight alcohol burn. Sweet flavors of bubblegum and maybe some caramel? Well either way this was a strong, full-bodied Tripel not for the light-hearted.

0,75lt Bottle. Beer Factory Athens. Lovely amber color with a big foamy white head. Fruity aroma with lots of spices. Complex but rather pleasant. Nice flavor or spices, malt and ripe fruit. Very nice.

bottle.  a big Abbey Tripel... pours a deep orange with a nice white head.  yeast, banana, and citrus in the aroma.  full medium body with some strong spice and yeast notes up front with a huge body over the top with some more banana, light fruit and candi sugar.  Strong finish with some alcohol (slight burn) and bright sweetness with a deeper malt presence.  A nice strong full bodied tripel.

Nice cloudy orange-amber body with a superb,huge, stable and lacing white head. Aroma of fruits like figs and raisins, some herbal notes of hop, liqueric malt.Thick body with oily texture, fine sweet flavor of malt, caramel, spicy and herbal tastes with nice fruity notes like pine and citruses. The beer warms me up with the well hidden high percentage of alcohol... Very nice.
orange golden white head. aromas of spice amlt, bread, caramel, some banana and alcohol. tart flavour that follows the aroma medium bitterness. warming.

Bottle. Hazy orange gold, large puffy white head that reduces to a dense white frothy skim. Aroma is sweet, with elements of straw, dried flowers, light lemony citrus, and cooked noodles.  Straw-like malts, sweet, with perfumey hops, vaguely spicy with a dry peppery bitter finish. Warm and a bit boozy, but not harsh. I wasnt blown away, but then again triples arent my favourite style.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: This is a beautiful looking beer. Pours a hazy pumpkin golden orange with a heavy dark amber base and a sudsy soapy head. Smell of apricots, rum, toffee, butter, and mango. Taste was not very sweet, but quite light and crisp and clean. Very nice finish with a slight syrupy sting from the alcohol and a dry palate. Apple and cider taste as well. Although there are some good things happening with this brew, it could have used some more character to define itself. Sadly, this seems kind of one-dimensional in taste but stands out as a pleasant drink nonetheless. Listened to Les Rallizes Denudés while drinking this one and it hightened the experience slightly.
Last one on the way of the three Maredsouses in the pack. Pours dark golden with medium head. Bready and nut notes in it, no traces of alcohol. Good.

Amber body, thin but lasting head. Nose of alocohol, figs, burnt raisins, apples and caramel. Taste was hints of sour apple and malt, quite spicy and dry, full of earth notes. Taste of alcohol was too powerful upon warming. Foamy palate, dry and crisp. NIce beer.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2009 A copper hazy beer with a fluffy offwhite head. Smells of spice, with some bready maltiness in the background. The flavor has a darker, nuttier character to it, with some roasty notes. Fairly thin mouthfeel, but no trace of the alcohol.

bottle, small but stable white head, dark golden/soft orange colour. The maredsous 10 looks like an average tripel. I get a fruity and alcoholic smell. But you taste a totally different beer then you should expect: grassy, hoppy, fruity, soft sweet, soft caramel and alcohol. The more you drink, the more grassy the beer gets. Not a special tripel and far too sharp!

bottle 33 cl. clear orange colour with a thick head that stays for while. THe taste is very powerfull (because of the amount of alcohol I guess) and reminds me more of a dark beer: hops, a pinch of caramel and fruits. Rather bitter aftertaste, but the tastes of sweetness and bitterness complete eachother.

Bottle, new label or something...tart, a little sour. Predominant flavor of green apple, a bit too much like cider, actually. Vinuous and grapelike too. Some fruit rind bitterness. Alcohol noticeable. Carbonation minimal. Somewhat disappointing.

Celebrate the end of the english fotballseason with this fine beer, go Chelsea F.C.! Bottle 33 cl. Apperance; Amber/golden, hazy with a nice and lasting creamy offwhite head. Aroma; Fruits, Caramel, alcohol and some yeast. Flavor; Fruits with a warm bitter ending.

33cl bottle, clear amber colour, creamy and persistent white head, caramel aroma, fruits (apple) and wine notes, sweet flavor, full body, interesting finish with some pear, hops and alcohol, hint of bitterness aftertaste

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2009 750 ml bottle aged close to 5 years. 2005 vintage. Aroma of peaches, a bit of pineapple, some funky horse blanket, pears, leather, apple. Very fruity flavor, with hot alcohol and yogurt. Moving towards a lambic, bretty flavor. Sweet spices. Great balance and a sharp, crisp finish. Wonderfully complex.      
New bottle: Clear amber with a low but thick and frothy head. Faint aroma of caramel and dark fruit. Flavor of medium-rich malt, a bit of caramel sweetness, raisins, and a bit of apple balanced by big alcohol hear and hops. Just enough caramel and fruit to balance the big alcohol. Decent, but too boozy, and not enough malt flavor. I think this needs to age a bit. 6/3/7/4/14

Bottle. A deep golden coloured beer with a large white head. Citrus and fresh apple aroma. Initially it tastes very sweet but then a very slight bitterness kicks in. I keep thinking vanilla and butterscotch whenever I drink this beer. Very well balanced and the alcohol is well hidden. An elegant, complex, good  quality Belgian triple that I would recommend to anyone.

Bottle.  Pours a nice golden color with a thick, fluffy white head.  Aroma is fruity with notes of yeast and bread.  The flavor brings out a warm alcohol burn.  The finish was sweet and dry.  I am not a fan of Tripels, but I tried this one at a tasting and really enjoyed it.  So, I picked up a four pack.

Bottle thanks to AndyReynolds.  Its has a dark golden color with a huge white, foamy head that sticks around.  I dont like most Tripels, but was surprised by this one.  Reminds me alot of Leffe Blond.  Both have a very similar taste, but with this brew being more powerful.  Strong fruity flavors with a nice, dry finish.

2009 Bottle.  A tasty little belgian ale, which fulfills expectations.  Aroma of sweet alcohol, some sugary malts, like a good golden ale.  Tastes above average, though not as robust as Duvel or Leffe Blonde.  Malty in the beginning with effervescence and alcohol punching in midway.  A nice clean finish with an aftertaste/burn of alcohol.  A good experience.

$3.69 12oz bottle from Bevmo. I love triples and this is no exception.  Light amber color.  Fruity aroma.  Sweet. Large 3 finger lasting head.  Yeasty, light banana Belgian aroma.  Some alcohol in the nose indiscriminate hops of mild to low bitterness.  Very good.
UPDATED: JUL 29, 2009 Dense and creamy head, tastes long, fruity, full body, although you also taste the alcohol a liitle too much
This was at the Peoria Beer Festival.  I was a server that got to sample a couple beers.  I didnt take notes like I should have.

A typical Belgique monastery beer, light and refreshing, with hints of spice throughout. Sweet and creamy. However, nothing stood out to particularly separate it from the rest of the pack. I would buy it again though, its pretty good.

33cl bottle at a taverne in Liege, served in brand ceramic bowl. Dense, creamy head that hangs around for the entire ride. Sweet and fruity aroma. Pleasant, warm flavour with apricot and malt. Excellent.

pours a cloudy orange with a large dirty off-white head, leaves some lacing.

smell of sweet fruits, citrus, spice, and some wheat.

taste is fizzy, tart, sweet, apricot, peach, some wheat in the back, spices, and pepper, ends on the dry side.

12oz bottle poured after a nice meal, for a sit down chat with family.  The nose is sweet bread and fruits.  Has the most wonderful flavor.  It is dessert sweet fruits with a kick of alcohol.  Not really a negative, but the alcohol lets you know this is not a session beer or a guzzler after mowing the lawn.  Gets much more complex as it approached room temperature.  The cloves announce their arrival, and the sting of alcohol subsides.  Mouthfeel is smooth and full.  Does not effervesce.  Fantastic beer.
Very tasty. Light in color with a foamy lacing head. Nice aroma of sweet malt and dried fruit. Spicy flavor accents the malt sweetness. Alcohol warmth at the end.

Bottle at Monks Café, sveavägen, Stockholm

Apperance: Hazy golden colour, medium foam which left a nice lacing. 

Smell: The smell seemed very promising with hints of dried fruit, nuts and ham. To be more precise a kind of Spanish dried pork where the pigs have been feed on chestnuts. Very appealing smell indeed and it leaned towards wine so I was intrigued. 

Taste: The taste was a bit disappointing after having smelled it. The alcohol took over most of the taste and I had a hard time tasting the sweet and dried fruits. It did made my mouth tingle which I found odd, almost like when you eat a kiwi.

Poured slowly with a thick five-finger off-white head that stays, some lace. Medium carbonation. Cloudy, light amber color with chunky bits.  Starts as a sweet mix of malt, finishes sweet and fizzy. Nose has distinct alcohol tones but the malts are in the background. Excellent triple and one to mellow.  Get a 750 and split with your drinking partner. $4.20 for a 330ml from Colonial Spirits Acton, MA.

Usually not available in Quebec, I bought a few packages of Maredsous 8 and 10 in 750 ml bottles with a glass, in special for less than 20$, of course at SAQ (that was a hell of a deal, so I think I have a total of 7 or 9 glasses...)  First time I bought that package, it was for the 8, but the 10 became one of my favorite tripels.  Well-balanced flavors of citrus and various spices dominate an underlying sweetness, that time might unshy.  The bitterness is moderate in the longlasting aftertaste.   A very pleasant beer that I might not taste again for a long time since SAQ ran out of these packages...

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2009 750ml bottle, very cloudy, deep orange in appearance, almost hazy.  The head was very creamy, frothy that left medium lacing.  Nose is sweet, tart, and slight alcohol as it warms. Very yeasty, has citrus, apple and slight alcohol on the finish.

This one had been sitting in my cellar for about 3 months before I decided to chill and drink it.
33 cl bottle, Maredsous Abbaye-Abdij. Pours hazy amber with a frothy white head, which disappear fast..Aroma of fruits. Alcoholic taste, with peppers and nice hoppy taste in the end,

From an 11.5 fl. oz. bottle with an expiration date of 05 2011 and a lot code of L3031-1840.  The pour is a hazy copper-orange with a significant supply of foamy beige head that sticks around for the entire time.  I always like that quality. The aroma is a mixture of overripe fruit and yeast from the bottle fermentaion most likely.  Impressive heavier mouth feel. The taste is a mixture of yeast and alcohol but there is something vaguely pumpkin-like. It ends dry and definitely makes me lightheaded with the 10% ABV.  I cant help but to wonder if Belgian Monks are always buzzed in the monastary.

Pour from a 750 is clear deep amber with a thick creamy off white head. Smells of sugar, yeast and lemon. Taste is citrus with a little spice and a big hop finish. Hints of chocolate. Pallet is thin. Alcohol comes though as it warms.
Bottle. Pours orange with an off white head. Fruity aroma, citrus and peach. The flavor is also fruity, apple, and others, as well as a restrained presence of yeast. Pretty good.

33cl bottle shared with larryLSB.   Orange with a big white head and lots of chunky lace.   Aroma of lemon, orange marmalade, dough, spicy apple pie.   Great nose.   The flavor is medium-sweet with a peppery, hoppy finish that has some drying, sharp alcohol.   Medium bodied with fine carbonation.   Great aromas, but a bit too hot in the finish.   This might be one to try laying down for a while, and its one of the better values in imported tripels, so that just might be something I need to try.

33cl bottle. Amber, firm white head with tight lacing. Alcoholic, slightly malty aroma, sugar, cellar, light spices and canned mushrooms. Strongyl alcoholic flavor with metallic and cellary notes, very light spices. Boozy, tangy finish. Medium bodied, strongly carbonated palate, not too smooth. A poor lifeless tripel.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of light bread, roasted and caramel, light herbs for the hops, moderately musty and a light note of dough for the yeast, with hints of date, brown sugar and nutmeg. Head is average size, starts fizzy then settles frothy, white, has fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is sparkling clear amber/copper. Flavor starts moderately sweet and acidic, then the long finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic and moderately to heavily bitter. Palate is medium, oily, has a lively to fizzy carbonation and finishes moderately dry. Damn, that was a good Tripel. Probably my favorite. Let this one warm a bit.

bottle, dark amber, a little misty, with medium white head. malty beer covering the alcohol pretty well, given the percentage. ends a bit dry and bitter. overall allright, but not definitely not excellent.

Off white full lasting head. Deep amber colour. Aroma is malty, fruity with caramel, nuts and light spicy notes. Flavor is malty too, fruity with apricots tones, ending in a dry  and slightly wooden alcoholic finish. Medium to full bodied.

330ml Bottle  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia, WA
Aroma: Nice Belgian yeast and malt aroma.  Fruity with light spice.  
Appearance: Amber in color, clear with a thin head.  
Flavor: Nice Belgian flavor with a good amount of fruit in flavor to add.  The yeast was not over the top. 
Palate: Dry finish with a nice Belgian Mouthfeel. 
Overall: A very nice Belgian triple.  I liked this beer it was very tasty.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 11. 2 oz bottle.  Not much of an aroma, but what there is is nice and almost fruity.  No alcohol in the aroma even for a 10% ale.  Slightly cloudy golden apperance with a small white head.  Flavor is complex with it sometimes having an almost sweet flavor and other times almost bitter.  Finish is very dry.  A nice beer.
Dark gold, almost amber with large creamy white head. Sweet vanilla and spice aroma. Tangy caramel and dried fruit flavours, witha thick rich body.

Color is deep golden brown that has just a hint of red.  Carbonation is good with a tight white head.  Aroma is spicy with a nice fruity yeast scent.  Taste is light and fruity.  Starting with medium body it goes down with a light fizzy feel.  Finish comes out with a hint of malt, some apple and big honey then a nice Belgian yeast flavor coming on the end.  After taste is a continuation of the yeast and honey with a pleasant alcohol taste peaking thorough.  This is an excellent Triple, great flavor, easy drinking and great yeast and fruit flavors.

Sweet heavenly taste with honey and fruits. Quite pissy looks with light golden color almost clear. White pretty head. ABV 10 very well hidden. One of the best ever. every sip brings water on my mouth.
Incredible malts comparable to a good whisky aftertaste (oban... laphroaig... not sure) nice sweet sourness on aftertaste. excellent.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2009 Light alcohol scent with sweet hints. Nice alcohol tingle with a sour finish.
UPDATE: 11/10/2009 Lovely aroma of dark cherry, grapes and plum. Dark fruits abound. Nice reddish orange pour. Taste is grape upfront however lamed with water. Finish because of this is easy-drinking. Nice dark flavor. I stand by my original rating, just glad to add enriching comments to it.
A cloudy copper with fairly dense white head. Aroma of coriander, apples, and dust. Medium body. Flavor at the front is sweet and spicy, and smooth at the finish. Excellent.

Draught at TND:  Aroma of slight funk and malts.  Poured copper/amber in color with a tiny, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Sparkling.  Clear.  Flavor is lightly bitter and light to medium sweet.  Tastes of yeast, spices (from the yeast), light alcohol, slight bubblegum, and slight medicine.  Medium body.  Medium-dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Yeasty, medium-dry finish.  Not a great Tripel.
Pours slightly hazy orange with a thick white head that lingers. Aroma is mildly fruity tastes also semi-citrus. Excellent body, thick and rich. Nice lacing also.

11.2oz brown glass squat pry-top bottle. BB 04.2011 on back label. Thanks to our new Duvel rep., Tori, for this one.

Appearance: Started to flow over when I opened it, poured a sudsy orange-amber with 1.5 fingers of sudsy light cream head. Not quite clear.

Nose: Caramel and light milk chocolate are the first things to mind. Dried apricots, dried pineapple, and maybe a hint of black olives.

Palate: Lively and almost crisp with acidity. Very "bright." Hints of chocolate covered cherries (cordials), a moist tobacco note, plus that dried pineapple (covered in light milk chocolate) comes back. Papaya too, perhaps, without the chocolate.

Notes: A tasty tripel, but not my favorite. It manages to avoid feeling too sweet by having a little acidity to clean up the edges. Impressed with whole "milk chocolate" thing from such a pale beer. Well done.

Bottle best by 02/2009. Poured amber with a creamy off-white head that had some lasting and good lace. Fruit aroma with a light alcohol backing. The flavor prune and raisin with a malty undertone. Medium body, sweet, and dry.

Very, very good. But not up with the best triples Ive had. Thick slow moving head on the pour. Fun nose with of dark floral honeysuckle and a bit of fruit. Light golden orange in color. Flavor was a little overwhelmed by alcohol presence. Slightly disappointing also was the weight of the beer. This one just messed my digestive system up a bit. Odd. Still a good beer overall.

Honey gold beer with a nice big light golden head that at first is noisy and that dissipates slowly.  Thick lacing.  Plenty of visible carbonation.  Nose is sweet fruit and malt.  Flavor has plenty of alcohol with fruit and hop bitterness.  Feel is zesty and dry.
Dark blond colour with lumpy, foamy head. Perfumed floral aroma. Silk textured beer with nice balance of grains and sweetness with warming hint of alcohol.

Pours a trouble amber color with a very thick tan color and lacy head.  Aroma is  sweet mixed fruits and some vanilla with a good strong alcohol feel.   Its flavors are fruits and sweet malts with oranges.  Its a really nice beer, great blend of flavors.

Poured hazy orange with initial large white head that settles. Alcohol, tart peach aroma. Strong alcohol, peppery flavour. Hoppy finish. Warms up your gut. Not my style. I enjoyed  Maredsous 8 the most.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2010 bottled. pours murkey orange. small white head. nose of citrus and honey. tastes of hops malt and citrus fruit. FInshes weak, not a big fan of this brew

2nd time around from a 25.4 oz bottle. Head is almost frothy, lost of lively carbonation, i can detect orange and honey. Itsdefinitely better than the 1st time i tried it. I will be buying again.
On Tap.  Muddy amber with full head.  Aroma: Strong fruity, alcoholic, Flavor: Malty sweet finish

On tap at west side B. Café in NYC.  Poured golden, albeit slightly hazy, with a thin white head that left nice lacing.   Aroma was fruity and slightly sweet.  Flavor is spicy up front, dry with esters.   Palate is medium.

Bottle...  Poured a foggy orange with a frothy, white head.  Wine-like aroma with some yeast.  Dry, highly carbonated palate,  flavors of apples and other fruity esters with little-to-no bitterness.  Dry finish with some malted grains and a little alcohol.

Bottle.  Pours orange tan, medium off white head, good retention.  Nose is fruity, standard belgian.  Hits a little sour, candy malt, fruit, slight citrusy hop finish.  A good triple, though nothing you cant find elsewhere.  Perhaps a little more citrus than to my liking in a belgian.

33 cl bottle in gift pack from LCBO, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. JA01/09.
App.:  Clear, light amber, with a large, loose froth.
  
Aroma:  Some lemon/citrus, light floral honey, some sweet grain and cereal, alcohol, light fruitiness.
  
Palate:  Medium body, fairly full but soft effervescence, slightly astringent.
  
Flav.:  Some brown sugar, light honey, still some sweet grain/cereal, more fruity than the nose; sweet with a little bitterness, a fair bit of alcohol and light lingering sweet malts.

Not really a fan of the style and this is not a good example anyway!

6-3-6-3-
Bottle from Vinmonopolet. Strong malty aroma with some yeast character. Malty sweet, warming alcohol, full body. Very drinkable, but it lacks the little extra to lift it above the crowd.

Aroma is sweet malt and citrus, maybe even red grapes. Translucent appearance the color of fall wheat, with a low carb head that keeps lightly present throughout. Grapes, raisins, pears, citrusy sweetness throughout, with some spicy yeast in use. Creamy but lively and abrupt finish, finally giving away to some alcohol-ness. Enjoyable, not the best tripel, but far from the worst.

Poured an orange tint with a small to almost no head. Maybe I was not aggressive enough. Will try on the next one. It had a surprisingly floral nose. On the palate, the floral notes from the hops carried on with some apricot and subtle pear flavors. A small sweetness appears on the palate before it finishes quite dry. Maybe too dry....

Bottle drink by May 2011. Cloudy orange/amber beer with meringue head that  just wont go away. Its probably still in the glass in my sink. Effervescent, medium bodied. Fruity (peachy?) and spicy and dry, and slightly tangy, but the 10% alcohol is too much not to be noticed.  Beer champagne in a neat stubby bottle.

Bottled, BB March 2008.  Poured clear brighter orange with a short cap of eggshell head.  The aroma opened with soft bready and honey notes, and it ramped up quickly in intensity with floral notes and a very distinct yeast character.. warm, but there was enough sweetness to head off the boozage.  The flavor had honey and pale malts on the semi-sweet to sweet core with warm floral notes and cloves around.. there was a heavy kick of warmth on the aftertaste and extending to the stomach.  Medium-bodied with moderate carbonation on the palate.. quite dusty and yeasty overall.. only a decent transition from the soft fore to the aggressive finish.

Une bier que doit me parler francais ici. 

Cette triple cuivreux de Maredsous, ou Dix (10), avait nune goûts plus blondes que vous pensent. Elle a toujours des nuances profondes entre les bitters doux et de houblon. Herbes ne semble pas impliquée. Une plat honnête triple.

------ beer made me speak french. 

This copper coloured triple Maredsous 10, tastes fairly more blonde than you would expect. It has many nuances between the soft bitters of hop and its dry sweetness. Herbs do not seem to be used in this recepy. A flat honest tripel.

Sweet, warm and alcoholic. Spicy, fruity, yeasty. Nice amount of carbonation without having a thin body. This one was nice to drink and the 10% made finishing the bottle all the more fun. Recommended.
Amber color and a little hazy with a small off-white head. Aroma is of yeast and spices. Flavor is of coriander and bananas.
I love maredsous, but a too strong for me

Bottle. Aroma was a nice mix of sweet and yeasty. Coppery, golden-brown when poured with a thick head that persisted a good long time. Very nice-looking in the glass, with its attractive color and fast rising bubbles.  A full mouthfeel; the carbonation was noticeable, but not overpowering. Taste was complex, dry, earthy. Flavor strengthened as it warmed. Alcohol flavor was almost unnoticeable. Among my favorites so far.

Lots of wood and caramel with some sugar in the aroma. Clear light amber/orange with small white head and nice lacing on glass. Dry woody with alchohol warming. Medium body and mouthfeel. Very dry woody finish with moderate alchohol warming and slight peppery bitterness.
Pours hazy ambr with large head. Very good lacing. Aromas of caramel, cotton candy and malts. Taste is mildl bitter, alcohol present, sweet. B+

Bottle. Pours a clear golden/amber with a fluffy white head. Nice lacing. Spicy aroma, notes of yeast and yoghurt. Remote notes of dental floss(!) as it warms. Spicy, malty flavour with a tart yoghurt-like note. Finish has a sharp, spicy alcohol-note. Soft palate. Pretty okay, but nothing extraordinary. 14-01-09.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2009 I had this from a bottle. Aroma for me seemed fairly faint and hard to determine, but it wasnt unpleasant. Pours out a rich amber color. Tastes strong, but smooth, with many little notes well-blended together. This beer sneaks up on you; Ive had many a beer similarly colored that had almost no taste; this one has plenty, and its all very rich. Dark fruits, maybe a little pine, tiny hints of yeast, oat. Feels soft as its tiny bubbles dance around the tongue and finishes with a pleasant prick of flavor. Amazing how it hits all the high notes and the flavor lasts, but in a pleasant way; you want the flavor to remain, and it does, softly, for several long minutes. Not too sweet, not too sour. A beautiful balance. This may be my favorite Tripel ever.

draft from hopleaf. thanks bwp116.  red copper color. feety and malty aroma.  there was another thing i smelled in it but i cant remember what it was. tastes weirdly of juniper and pine cones.  awful.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2009 Tap at Lucky Baldwins.  This tastes Like a Rochefort 9.  Yes I said nine on purpose.  Thick, raisiny, yeasty, syrupy, sweet, balanced, superb.  That this is a tripel is flooring.  Wow.

750-milliliter bottle. Pours a cloudy orange-amber with a generous, fluffy head. Aroma has that rotten garbage sweet smell that seems to be common of tripels and dubbels. Flavor is good with dark fruits and apricot and is only slightly bready. Alcohol burn is modest, on par with its 10% ABV. Good overall, but not a world-class performance in my opinion.

750 ml bottle. Clear orange colour, big off-white head. Fruity aroma, with apples, citrus and a whiff of alcohol. Caramel malts, plenty of fruits, a little yeast and a nicely warming, dry hoppy finish. The mouthfeel is medium-bodied and smooth.
Bottle.  Pours an orange amber body with a big off white creamy head.  Lots of fruit latent alcohol, citrus, apricots.  Finish is dry with a hint of wood.  Good brew.

This beer strikes with a welcoming candied smell.  It is not over the top, very subdued compared to other trippels.  Overly carbonated taste that almost has a oat like feel to it.  The spices last through out and this beer ends leaving the mouth feel wet.  Very delicious beer.

Pours out visibly viscous with a colour closest to filtered apple juice with a rocky white head that clings to the glass. In the aroma, notes of apple, pear, honey and aromatic malts. As it warms, farmhouse musk and caramel come through in the aroma as well. The booze is well masked in the nose as well, though not so much in the flavour. The flavour, aside from being characterized by floral, earthy hops, light fruits, some citrus, and light malt sweetness, is a bit medicinal in the warming, alcoholic finish. Nuances of toffee also form the finishing flavours. The palate is medium bodied,  prickly carbonated and dry.

11.2oz bottle. Pours opaque orange/red with a large white dissipating head. Fizzy and dry mouthfeel with nice initial fruit flavors and caramelized sugar at the end. Alcohol is well disguised. Good overall, but a little too sweet for my taste.

A bitter and somewhat medicinal Tripel that is good but not great.  This beer suffers from some stiff competition amongst its style.  Dusky gold liquid with a fine soapy head.  Sweet and fruity smell with a medicinal and bitter backbone.  No mistaking its Belgian origin.  Flavor is earthy with the alcohol hidden away in fruit and spice.  Orange toffee and yeast.  Velvety smooth on the palate.  Pairs very nicely with strong cheddar.
On tap. The high percentage gives this beer a lovely warming finish, but with out any harshness. A honeyed, brown sugar flavour and some herbal notes too. Very smooth palete. Nice.

Bottle. nice pop to the cork.  Poured an orange/amber with a really nice medium to large head.  Head was long lasting with good density.  Aroma of yeast apples alcohol spice and earth.  Flavor was very malty semisweet with a nice apple/fruit presence.  Lovely yeastiness.  Some great after taste. although the initial flavor was just good.  I really do like the style and thought that this one was at least above average to very good for the style.

Thanks to Redlight for the taste.  Flavors are sweet honey, vanilla and apples.  Pours a nice golden color with champagne-like carbonation.  Slight hoppy bitterness and some grassy notes finish this off.  A solid tripel.

330 ml bottle from an LCBO gift pack. best before march 2011.

pours deep clear golden with an everlasting white head that lingers and laces. 

aroma of alcohol, yeast, pale belgian malts, hops.

flavour. soft and sweet up front with the yeast aspects in the middle and a long bitter hoppy finish.

not a bad triple just not the best.

id buy it if it were availible in singles.

Was looking forward to this after reading about it in the ’protz’ book but it didn’t set the world on fire for me....in fact i didn’t finish it and i poured myself a stonecutter instead. I got  some vanilla in the nose and flavour to start with but then the alcohol kicked in and dominated.

Tasted 01/11/2008, 330ml bottle from Regionals.  Would make a nice dry, bitter tripel if it didn’t have such an overpowering aroma and flavour of alcohol. Like someone dropped some a little Jagermeister in an imperial version of Moa Original. Didn’t do it for me.

750 from Country Club Liquors! Nose of caramel, yeast, candi sugar, and clovey spiciness; cloudy copper with a big yellow-biege, glass-lacing head;flavor is caramel, light alcohol warmth, yeastiness, and light sweetness and contrasting bitterness.

330ml bottle gift pack from the LCBO
Aroma is a nice sweet smell
Pours a pale copper with an off white head plenty of lacing on the glass
Quite a nice beer but very strong alcohol taste
UPDATED: FEB 27, 2011 Bottle. Pours golden blond with a thick white head. Very strong nose, fruits, marzipan, malts & alcohol. Same aromas, full bodied and well balanced but a bit too alcoholic.

Pours a dark amber/orange, with off white head. Amazing sweet aromas of spice, fruit, clove and a hint of alcohol and malt. Flavour is full of bitter hops and citrusy, ending up like a grapefruit. Alcohol is quite strong in the flavour, which hides a lot of the flavour I think. Bitterness lingers for a while and alcohol leaves the mouth feeling fresh.

Style and Glass: Abbey Tripel; Trappist
ABV, Volume & Calories: 10 % in 25.4 fl oz. estimated at 400 C
Purchased at: Trenton Road Take Out, Bristol, PA for $6.99

Aroma: nice, spices, fruit, floral, alcohol. 9 out of 10.

Visuals: medium design, golden, clear to hazy, bright white head, sticky lace. 5 out of 5.

Taste: well balanced, high malt, medium high hops, high strength, high craft. 9 out of 10.

Palate: high quality, scratchy texture, long spicy finish. 4 out of 5.

Overall: A hoppy Belgian style. One of the most beautiful laces Ive seen. Well done, a repeat, not necessarily a favorite, medium value, medium high craft. 17 out of 20.

Pours a clear dark orange/amber with a medium frothy white creamy head.   Rich caramel aroma, hops are somewhat oxidized even though the bottle is pretty fresh, a bit spicy with some hay as well.   Rich toffee first taste, loads of caramel and sweet fruit, pretty one-dimensional,  touch of grassy hay.   Bitter alcohol aftertaste.   Medium/full body with lots of fluffy carbonation.
