Pours a medium dark cloudy golden/yellow with a white foamy head. Aromas of spices and fruit. Some of the spiced aromas come into the flavor with hints of fruit. Alcohol is noticeable. Semi sweet. Mouth feel is a little stringy. Pretty tasty and pleasing all around but the alcohol is almost dominant amongst other flavors.

750 ml bottles pours to orange/brown bottle with nice head that lasts and clings to the glass.  Smell fairly week for a tripel (but perhaps I have cold).  Taste is nice ,nothing special for a tripel, but enjpyable.  Hints of alcohol warm the belly.  Palate is nice bit it leaves a somewhat chalky mouthfeel afterwards. Slightly disappointing.

Poured a hazy orange/brown with a stable foamy off-white head.  Aroma was not too strong, but mainly of fruit and some Carmel.  Flavor was pretty unremarkable.  Some fruity notes with caramel and a hint of yeast.  Not as smooth or as much yeast flavor as other Belgians.  The alcohol is pretty well hidden however, so it is very drinkable.  Overall pretty good, but there are more flavorful tripels out there.

Bottle 33cl.
Pours an clear orange colour, very well carbonated, with a good size head, didn’t have the proper glass, but the same type so I imagine it won’t make much of a difference.
Can definetly recognize caramel in the scent, but also vaguely some fruits are in the mix, though very hard to detect.
Very strong flavour, with a bit too much alcohol to it. Nonetheless has a good flavour with yet again a dominance of caramel.
Pretty good abbey tripel, but could do with less alcohol flavour to it.
KSBF 08- Bottle- Hazy gold pour with foam off white head.  Earthy wheat, slight sweet and some clove spice mixed in.  Yeast body with a malt balance.  Dry crisp finish.

(Bottle).  Medium-sweet fruit aroma.  Clear light copper color, huge off-white foamy head.  Flavor is delicious fruits and herbs, medium carbonation, very light finish.   This is a powerful beer, but with the alcohol well disguised; caution required!
750 ml bottle.  Dark color with strong caramel smell.  Heavy malt flavor that finishes smooth.  Went great with a slice of pesto brie cheese.
From a bottle at the KSBF ’08. Hazy dark gold with a small head. Candy dominates but there is a nice maltiness and some light spice as well. Very good.
Had it off a tap. My taste buds went crazy upon consuming this one. Orange color with a strong taste of alcohol. Not for me but i would recommend it to some of my friends. (Had it at Chimes Bar)

330ml bottle, marked best before 11/2010. Slight gusher. Pours hazy amber with a large, fizzy, offwhite head, decent retention, good lace. Smells sweet malty and bready, spicy sweet. Tastes sweet and malty bready spicy. Lots of spice on the finish, a little pepper and some warming alcohol. Full body, fizzy carbonation that fades relatively quickly.
Orange amber color,  malty aroma , caramel, toffee with alcochol, spicy flavor and friuts a little bit strong the presence of alcohol.

Aroma is full on fruit, flavor is full on refreshing bitter hops. A winner! Starts off with a fruity nose with honey in there. Flavor is sweet that fades to bitter. Funny how much bottle conditioning helps! Smooth and you can’t taste a drop of the 10%.
Mild fruity and malty nose. Pale large head. Pale golden copperish colour. Peppery slightly sour taste. Nice maltiness. Alcohol well hidden. A 0.75L bottle (BBF 01/2011).
Dark blond pour with fluffy head and spotty lace. Alcoholic aroma. Thin bodied. Sweet malts and honey up front with a twist of citrus on the finish
Large thick head with amber color, aroma of herbs hop, highly carbonated, flavour is sweet and has some fruit notes, nice triple.
Quite light malty aroma. A little foggy orange-copper color and offwhite head. Sour fruity and malty flavor covers alcohol well. Smooth softly carbonated mouthfeel. Dry and warming aftertaste.

Marked as best before 1/2011.  Pours with a very large, and very thick, off-white head, covering a clear yellow body. Aroma is yeasty, with banas, ripe peaches, and some otheer fruits. Taste is alcohol evident, with a yeasty, the salty, then fruity movement. Small, sharp bubbles, with a water-like mouthfeel.

bottle, aroma  : vanilla, citrus.
cloudy orange with large offwhite head.

flavor: strong, powerfull, slightly alcoholic, tastes like more than 10%. spicy, bitterness from spices. sweet fruits (plums maybe), beer flavors opens up as it warms. should not be drunk in a hurry.

Bottle 33cl @ home.Clear medium orange amber color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, toffee, star-anis notes, light alcohol.Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long to average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholc. (040708)

Sweet, warm and alcoholic.  Spicy, fruity, yeasty.  Nice amount of carbonation without having a thin body.  This one was nice to drink and the 10% made finishing the bottle all the more fun.  Recommended.
330 ml bottle. orange colour. not to big a head, especially for a tripel. sweet citric, alcohol in taste.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a mostly clear dark god body with a one cm creamy off-white head, lots of carbonation.  Heavy pale malt nose with touches of yeast, alcohol, and fruity esters.  Rather thick doughy pale malt flavor up front followed by a very sweet alcohol and honey laced finish.  Notes of yeast, banana, and citrus fruits.  Mouthfeel is thick and viscous with lots of fizzy effervescent carbonation.  OK overall, but not among my favorites.  As it warmed the alcohol became more and more apparent.

750 ml bottle. Slightly cloudy amber color, expansive off-white head. Herbal hop aroma with sweet malts and alcohol. Noticeable alcohol flavor, with more herbal hops and a sweet malty finish. Slightly astringent mouthfeel, high carbonation. Mellows considerably as it warms. Not my favorite tripel, but not a bad beer by any standard.

A very good Abbey Tripel, pours a gold orange-like with a slightly small head which goes down quick until there’s a thin white head left, tastes slightly sweet and fruity, has a more pronounced taste of alcohol than maredsous 8 (not very strange, due to the alcohol percentage of 10), a little bitter, but the taste is a little more sour-like than the average Abbey Tripel. Clearly one of my favourites

This was new to Chimes last time I went. Since I liked the 8, I figured I’d like the 10. The taste of this beer is sweeter than the Maredsous 8, and the alcohol is more pronounced. It left my mouth a little sticky feeling. Not a bad beer, but at $8 a pint, I’ll stick the Maredsous 8.

On tap at the Maredsous abbey in a clay mug.
Pours amber with a thick creamy beige head.
Aroma is malty sweet sugary, taste is again candi sugar, floral light malt and hops, notes of dark fruits such as cherries, prunes , raisins, after taste is spicy and malty.
I found the tap version to be a lot better than the bottled one.
An excellent triple, well balanced.
Smells, and tastes like alcohol, a big beer trapped in a small bottle.  Decent triple.

33cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. It poured an amber golden colour with a medium white head that settles down fast in the glass and leaves a thin layer remaining on the top. The aroma smells of fruits, spices and alcohol. The flavour is bittersweet and tastes of spices, fruits and alcohol.
It has a short aftertaste.

Many bottles and taps, @ De Geuzen & Café Gollem. Amber-golden colour, nice thick creamy head. Aroma of fruits, alcohol, slightly sour. Taste is sharp, a bit sour, sweet, alcohol, spices and fruits. Creamy mouthfeel. A very robust triple. I must admit it’s not the most subtle example of the style (understatement of the year?) but still one of the best imo.

Hazy orange beer with a large fluffy white head, aroma is sweet, citrus and a slight anise finish. Flavour is strong (but i like it) with again citrus and a sweet alcoholic finish. Pherhaps not the best Tripel but still a good un !

Bottle. Creamy whiteexcellent mostly lasting head. Dark yellow colour. Powerfull hoppy and yeasty aroma, loads og fruity citrus notes. Powerfull bitter fruity flavor. Long nice powerfull finish. Creamy palate. Nice trippel.

Hazy orange colored beer. Although this beer is still good for a year, I think it already suffered from aging. 
A very alcoholic aroma with port and madeira. In the mouth also port and madeira with a lot of alcohol warmth.
bottle, copious head, almond color with malty  sweet nose,spicy mild flavors of caramel sugar, smooth even finish, nice beer
33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex brew, clear, rocky head, very good brew, the best of the Maredsous-range

On tap. Has a golden colour with a creamy white head. The aroma is sugar candy, Seville oranges and some herby belgian yeast. The flavour is sweet with notes of oranges and herby belgian yeast. You do feel the alcohol (maybe a bit too much).

big bottle 750ml.  Nice white head light amber color to the beer.  lots of flavor going on in this one.  just enough sweetness and the alcohol taste is very mellow but not too intense with this 10% brew.

Huge fizzy white head that mostly lasted. Good lacing. Clear sparkling golden color. Yeast, spice, coriander, citrus, caramel, liquorish. Full bodied with an average carbonation and a light alcoholic texture. Nice moderated sweet flavor with some bitter warming alcoholic bitterness. Sweet spicy finish.

Bottled 33cl. It pours a beer with a nicely lasting creamy head. Sweet taste. Malty with hints of almonds, hazelnuts, marshmallows, apples, banana, marzipan and apricots. Buttery. A bit boring. No punch to this beer. Musty. Sweet unpleasant yeasty finish with a hint of paprika. Dissapointing.

Pour is a dark red with a large tan head.  Aroma is very hoppy and fruit with a bready malt underneath.  Flavor is again more of the cirtrus fruit with some doughy malts.  Finish has some candi sugar with no noticeable alcohol.  A kind of different but tasty rep of the style.  Probably the hoppiest triple i have ever had.

6/29/08 From .33l bottle. Aroma is fruity and tart with very light peppery phenolics and no hops. Appearance is clear copper gold with a well maintained white head and some lacing. Flavor is sweet and citrusy with medium bittering and an interesting grain flavor that blends with a bit of its own texture. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a moderate carb texture and slight resiny feel.  Overall, an interesting brew that is light enough to be approachable even by those who cant stand Belgians.
orange coloured sparkling body with a hughes white head a spicy fruity hoppy aroma a spicy hoppy fruity taste with a malty bitter finish
Clear amber coloured beer with medium off white had and medium carbonation. Malty fruity aroma (chocolate). Full palate. Bitter and herby ending. Good one.

0,33 l bottle. Large creamy white head, which stays for a while. Golden appearance, sort of hazy liquid, infiltered? Nice fruity, hoppy aroma. The flavour is slightly fruity and hoppy, a lot of taste of alcohol, which disappears after a while - getting used to it, brings the flavours forward too. Very bitter finish. Nice beer.

Appearance: Dark golden. Loads of thick head. Loads of bubbles.
Aroma: Fruity, pears.
Taste: Fruity, pears. Strong. Hopsy. Malt in aftertaste.
Info: 330ml bottle, 16/3-2006, 90/300

75cl bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa, FL). Pours a translucent amber color with an off-white, thick, creamy one finger-plus head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma is very sweet with notes of malt, honey, caramel, bread, yeast, candy sugar, syrup. Flavor is caramel, honey, slight tangy fruit sweetness (like ripe dark fruit) with a very slight bitterness (nearly undetectable) on finish. Generally medium-bodied with good carbonation (but not too much). Well done tripel.

[Tap] Pours a clear gold with a decent sized whitish head. Aroma is pretty spicy, plenty of hops, and a little bit of yeast. Flavor is pretty rich, and matches the aroma. The mouthfeel is a little more thick and syrupy than I would have thought for the style.
Amber trippel with a thin white head. Sweet aroma. The taste- alcohol with some carbonation, with sugar and a little bitterness at the end. A decent Belgian trippel.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2013 Bottled. Cloudy amber beer. Medium, long-lasting white head is smooth and creamy. Aroma has dryish malts, notes of clove and pear, some caramel and a hint of sweetly herbal/floral hops. Dry, very refreshing flavor has peppery spiciness and moderately bitter finish. Alcohol is there but still quite well hidden in taste. Medium bodied, slightly sticky yeastiness, frothy  carbonation. A bit overcarbonated which is not a problem with proper glassware. Great tripel.

A clear amber coloed beer, with a great foamy white head. An aroma of malts, yeast, fruits and some spices. The alcohol is in the back. The taste is powerfull, fruity sweet in a way you usally not taste. It has some spice, with yeast in the back. A little cognac/brandy like. A very good beer.

Absoultely amazing beer.  Loved every sip of it.  High in alcohol but you could not tell on the palate or by the aroma.  Heavy bodied beer that fills your mouth with sweet fruits and spices.  Everyone needs to try this.
Amber trippel with a white head. Sweet alcohol aroma. The taste- average carbonation, filling mouthfeel with beautiful sugar and a hit of bitterness at the end. Definitely a good trippel.

Much better Tripels out there but I wasnt dissapointed with this one.  Aroma was mostly candy and alchohol.  Taste has a bit more to offer with some fruit and alchohol.  Flavor does lack the complexity found in many Abby ales.

A nice, if less than top tier tripel, this one pours a medium, golden copper color, with an almost white head.  Nose is lightly spicy, with yeasty notes.  Flavor is similar, with some fruitiness, as well.  Overall, its quite good, but lacks a little in depth to make it one of the best.

Bottle.  Lightly grassy, sweetly fruity, and angularly floral aroma.  Clear amber pour with a large soapy beige head.  Taste has hot alcohol, too hot, with overripe fruit and alky fumes.  Berries and fig with strong pale malts and a deft caress from the hops.  Dry and peppery, unbalanced ans sugary.  Medium body.  Dare I say it?  Too boozy for a tripel.

Nice cloudy amber in the glass with a big white head. The aroma is mostly fruity, with a some spice and alcohol presence as well. The flavor is slightly bready, with lots of citrus and spice, making for a full bodied yet refreshing brew. The mouthfeel is pretty full, and is balanced out nicely by the generous carbonation. Good beer.
A nice beer. Cloudy amber pour with a big white head. Lots of nice malty fruity flavor. A bit too carbonated for my taste but still a top notch drink
good tripel, with a nice head and a sweet flavor to it.  Full of malt and fruits in the aroma, nice body and head.  worth trying for sure and nice one for my night of tripels.
aroma is sweet and malty flavor is a lot like a spiced beer lots of citrus flavors and little to no hop flavor very goog

Pour is dark golden with a white fluffy head.  Aroma is of malt, citrus, and orange peel.  Flavor is alcoholic with a lot of citrus and light fruit.  Well blended.  Reminds me of Westmalle tripel.  Good brew.  Would buy again.

Pours a hazy copper/amber color with large light brown head with good lace retention.  Sweet roasted malt aromas with hints of dusy clove, earthy floral perfume, rum cake, caramel, and raisins.  Full bodied, almost chewy, with good carbonation.  Initial taste is a wonderfully complex malt sweetness with suggestions of figs and dark fruits, buttered cinamon toast, and yeasty dough.  The beer has a long, tappering finish that is very warming with lingering hints of sweet single malt scotch, burnt sugar, and bitter coffee.  A great digestive, try with rum cake or a rich brandied fruit cake or chocolate desert.
good aroma or a deep rich nature, good mildly hazy amber color, nice even head, flavor not as sharp as expected from a ABV 10, palate doesnt linger too long, overall not bad.

Aroma is sweet, fruity, including yeast traces. The head is beige to white, not very foamy and not much persistent. Amber color, low to medium haziness. On flavor, malt is dominant, with some traces of citric fruits, specially orange; presence of alcohol is very pleasant and discrete. Medium body, little to medium complexity and carbonatation. The bitterness is present and coherent. Finish is smooth, developing to something between smooth and dry, as more is drunk. The beer is fairly balanced, with some aftertaste of malt and alcohol. A good beer.

Gracias a la ultima alucinacion tuvimos la de 6 la de 8 y la de 10.  Todas frutosas y bastante buenas
Gracias

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2009 The pour is carbonated and a big fluffy head starts developing right away. Sort of a light brown color with some amber in it. The head is maintained leaving a lot of lacing. The aroma is floral with perfume but really rather mild. The feel is zesty and full with tangy fruity flavors, some yeast, a bit of spicy hops and some of that floral perfume or champagne. The 10% abv really doesnt show. Im not sure why I gave this one a pass when I was going through a Triple phase a little while ago. This beer is good!

A very easy drinking belgian especially considering the alcohol. Notes of sweet flowers come through in the aroma. Taste is of dank Belgian beer, sweet and easy on the palate. I enjoyed this one, you would too.

Pours a very appetizing transparent coppery amber. In a tulip glass, the head is quite large at first, but diminishes to a lesser size fairly quickly. Aroma is yeasty with notes of spice and fruity undertones. Sweet instantly balanced with noticeable bitterness that lingers on the palate for some time. Bright but not overbearing carbonation. Great for sipping.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2008 From bottle. Really nice appearance, darkish amber with a small head. Aroma of malt as well as some fruit and yeast. A bit of alcohol but not overwhelming. Lovely taste, moderately sweet with a slightly more bitter finish. Fairly carbonated. A nice, medium bodied albeit slightly dry beer. Some alcohol aftertaste, but the beer certainly works hard to mask the high ABV. Overall a very good beer and my introduction to Tripels.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2008 330ml Bottle, this is pretty easy to find in the UK. 

Pours a nice dark amber with a mini-head in pure white.  Medium  carbonation. 

Sweet tatse, quite spicy with a nice smell of hops.  I prefer this to the Maredsous 6 or 8.  Hides its strength quite well.
Copper colored and with a big hazy head.  Smell is yeasty, banana, fruity, and maple.  Taste is sweet, alcoholic, grape, rasians, bananas.   Pretty good.

I was fully satesfied with this.  Nice dark amber color with the fluffiest off white head!  Suprisingly smooth for the alcohol content , and finishes without any bitterness although a warm fuzzy sits in the belly.  Caramel, plum, and even a bit "o" honey set this one off.  Good Times

330ml bottle pours a sparkling coppery amber liquid with an energetic creamy head that springs up to the occasion. The mouth feel is rich and creamy but trails off with an astringent fruity melody rich with plums, caramel and malt. The powerful alcohol (10%) quickly smacks you but retreats leaving a warm glow and a parting sweetness and tartness that hearkens back to peaches and plums. A final echo of earthiness and toffe. A complex and flavorful brew worthy of savoring.

330ml Bottle. Slightly hazy amber colour with a small white head and decent carbonation. Honey, spice and grassy hop aroma. Sweet malt flavours with some caramel and more hops leading to a dry finish. Very good.

on tap in Pothuiske in Mestreech with m0rhi. Orange color with huuuuge fluffy slightly beige head and nice lacing. Aroma is full of caramell and some alcohol (10% is 10%). Flavour is also dominated by caramel with malts and some fruits. Very very nice one!
Cloudy yellow-brown with a medium tan head.  Sweet malty aroma of maple, toffee and fruit.  Tastes sweet and sugary with a very dry finish.
This smells like crisp freshly cut Delicious apples; wonderful. Looks nice. The flavor is also crisp and citrusy but lets a little bit of the alcohol through. Overall an excellent tripel.

Gold fizzy pour with a big, clingy white head.  Great lacing on the glass.  Aroma of wheat, a lot of spice, and some citrus.  Very sweet but with good drinkability.  Honey, and some citrus fruit, followed by some hops.  10% ABV is not even that noticeable.  Enjoyable.

750ml bottle. Caramel and maybe honey in the nose.  Hazy orange copper color.  First sips... This is pretty GD delicious.  Nice head that dissapes medium lacing spicy hops which seem a bit rusty.  One of the better trips out there, in a style that can sometime rub me the wrong way. 10% Uber.

33cL bottle from Wine Warehouse Charlottesville. Pours a slightly hazy dark amber with excellent retention and lacing. Weak aroma of honey and spice. Taste starts off sweet and goes somewhat bitter. Very effervescent. Subtle sourness that is not offputting. Nice.

A 750 ml. bottle. The color is a hazy gold with an off white head. The aroma and taste is of spicies and malt with a sweet honey taste also. The 10% alcohol to me is not that noticeble.For my taste I prefer no.8.

Gold/copper beer, with a fizzy body, and lasting, foamy head - moderately earthy aroma, with honey and wildflowers, a hint of grassy hop bitterness, fruit skins, and very mild wild/funk character far in the background - relatively high sweetness for a belgian-made tripel, but some spicy alcohol and herbs counter it nicely - full carbonation in the mouth - notes of melon, honey, citrus - some apple tartness and acidity - a very mild leathery/earthy character far in the back adds a depth of character - a full and complex tripel.

Bottle. Pours a deep hazy amber with thick off-white head with great retention that laces the glass. Aroma of malt with nice floral notes. Flavor is very malty with fruity notes and sweetness and alcohol spice with very slight bitter. Very good beer.

750 ml. bottle.  Bright, clear goldish color.  This had a super fruity smell.  Some bubblegum on the nose as well.  Flavor is very fruity.  Pretty nice but super strong.  Drank this with my neighbor along with a Decadence and we got pretty wrecked.  Glad I wasnt drinking these beers on my own or I probably would have been in bed.

pours a cloudy gold color with big fluffy head.  scent is of flowers and sour citrus.  flavor is kind of sour with tones of alcohol and wheat.  not a bad beer, but probably not one i would purchase again.

Pours hazy honey yellow gold with thick head that looks like cream colored egg whites. The head dissipates to a fair amount of lacing. Aroma is fairly light. Notes of honey and sweetened yeast, apple/cider. Flavor has this strange tart undertones. There are definite yeast notes and honeyed sweetness with flavor of granny smith apples definitely (i think that is the tartness i am sensing). Body is medium with a lot of carbonation. Okay but really not at the top for tripels.

resistance in fragrance. very subtle hesitation. When smelled while tasted, this beer has a marrying effect, perfect for each other. beautiful color when held up to a light. misty interior. head stays continuous when poured in crystal-ware. Very dry sweet after taste, pleasing and very light-hearted. aroma becomes more and more pleasing as the glass continues. and not just because its 10%.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2008 Pours a clear copper with a two-finger white head that fades pretty quickly. No real lacing.  Sweet, yeasty aroma.  Flavor is interesting, but never quite gels for me.  Theres sweetness, sourness, a high carbonation finish without ever quite coming together.  Dont get me wrong, its quite nice, I just think there are stronger tripels.

Pours a clear golden orange color with a nice big short lasting head.  Nose has a hint of a sour ale to it.  Palate cant quite seem to decide if it wants to be sweet or sour, but theres a lot of good play going on between the two.  For a 10% beer the alcohol is nicely masked.  Very good beer.

Nice dark golden color with a white fluffy head. Very pleasant taste of malt and sugars with a sweet, light aroma. A hint of sharpness at the end that lessens as the beer warms.  I liked it a lot and Ill drink it again.

Had this on tap last night at Brother Tuckers.  Really a delicious beer.  Poured a nice large head and a dark ameber color.  Very malty and you can tell you are drinking a strong beer.  Sweet taste.  Very nice.

Pours a deep amber-golden color with a thick fizzy white head that doesnt last for very long.  Some decent lacing though.  A rich thick caramel nose with some fruit character and alcohol.  A really deep malt flavor for a tripel... almost a woody flavor.  Lots of caramel, toffee, and alcohol.  Not really much fruit in the taste.  A little bit of bitterness left on the tongue, but most of it is a warming alcohol.  A nice thick body.

3/8/08 - Draft at Ginger Man in Dallas.  Pours hazy orange with thick, cloying, white head, rocky and delicious-looking in the Chimay glass.  Scents of pineapple, apple, pear, and maybe a bit sour.  Sweet and complex, fruity and dry, apple, pear, a touch of cherry.  Some bitter with a dry finish.  Very complex, lots going on.  Tasty, drinkable.  Good lacing and mouthfeel.

Pours A dark yellow with a nice white head.  An aroma of yeast, hint of citrus, and spices.  The taste was sweet but was lacking enough spices and ciitrus flavors to balance the alcohol after-taste. There are much better Triples to spend beer money on.

Keg (Wildeman, Amsterdam)
Deep orange, healthy head. Sweet and fruity aroma, spicy too. Full body, malty base and fleshy fruits, made more aromatic with the alcohol. Long fruity and noble hop finish. Alcohol definitely present but quite subtle as 10% goes.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 330 ml, bb 04 2010. Huge billowy cap on a hazy, burnt-orange body. Aroma is spicy yeast and honey. Flavor is dryish light fruit on the front, with honey in the aftertaste. Light-medium body is dry and slightly astringent.

33 cL bottle. Pours hazy dark orange with a huge light tan head. Aroma is overripe fruit, solid caramel malt and a light spice note. Fullbodied mouthfeel. Flavour is dense fruity, raisin and other dried fruit notes. Solid caramel malt flavour. Spiced. Towards light woody. Lingering fruity and sharp caramel malt flavour into the finish.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2016 33cl bottle, bought in NL.Generous, bubbly head. Beautiful clear, amber colour with lots of gas.Typical Belgian tripel smell; sweet, bready-yeasty with hints of banana, apple and spices... curry?Sweet-sour, well balanced flavour.Minty, bitter-sweet palate with a bitter aftertaste. Bit too alcoholic for my taste.This beer is best on draught, as it is a much better balanced beer then with no unpleasant bitterness and a relaxing homeliness.
Good, but no danger of being my new favorite. A bit thick on the tongue and too much fruity sweetness to be great. Nice oat and malt blend balancing again dark fruits, but not worth the price.
33cl bottle.   Pours copper color with nice head.   Malty, sweet flavor with alcohol finish.  Nice to drink but lacks the complexity of some others in this style.

Pours a golden color with off white head. Aromas of dough and caramel. Flavor is sweet and malty that finishes with hops. Alcohol comes through a bit much, gets worse as it warms. Medium body with prickly carbonation. There are much better tripels out there.

29/02 Draught at Hopdevil. Copper golden bodied with medium white head. Yeasty and sweetish malty nose, pretty alcoholic. Sweetish alcoholic flavor, not nasty in any way, pretty nice and drinkable, but still nothing special and way too simple. Some fruitiness, like apples and grape. Short finish, sweetish, alcohol is still felt. As Ive said, nice beer but nothing special, really cant understand those hight ratings, specially as I love the style.

75 cl. bottle...Poured a nice golden yeallow w/ some haze. Great mostly lasting, white foamy head...Smelled like a caramel apples, yeast, and florals. Taste was similar...caramel, apples, candy, mixed w/ a little alcohol bite towards the finish. Very sweet! Great beer...
750ml bottle. Pours nice, thick creamy long lasting white head. Gorgeous amber colour, pleasing aroma. Nice full bodied taste, pleasant finish.
Nice two finger head, strong flavor, maybe a little too sweet of an after-taste.

Pour from the bottle. Nice huge head and clear golden color with lots of carbonation. Nice nose of spice and a nice hint of hops lurking in the background. This tripel is sweet yet it is complex and hearty. A very nice beer from the bottle. I would love to try it on draft. chimay is one of the standards and this holds up to it nicely.

75 cl. bottle. Pours hazy orange with a big fairly well lasting off-white head. Aroma of yeast, fruit and alcohol. Good mouthfeel. The flavour is has a good sweetness with yeast, alcohol, spices, toasted malt and a good frutiness. The alcohol is rather dominating is the finish.
fruity, floral, and slightly herbal nose. Golden with a small head. Very fruity with a subtle carbonation. Well balanced and well masked. Very good example of the style
Aroma of fried bologna, medium body, I dont find much caramel, very light bodied for such high alcohol which it does hide well. Not bad, not too complex, but no obvious flaws. Kinda boring.

Wow what a good tripel. Maybe one of my favorites. Nose is fruity and sweet with a bit of floral notes. Pours a golden cloudy color with some haze and a bit of darker yellow almost brown swirals. Tastes great. Very caramel like, and sweet. Long warming finish with a bit of hops. I was very surprised by the great taste and the alcohol content is almost nothing. Wow.
On tap at Maxs.  Orange-red with a thick white head.  Sweet aroma with lots hops.  Nice sweet taste with spice and fruit tones.  Bitter finish.  I enjoyed it.

Poured from a corked 750 ml bottle into the Maredsous glass that came with the gift pack. It was an off-orange color with a full white head. Smell was of dried fruits. A nice sweet flavor, with orange coming to the front. A little alcohol burn, but not overwhelming.

Clear orange-copper with good, creay off-white head / Modest, sweet, candied grape and apricot nose / Medium, creamy, vinuous body with good finish / Unique, candied floral flavors of tropical fruit -bananas, pineapple, papaya, star fruit, etc., caramel, and honey / Almost a liqueur.  A beer I respect but not sure how much I like it.

Caged corked 750 ml. bottle, best before date (08 2009) on the lower stage left side of the label, sampled in a chalice. Sediment is visible in the bottom of the bottle.

L: Burnt orange, tarnished golden in color, clear appearance, stiff white head of creamy foam, good retention, fair amount of sticky lace rings the glass.

S: Bright floral and fruity bouquet, orange blossoms, pineapple, pears, bananas and peaches, that meshes with the alcohol, giving this a nice estery quality. Framing the edges is a wheat graininess, touch of herbs and earth spicy, nutty yeast.

F&T: The active carbonation gives this a quite lively feel in the mouth without being fizzy, firm moderate body with a springy creaminess. Delectable spicy tastes of pepper, earth, raw green nuts and sticky clove that complement the fruit flavors, orange, pineapple, green pears and apples. The alcohol provides a low grade warmth in the palate and has the flavor of spicy nuts. A tasty herbal spiciness comes out in the dry finish along with lingering tastes of husky wheat and yeast.

A quality, well crafted tripel, a pleasure to consume on this cold wintery night, both warming and satisfying.
Bottled at home. amber in colour. sweet and fruity but nothing more to add. I would give duvel a better rating
Hazy amber with large off white head. Aroma is sweet, fruity and yeasty. Sweet flavor with orange, yeast and spicy notes.

Bottle from Westholme Stores, Londis, Goring-on-Thames had this 23-01-08   Poured a clear golden colour with big frothy mallowy white head. Plenty of fruit and yeast on the nose along with some spices and pepperiness. Tasted sublime, spice and yeast once again making their mark as did the warming alcohol some honey also present but this was one to sip and savour that was until my dad got hold of it and hepled me finish it.
Dark golden - brown colour. Aroma is fresh and fruity and yeasty. Flavour is fruity and spicy. Alcohol well hidden. Very good beer.

Bottle coutesy of pepsican. Sour and spicey aroma along with some yeast and soap. Dark golden body with big white head and good lacing. Thin layer of head formed a manhole cover over top of body though out beer. Spicey and sour flavor with some toasted roasted grain in the mix. Good brew.
Very solid beer. Definitely could taste the sweetness talked about. Supposedly this is Michael Jacksons favorite beer. Wouldnt buy again for $10.99 for a 4pack
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Bottle 0.33 l. Darkish golden, staying thick white head. Fresh, a bit sour and vinous nose. Lot of yeast there too. Flavor has caramel, toffee, a bit of vinous alcohol which works beautifully. Somewhat sweet and sour. Nicely balanced overall with smooth carb.
A very good Belgian Abbey Triple with a nice golden brown hue and a frothy head.  Flavors of brown sugar and honey are noticeable.

Dark shade of gold poured from a bottle at Clock tower in the Sierras. Nice white head and fruity citrus aromas up front. Some good sweetness and spice were the flavors. Smooth on the palate and easy to drink. Good solid tripel.

The 75 cl. bottle pours an amber colored fluid with a foamy white, lingering head. Nice lacing on the glass. Has a very peppery, spicy orange peel smell. Slightly sweet, fruity, spicy, bready taste. Has a nice bite to the mouthfeel. Finishes dry with a strong hop alcohol bitterness. 

Definitely a triple worth visiting again
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Pours orange. Small short lasting head. Aroma of belgian yeast and spices. Some oranges and tangerines maybe. Flavor of more yeast and spice and light citrus notes. Some oranges and peaches maybe. It tastes nice and is easy to drink. A touch of alcohol in the finish, but it is rather light, but still flavorful. A spicy finish.
Nose of peach (ester), citrus and pepper. Fairly sweet but balanced by a pepperry/citrusy hoppiness. Creamy mouthfeel, not cloying. A well brewed tripel.
A really smooth, light yet full-bodied sweet Belgian. REALLY enjoyed the crap outta this one!! On tap at BURP CASTLE.
UPDATED: FEB 22, 2008 Dark gold in appearance. Thin white head with slight lacing. Sweet fruity almost spicy nose. Orange toffee taste and finishes with a nice warmth! Greeeeat beer!

Candy sugar, fennel, liquorice, amber malt aroma.  Gold with lingering, fluffy head.  Rich and creamy, amber malts, italian spices, slight white pepper, medicinal herbs, bitter hops and honey...a little grainy,  Not as sweet or citrusy as some triples which is fine.  Overall its quite tasty!

Bouteille de 750 (en embalage cadeau avec la 8 du même format et un verre), acheté à lSAQ sur boul des Laurentides (Laval). Dorée légèrement brumeuse, bon collet avec un peu de dentelle. Arome dépice sec, pain crouté frais et de siegle. Goût bien sucré, petite touche de siegle épicé et lalcool est peu présant. Partagé avec LadySusan.

bouteille brune de 750ml avec bouchon de liège

belle bière de couleur blonde blé-or passablement trouble. nez sucré agréable avec de épices, en bouche la bière est longue, marqué par les épices et très agréable. la sucrosité du produit se fait sentir.

Pours out a great head that has a solid lacing on it, the color is golden brown. 

Smell has caramal, burnt sugar, nutmeg, and a slight pepper.

Taste is very complex and hoppy. Flavors of caramal, pepper, nutmeg, and a little clove.

Mouthfeel is great, carbonation that rushes the mouth and refreshes the palate.

I would enjoy another one of these, but not right necessarily right away.
Its good. Very dark, malty, with strong alcohol taste, has a bitter hops aftertaste and also a fruity raspberry taste. Good head, nice lacing.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Stockholm) Pale amber colour with lasting, frothy, off-white head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of dried fruit, marzipan and fruitcake. Malty taste with dried and/or dark fruit, marzipan, fruitcake, dried papaya and mango. Fairly sweet, full bodied with chewy mouthfeel. Powerful and elegant beer with good balance. Very nice!

From a 330mL Bottle.  Somewhat hazy, golden honey colored pour with an enormous layer of fine bubbled, creamy ivory.  Aromas of pear brandy and freshly baked challah bread greet the nostrils immediately.  Doughy, yeasty, and a bit of a sugary glaze.  Fresh violet petals and a creamy banana.  Medium bodied, sizzling carbonation that creates an effervescent texture that lifts some of the sweetness off the palate.  Doughy, bready malt flavors up front, lightly spiced with some milky cardamom.  Some herbal hop character comes through mid-palate, bringing out a clean, drying bitterness.  Finishes fairly dry, but leaves a stinging alcohol warmth behind, tickling the palate.  Overall this beer demonstrates a nice balance between light malt flavors, hop bitterness, and yeasty spice, but the finish is a bit too hot.

This beer pours a cloudy yellow orange with a medium white head leaving some good lacing down the sides.  The aromas are oranges, sugar and yeast.  The flavors really mix well together to bring it to a wonderful flavor!  Somewhat dry but a little lively on the carbonation.  The finish lingers just long enough to enjoy!  I liked this brew.  Cheers!

Golden body with a foamy white head and excellent lacing.  Yeasty malty aroma with some bananas and cloves.  A sweet, almost sugary taste with some yeast and bananas, and a bit of bitterness near the finish.

(33cl bottle) Hazy, orange-golden colour with a big and persistent foamy white head. Sweet, bready and slightly toasted malt aroma with a present alcohol. Sweet, slightly sugary flavour, not too fat malty base, only medium body impression, well-carbonated mouthfeel; balanced malty sweetness, hoppy bitterness and some spicy notes in the moderately alcoholic finish. Nice, but not too spectacular.

Cloudy orange color, frothy white head that quickly dissipates. Sweet aroma of banana, cherries, yeast and dough. Flavor is initially somewhat dry and then the creamy sweetness comes through. Medium to full bodied, big carbonation. Very long finish.

750 ml bottle purchased at Jonathon Ron. Pours a slightly hazy honey orange with a fantasticlly large frothy pure white head. Lacing and head retention is nothing short of amazing with this gem. Big time aroma of yeast, fruity banana, candied sugar and sour dough bread. Medium bodied that has a nice creamy feel from the phenomenal head and a good amount of carbonation to balance it all out. Initial flavor is sweet, big honey flavor, that leads to tropical fruit followed by some breadiness. I must admitt this beer truely is a ten.

750ml - Poured a cloudy dark amber in color with a medium and foamy white head that settles to a thin coating over the bear.  Nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is the classic estery Belgian yeastiness with plenty of fruit... citrus and peaches... with the barest hint  of floral hops.  To me, the flavor is initially like drinking a carbonated peach-flavored beer... not unpleasant at all.  Sparkley carbonation in the mouth... surprising, considering how fast the head faded.  Some alcohol as it goes down, but no burn.  Plenty of Belgian malts and yeast.  Sweet finish.  I really enjoyed this beer.

Slighly murky orange pour with a soapy white head.  Strong, fruity, citrus aroma with some yeast and a bit of alcohol.  Nicely carbonated, full bodied.  This one is strong and tasty.  Lots of earthy flavors, some floral notes and a sweetness that is intense, but far from overpowering.  Esters and alcohol linger into the finish.  Warming aftertaste.  Great!
I find this to be my favorite beer at present.  It doesnt have the aftertaste I dislike in some other beers, yet has a great flavor, especially considering how strong it is.

750ml corked & caged bottle, 2006. Foam comes up, almost out of the bottle, as soon as the cork is popped loose. The beer has been in a wine fridge at 59 degrees F for a little over a year. The beer pours a deep, hazy gold with a thick white head that is somewhat short-lived, consists mostly of large bubbles (though not soapy), and leaves some lace on the glass (but not much). The aroma is sweet with a slight herbal quality - very malty and sugary smelling with a touch of honey, a light dose of grass, and some alcohol. The beer begins quite sweet and bubbly in the front of the mouth. The sweetness is grainy - and the graininess grows towards mid-palate. The alcohol also grows towards mid-palate. The flavor has some characteristic Belgian esters, but is for the most part clean and sweet with a light touch of grassy hops in the flavor and a balancing, herbal bitterness on the middle and back of the tongue. The mouthfeel is quite light and quite vigorously carbonated - quite spectacular, actually. Overall, a very nice tripel.
Dark gold color with small creamy off-white head. Aroma and flavor are very nice, malty, sweet and fruity. Great overall but nothing out of the ordinary.

Appearance: orange amber color. Great head, ivory color, some rocky and persistent.
Aroma: malty with fruity tones like ripe papayas, oranges and pears. Slight floral hoppy smells like chamomile. 
Flavor: very sweet start from malts and sugar. Fruitiness (similar at nose) like papayas, tangerines and peaches in syrup. Slight dryness in the end. Warming finish. Malty aftertaste.
Palate: medium body; light to medium carbonation.
Mediocre, sweetness unbalanced.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours a brownish golden with a medium but ading white head and citrus in the nose. Taste has citrus, caramel, spice and alcohol. A good hoppy ad spicey finish makes this a pretty good tripel. But not the best

33cl comprata da Squillari; versa color ambrato chiaro con schiuma abbondante ma non persistentissima. Aroma piacevolmente fruttato: pera (! retaggio della Duvel?), uva bianca - con una buona componente alcolica ma non pesantissima e anche un discreto sentore di luppolo. Sapore dominato dai toni piccanti dellalcool ma con una discreta complessità dietro ad essi e anche un poco di amaro nel finale, anche se subito sopraffatto da un retrogusto caramelloso e anche qui molta frutta dolce qualcosa che si avvicina molto a..... non ve lo dico. Decisamente meglio laroma. Corpo discreto ma frizzantezza troppo elevata. Discreta, meglio delle aspettative, ma un po moortgatiana. Speriamo che non sia questa la fine che farà La Chouffe (si era quella che pensavo prima) perché qualcosa in comune ce lhanno...

Cloudy gold color, suprisingly mild tan head.  Malty aroma, a flowery citrus smell mixed with various spices - your typical smelling tripel.  Fizzy mouthfeel, perhaps too fizy for true enjoyment.  Malt flavor with a spice and slight warm sensation certainly due to the 10% alcohol.  While this beer lacks a unique or defining characteristic it is still a remarkably easy to drink 10% alcohol brew.  That alone gives it high marks and is another testament to belgium brewing supremacy.
Pours a hazy copper with thin head.  Yeasty aroma.  Toasted malt and orange flavors.  Silky mouhfeel gives way to spice/bitter finish.

0.33L bottle. Small but firm head, hazy dark orange colour, rich malty aroma with some brown sugar and yeast. Taste is at first dominated by alcohol and carobonation is a bit too strong and noticable but as the beer warms sweetnes shines with notes of peach and some vanilla, although the alcohol is still present. Finished with a lingering long  sour finish.
Bottle 0,33ltr: Bought it with a stone chelk by the locoal Gall & Gall(Liquor store). Orange coloured heavy in alcohol but very easy drinkable.

750 Ml Bottle-Trade w/pepsican-golden color w/a moderate head & great lacing. Classic sweet Belgian aroma. Sweet Belgian flavor of bananas, cane sugar, honeydew, citrus, & spice. Had a lot of carbonation, very lively. Very smooth & easy to drink, alcohol was well hidden, doesnt taste like a 10% beer, but it hits you like it is!!! This was a very fresh, very enjoyable, easy drinking brew. Thanks for this one Andy!!

750ml bottle, hazy honey gold hue, with a fluffy white head, leaving laces, yeasty, fruity nose of stewed apples, peaches and grapefruits, with some honeyed pale malt notes,  a subtle coriander spicy accent, with a faint floral hop warmth aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate wih a yeasty, fruity, spritzy character, with some peach and citrus notes, with some sweet honeyed pale malts,  a hint vanilla, a mild flowery hop accent within a warmth mouthfeel, leading towards an honeyish warm, fruity, dry finish.

Bottle. Clear (or maybe slightly hazy) orange color with a medium, quite stable, white head. Aroma of yeast, fruits and spices and a bit of alcohol. Sweet flavor with yeast, some citrus, spices, and a bit of malt. Finishes dry with spicy hops. Lots of alcohol presence - a bit too much (the alcohol feel gets a bit less prominent as the beer warms up a bit). Medium-bodied with lots of carbonation. Not as rich as I would expect a 10% Tripel to be. Not one of the greatest Tripels out there.

Bottled 33cl @ Belgian Beer Cafe, Rio de Janeiro. A hazy amber beer with a good creamy head. Aroma is sweet, fruity and herbs. Taste very spicy and malty. Alcoholic but balanced. Dry and alcoholic end. Very good beer

Tap: very good beer, quite alcoholic but it does not make it less enjoyable. very rich, loads of caramel and spices, fruity - strawberris, pears and oranges, weak hoppy bitterness, i really liked  this one.

Pours a cloudy yellow color with a big creamy head. Great fruity aromas whaft off this wonderful brew. Flavor is of tropical fruits with a tantalizing high carbonated mouthfeel. Nice bitter finish.This brew reminded me of drinking a fine wine! Wonderful stuff!! Thanks Ubamartian for this brew!!

Lively garden fresh fruit basket aroma, amazing how a beer can smell this fresh,given its long journey to the stores shelf,taste is plum,pear ripe banana and other tropical fruits tantalize the tongue,your buds constantly re-energized by the high carbonation,all goes down with a slight bitter finish. Basically your classic triple thanks LT. Judge

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2010 Initial Rate: A strong, assertive beer but one with no outstanding features that might set it apart as an exceptional brew. Decent, though, and a good one to try. 8-3-7-3-14  Rich warm orange with thick luscious stable head. Served too cold @ Kaiba bar in Shanghai...Aroma is fruity with alcohol apparent. As it warms more esters emerge, lending undeniable cherry piquancy. Smooth easy gentle palate with alcohol drying the finish. Dry but fruity tripel. Flavors and aromas both have an interesting interplay of melons and vanilla bean.

From 11.2 oz bottle- poured transparent yellow/tan, big head formation.  Aroma of hops and light malt.  Hits the mouth with a dried fruit taste, very light body, mild alcohol finish.  Nothing to write home about...

Sampled @ GDBTF. Pours an unusually dark orange for a triple, nice small head; very fruity nose, with apples and distinct pear aromas; clean and sweet, with the floral hops felt more in aroma and flavor than in bitterness; warming alcohol, slight dryness in the finish.  Quite nice.

On tap, from old notes.  Pours a slighly hazy deep gold color with rocky white foam, great retention and lacing.  Little bit of pale malts in the aroma, some yeasty phenolics, maybe some hops, good bit of alcohol.  Flavor is has some notes of dried apricot with a fairly dry bitter finish. A solid triple.
Golden. Strong flavors. Another quality tripel from the lovely Belgium. Every now and then I remember Maredsous and enjoy.

A nice AT. My only complaint with the style is the excessive sweetness and this was no different. Pour was a nice dark gold with a huge puffy white head. Aroma of strong yeast and spices. Taste was very yeasty and sugary. Could pick up light fruitiness and heavy malts. Strong alcohol burn.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle, 33cl. Beer pours a nice golden yellow color. The head is white and dense. Somewhat fizzy. Fruity aroma, some coriander and little yeast. Flavor has notes of orange and other fruits. The alcohol sits on the tongue. Overall this is not a spectacular beer, but around average.

Bottled. Golden orange color, small fizzy head that settles quickly to light surface coating. Aroma of pear, orange peel, coriander and yeast. Nothing spectacular going on in the flavor, straightforward and simple. Light fruit notes, hints of citrus and a strong alcohol finish. Too much alcohol showing up in the finish, like cough syrup after it warms.

What can I say.  It was my first Abbey style and I fell in love. The pour is a beautiful dark red-orange, with a creamy head. The aroma is yeast and malt, with a slight hint of citrus.  The flavor is similar but brings with it a more delicate blend of all the flavors.  The finish is dry and mildly lingering.  A very good beer.

Orange to reddish brown color.  Nose is yeast, spicy, citrus and slight alcohol.  Flavor is much like the aroma with a small alcohol bite.  Dry finish with classic triple abbey characteristic.  A Good beer.
orange in color.  Spicy aroma with alcohol, malt and orange.  Malty to taste with a little yeastyness. Good.

The aroma is fruity with spice, yeast, and malt. The appearance is orange gold with a decent head. The flavor is like the aroma with a lot of alcohol. The palate is OK. Overall its good but not great.

2005 Vintage bottle via friend Michael.  Pours orange with an off white ring head.  Nose is crisp, with hints of candy sugar.  Taste is sweet and refreshing with the notes in the nose coming back through.

Dark orange, unclear with a marvolous rocky head. Sweet malty yeasty aroma, I think I detect the slightest hint of mollases. Full bodied. Very soft and refined fllavours, leaning towards sweet and fruity, pepper, orange and toffee are evident. The finish is of restrained hop dryness and warming alcohol.

Oct. 2005 - A pleasant surprise. Beer poured with nice head, typical trippel color. The aroma jumped from the glass. The taste was very rich and complex without being overdone...with even a little hop bitterness to finish. Mouthfeel may have been just a TOUCH too carbonated, but I cant really complain about anything in this beer. Very nice. This definitely belongs in any "trippel tasteoff".

pours a clear dark honey orange color with a nice two finger fluffy off white head. aroma is hops, yeast, and citrus fruit. has a medium body with good lacing and great carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma but just a bit stronger. has a little bite from the hops and carbonation and is a touch spicy. pretty good a very solid stepping stone for people who want to try triples. the 10% abv is very well hidden and the aroma is a little stronger as it warms.

750ml bottle.
best before:09/2009
murky dark golden beer with a nice sized, tight bubbly white head.
Sweet apples and pears aroma, touch of alcohol burn, brown demerara sugar.
Falvour, more of the apples and pears, and add some black plums, sweet, touch of malt,soft carbonation.
Very nice mouthfeel with the refermentation in the bottle. Soft,silky.
Overall nice beer, enjoyable and at a good price ($5.99).

Pours close to clear with a gold color that has an amber touch. Nose is like apple with alcohol. Flavor is not very pronounced I think. Slight malty presence with a minor bitter edge. I feel it lacks anything interesting or unique that makes it shine. Feel is standard for the course, though it is good....not knocking it there. But why would I want to drink a lot of these when there are other brews out there which are much more interesting for my tongue?
awesome belgium from the moortgat family. hazy golden beer that drinks smooth considering it has 10abv.
Big frothy head on top of a golden yellow pour.  Full malty body taste.  The great spice flavor is what sets this beer apart.  Hard to pick out the mixture but it hides the alcohol completely.
At a cellars tasting.  Bright yellow color with a sweet spicy aroma.  Smooth thick finish on this well spiced beer.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2008 Perfect blonde, slightly hazy, filling fluffy head that crested just over my trappist glass.  Aroma changed as I had to pour this in 2 stages.  First was a musty farmhouse, then burnt toffee, and finally deep yeast.  Delicate notes like Ive found in wheat based beers clashes with the sting of the high alcohol and an ongoing sour character with lemon notes.  Residual honey sweetness.

Date: 01/26/2005
Mode: Bottle Conditioned
Source: Tasting

dark yellow, big white head, light spicy aroma that grows as it goes, nice sweet malt flavor, slight alcohol esters fuming in the finish, 

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 2.7/5.0Score: *4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Pours dark amber. Very carbonated and has a thick foamy head. A very delicious beer. Sweet flavor, hints of banana and yeast. Slight bitterness in the finish. Fairly high in ABV so its not sessionable. One or two would do you good though.
Amber of color with a beige head. An aroma of spice, balanced sweety notes, no alcohol and sweet fruits. A flavor with sweets, some bitter notes and apples.

330ml bottle from Zinister.  Pour is clear golden orange with a large, rocky white head.  Aroma is Belgian spiciness, earthy and a faint fruit sweetness.  Taste is dried fruit sweet at the start, a bit earthy sweet in the middle and some heat to the finish.  This beer was fine, but nothing out of the ordinary.

Aroma of caramel, yeast and peaches. Golden amber color with a frothy white head. Tiny bubbles. Thin to medium bodied. Spritzy carbonation that turns creamy. Yeasty, mild spice, light stone fruits, and some hop. Finish is rather dry, and it is lightly bitter. Very tasty.
Golden body and a white head. It´s aromatic, hopy, grassy and flowery. Flavor brings pepper and yeast. The alcohol shines through to much.

Gylden klar øl.

Sød og varm duft af humle/belgisk gær. Begge dele tilpasset. Frisk blomster duft.

Frisk p.g.a tor tilpas mængde kulsyre.

Smag er sød og fyldig. varm blød eftersmag. Let gærsmag.

Eftersmag humlet.

Overraskende blødi smagen, gør denne øl suveræn
On draft at Flat Rock Saloon.  Poured gold with pretty golden lacing.  Fruity, floral aroma.  Smooth and hoppy.

I tried this beer on August 10, 2007 at the Biermarket in Toronto.  The beer was poured into a glass with a small white head that dissipated quickly.  The beer was a cloudy orange-brown colour.  The aroma was a strong yeasty aroma with some perfumy florals.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with a fair amount of carbonation.  The taste has hints of malt and bread with no bitterness whatsoever.

Bottle. Nose is mildly sour yeast with hints of peaches and sour apple. Golden orange with a thin white head which laces nicely, active but slow carbonation rises evenly. Spicy sour open, lots of carbonation, but smooth finish. Nice depth in palate, somewhat sour flavor with minor fruit notes.

Bottle. Poured hazy golden amber, with a huge white head. Aroma of yeast, spice, fruit,  and alcohol. Bready, yeasty flavor, with some hops, spice and white pepper. Alcohol more prominent as it warms. Dry, yeasty finish.

11.2oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange with a thick but fleeting head.  Aroma is earthy and malty with a faint but detectable sweetness.  Body is very full and smooth with a hoppy taste containing hints of caramel.  A delightfully robust tripel.

Dense flavor profile with strong notes of hazelnut, caramel, and wheat. Rather sweet for even a tripel. Not particularly effervescent and has a strong, lasting presence on the palate. Would be best suited as a dessert beer and paired along with something lighter and tangier like apples, nectarines, or currants.
golden with big chunks of yeast floating around. hoppy aroma. alcohol very clear in the aroma but pretty well hidden in the taste. caramel and sugar in it, perhaps a little overcarbonated.
Pours a golden color with a lacy white head.  Aroma is floral hops with yeast as well.  Taste is same with a noticeable alcohol aftertaste.  Not bad, but nothing overly special either.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2007 This is one of my favorite Belgian beers.  Pours a clear amber with a lacy head very smooth beer with noticeable alcohol feel.  Very fruity aroma that lends well to the flavor.  I would recommend this to everyone.
picked up a 4 pack of this the other day. i think i definitely got my moneys worth.  ill probably be drinking this again sometime.

750ml bottle, best before 10 2009.

Pours a mildly hazy, yet very bright coppery orange with frothy three fingers worth of head. The fowm settles very slowly to a thick cap, leaving behind a thick lacing.

Smell; some mild tropical fruits, yeast and a little alcohol. Pretty decent, but not quite as good, or as defined as I would have expected.

Taste; Very nice tropical fruits with pineapple, oranges and maybe a hint of banana. Sweet bready malts fill out the middle, and the finish is all peppery and alcohol spiciness.

Mouthfeel is full bodied and a little on the heavy side for what I like in my triples, and the drinkabiity is pretty darn good. Especially since the alcohol just seems to ride along with all of the other flavors instead of dominating them.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Bottle:  Clear yellow colour, with a nice creamy head.. Aroma of sournes,citrus,fruity,yeasty,malty,flowers and a nice tjekkian hopy nose. Flavor is almost the same, has also a alc-bitter medium finish. Medium body. A Nice compex belgian trippel.

I ranked this low only because of its incrfedibly sweet taste.  It was, as a friend likes to call it "Beer-pagne".  More like champagne than beer.  Not bad, but could have used more bitterness and less sugar.
Straw yellow pour with thick, white initial head. Malt upfront with good Belgian aromas. Taste is peachy fruits with clove and soft malts. Good spice on the finish.

Tap at Blind Tiger.  Golden beer with a thin white head.  There is a very fruity/spicy aroma, pale malt with a fruity and fairly earthy yeast.  Banana, clove and apple/peach.  There is a light Belgian malt flavour as well.  Spicy and fruity sweetness wiht a touch of pepper on the finish.  Its a fairly simple beer with a Leffe-ish quality to it.  Ok, but its a bit hot for my liking.
Bottle poured clear orange amber with plety of fluffy off white head. Sweet, yeasty aroma with alcohol notes. Slightly syrupy and sweet with alcohol warmth. Fairly complex. Delicious.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy pale orange body with nice head. Aroma is of spices, bubblegum. Flavor is a mild blend of spices, yeast, light citrus. Alcohol undetected.
Pours a dark shade of gold with a nice frothy white head. Aroma of sweet fruits and slight yeast. Complex taste mostly sweet, but nicely balanced.
Wonderful Belgian beer. Pours a nice amber color with a huge head. Lightly hoppy and some fruit noticeable. This is a really nice "high class" beer in my opinion. I loved it.

330 mL bottle.  Clear golden amber with a small fluffy white head.  Aroma is sweet and flowery with a hint of honey.  Thick sticky palate.  Taste of honey, nectar, and a sweet flowery finish.  The alcohol is nicely masked, but provides a little warmth in the throat.  Well balanced over all and quite good.

a nice dark gold appearance with a nice depth for a triple.  the taste is that of a classic belgian triple with some solid complexities and a very well balanced finish.  not the best triple i have had, but very good
Very musky, bready - very belgian.  Flavor is sharp, peppery.  Effervescent palate.  Overall, quite well-rounded and robust.

This beer impressed by being both a pretty tasty beer and fairly different from other tripels Ive had.  The beer is spicy (typical) but this spice is balanced by a citrus sweetness that I found very well balanced.  My notes also contain the phrase "the opposite of mellow," which I remember thinking as praise masked as criticism.  Combine this with the fine carbonation and smooth mouthfeel that secondary fermentation can provide, and you have yourself a winner.

This beer poured a dark straw color with a very white head.  Aroma was a lot of clove combined with some zesty citrus notes.  Taste was very clovey with a touch of sour.  The remark in my notes "the opposite of mellow" remind me that I thought this beer was "big" but also had potential for those who age beers to become something more complex in time.

A nice beer, and definitely recommended.

Rated 3/11/07:  A truly authentic Belgain Tripel that awakens the senses. Wonderful beer, a remarkable example of a delicate style. Best pour Ive seen of a Tripel. Slowly down the glass a billowing white head formed easily 2" in thickness. Vibrant orange color that sparkles through a hazy body. Splotchy lacing, the creamy head ultimately settles to a finger thick. Soft aroma of Belgian yeast, malts, and spices. Musty with some light earthiness, there is a really faint alcohol presence really surprising how hidden the abv is in this one. I detect a mix of flowers and mild fruit, banana and clove primarily but there is more to it. Peppery with some sweet candy sugars. Nicely made and more complex than some of the other great Tripels Ive sampled so far, this one is top notch.

Bottle. golden/amber colour with good white foamy head. Light aroma of malt with undertones of light hops. Flavor is of light spicy hops with just a hint of alcohol. Nice amount of carbonation with medium to full body. Lovely beer.

Warm amber with a nice head, that leaves islands of foam on the surface. The aroma is light and fruity and the mouthfeel is round and smooth. The flavour is sweetish and hides the 10% ABV well. It has notes of malt, fruit (apple, orange and plum), walnut, spice and a hint of alcohol. It has a nice citrussy finish. Its a nicely balanced tripel, one of the better ones...
Rich amber pour wih deep creamy head. Lovely lacing. Spicy, a little sweet iwth a medicinal flavor at the finish. Nice, but not my favorite.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2007 Pours to a deep amber with a lot of carbonation, creating a thick off-white head that lingers well and leaves good lacing. Initial aroma is floral and dark fruit, with alcohol well hidden. The mouthfeel is tingly from the carbonation, and as the beer warms, it becomes more influenced by the 10% alcohol. Likewise with the flavor, which is a pleasant fruit flavor thru mid-glass, but becomes more dominated by the alcohol toward the end, as does the finish, which also beecomes increasingly sweet at beers end.

This was not a bad beer at all, but I would have rated even higher had I stopped at mid-glass, before the alcohol and syrupy sweetness dominated the end.

attractive beer with excellent carbonation and head. Slightly too much alcohol compared with the flavor, which is typical belgian ale. Some nice creaminess to the palate and a sweetness rounds out the beer very well.

Pours a translucent dark amber. Big head with lots of lacing. Aroma of cedar, fruit, and malt. Taste of alcohol overpowers some of the other flavors, which are of cherry and fruit. The aftertaste fades into almost a  cough syrup like flavor. There are Belgians out there that are a lot more balanced. More of the unpleasant undertones come out as the beer warms, but there are many worse beers.

Tap - in Maredsous glass.  Above avg, off-white, fizzy head into clear light ambered hued body.  Alcohol, light spiciness,  light fruit (mostly cherries), light vinous, yeast are all present in  the aroma.  Strong sour notes in the flavor but finishes suprisingly on the sweet side.   Some alcohol warming was noted.  Good Tripeo.

Huge fizzy white head that mostly lasted. Good lacing. Clear sparkling golden color. Yeast, spice, coriander, citrus, caramel, liquorish. Full bodied with an average carbonation and a light alcoholic texture. Nice moderated sweet flavor with some bitter warming alcoholic bitterness. Sweet spicy finish.

Utterly boring is the last note at the bottom of my page of scribble, I found this as monotone as a single drum-kick recurring for hours on end, frustratingly lacking something to give it life. Into a chalice at around room temperature. Head, as expected does its rise on the pour, a big, dense messy off-white mass that further expands, holds well and laces wildly. The beer a very hazy, almost muddy, tawny amber  with minute bubbles streaming endlessly. Aroma, so feint I thought I must have a head Cold. What I did get was chemical, medicinal alcohol with some fairy-floss sugary goodness. Big frothy, come smooth palate like a chocolate mousse. Toffee and caramel, and undeniable butterscotch gamminess on the palate, sweet but controlled only by unnecessarily higher alcohols that feast off the palate in back and into the yeasty, bready, gluggy, oily swallow. It becomes, amongst its diacetyl and fusel ridden palate, quite doughy, and altogether bothersome, awkward on the palate. I didnt like this one at all, obviously, but a back-up came as the wife tasted it saying it was "like yeasty bread dipped in Vodka". A re-rate might come, but Im sure the sample I tasted was in true form. Ahhhem!!! (33cL, BBE 03/09, Intl Beer Shop, W. Leederville)
ACBeerfest-750ml bottle-pours a light tan head and yellow/gold color.  Aroma is sweet, yeast.  Taste is sweet medium malt, yeast, perfumy, spices.  OK carbonation.  Occasional.
Bottle. Best before 2003. Pours a hazy orange color with almost no head. Malty yeasty spicy aroma. Sweet malty warming spicy flavor with hints of yeast. Sweet fruity warming finish.
Full and fruity nose.  A deep golden color with an off white head.  Initial taste is sweet, with a spice taste coming through early on and a taste of alcohol.  Medium bodied, nice finish.

Medium offwhite head. Deep orange body with lots of carbonation. Deep tropical fruit and caramel aroma with notes of spice, bread, and soft metal with a kind of medicinal, tobacco-like background. Deep, spicy taste of that medicinal, tobacco-like thing with strong fruity notes. Powerful, chewy mouthfeel. Some alcohol heat. Dry, spicy aftertaste. Very nice. (0.33l bottle.)

Pours a clear, brilliant sparkling golden color. Head is big, white and frothy with good retention. It leaves a nice and stable film.
Aroma is yeasty/fruity with subtle maltiness and hoppy traces. Notes of raspberries, apricots, apples and oranges in the surface. Whats weird is a hint of fussels, burnt plastic and loads of medicinal/alcoholic presence too.
Flavor is sweet with a huge alcoholic presence. Almost a spirit. Notes of fruits, cherry, liquor, muscat, medicine and oranges. Overpowering alcohol....this is too much.
Medium body, medium to low carbonation. Oily texture. Long alcoholic finish. Sweet aftertaste. Too much alcohol and that burnt alcoholic presence. I didnt enjoy this. Maybe I had a bad bottle.

In the 750 mL bottle from Beertopia. Pours dark clear gold with a large thick white head.  Dominant bubble gum aroma immediately strikes you in this one. Slightly medicine-like. Flavor is sweet, but not so rock candy sweet that you are distracted by it. I found this odd in that there was no alcohol in the nose or the mouth, but boy do you get a serious belly burn once it gets inside of you. Overall, not magnificent, but a fairly good tripel for under $8 a bomber.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2015 The first time I ever saw the Maredsous 10 was at a famous tap house in downtown Denver.  Everything on the wall seemed kind of average, kind of droll, and kind of unexceptional, except the Maredsous.  Right when I was about to raise and a hand a get a pint of this tasty tripel, my friend interjected and announced the glory of a different beer; it turned out to be a bland IPA, but what was worse I had missed an opportunity to sample a fancy sounding beer from the tap.  The second visit to the same tap house was another failed opportunity, foiled by temptation of a short-lived keg of beer that had arrived a few days earlier.  When I finally got my clutches on a bottle of the Maredsous I was relieved to, at last, sample a beer that had consistently evaded me.  My efforts, Ive found, were not in vain.  The Maredsous poured thickly, forming a profoundly dense head, and clarifying to compose a body color reminiscent of a rotting orange peel  somewhere between brown and orange.  However, the smell was far more appealing and satisfying, much like pronouncing this beers elegant name.  Wheat and coriander portray the Maredsous as a doppelganger of a wheat beer, and the ticklish tinge of lemon and lime confirm it.  The smell of sautéed chicken breast, something Ive never detected in a beer before, dispels the illusion and puts the Maredsous in its rightful place as a tripel.  If a drinker is still confused as to whether the Maredsous leans towards wheat or tripel, a taste settles the matter, washing the tongue with a combination of hops and wheat, brilliantly balanced against each other but composing a full flavorful taste of grain.  Caramel and honey join the mixture, giving their sugary blessings before the flavor profile turns dry and savory again.  The aftertaste is an elegiac conclusion, throttling the esophagus with a dwindling alcohol burn in a sort of last gasp of regret.  The Maredsous 10 runs the gamut of sweet and savory, assertive enough for some hearty starch based meals like thick-red pasta dishes or even pork, and may very well be an excellent ingredient in cooking.  A braise or marinade comes to mind most especially, but wherever it is applied the Maredsous will wow with its flexibility in flavors, prancing all over the tongue and entertaining all audiences.

Two finger white head, characteristic cloudy golden tripel.  Fine lacing.  Oh yes, lots of carbonation. Aroma of vanilla, tangerine and banana.  Spicy and buttery, with a musty yeast flavor.  I detect dry hops. Velvety mouth feel.   Quite a good tripel that is high in ABV but not as noticeable in the taste as one might think.  Spicy long warm mouthwatering lemon finish.  This is an outstanding tripel.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 bottle @ the dove, farringdon. Perfect amber colour with a thick cream head. Aroma of orange, vanilla, yeast and spice. Taste to match with a strong taste of alcohol. Though the alcohol is noticeable, its not overbearing. Finish of creamy orange. Dreamy soft mouthfeel. Like buttah! Very, very good.
Poured from 750ml bottle into beer goblet.  Deep amber color with nice head.  Great aromas with a very drinkable taste.  Well brewed belgian ale.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2008 Bottle, served in big brandy-glass. It´s strong, but the alcohol is well hidden. Very balanced. Triple is not really my thing, but this one is great. 8-4-8-4-17=4,1.
Re-rate: Amber color, nice off-white head. Aroma is fruity and spicy. Flavor is fruity, sweet malty, alcohol, spices. Balanced and very nice. And I like tripels now!
Very pleasant aroma, coppery orange color, you do not notice the alcohol due to the taste of the beer which isnt bad but a little rough.

Poured from 11.2 oz bottle into a Trappist glass.  Deep gold color with one finger white head.  Belgian lacing present.  Does not taste of alcohol despite high alcohol content.  Medium body.  Fruity aroma.  Low spicy hop character.  Mediume bitterness.   A very nice tripel.

Draft. Sweet and fruity, this left an earthy, yeasty aftertaste. Clear, golden pour. The nose presents peach, apple and plum. The flavor starts sweet and turns tart and bitter. Dry finish along with a slight musty aftertaste. Warming alcohol. Nice mouthfeel with its moderate carbonation.

A dark tangerine hue, with creamy off white head, excellent lacing, has an overriding alcohol smell strangely enough like mixed fruit snacks which dont actually contain much real fruit, initially sweet with some spice and taste but kills you with a long harsh bitter aftertaste, like sucking on a lemon but the lemon is alcohol and youre not too in to sour things.  Wanted to like it more that I did.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2007 This Beer is really spicy. The malts and minor hops aroma play almost the secondary taste while the appearent spice is front and center. The palate is thick while the head lingers on. Very Dry too.

(Bottle) Pours a light amber color with a white foamy head. Aroma of sweet malt. Taste is much more earthy than I expected, with notes of dark fruits and a touch of spice. Seemed a little over-carbonated. Not a bad brew, but flavor-wise a little more harsh than I expected.

Draft at Flanagans Old Ale House: Sparkling clear, golden pour.  Rocky head leaves extensive lacing in its wake.  Sweet peach and apple esthers dominate the nose.  The body is creamy, with a nicely carbonation that expands on the tongue.  Honeyed malts, fresh dough and fruity apple cider notes in the body.  Long, drying champagne-like finish.  Very refreshing.
Golden color with strong head.  Aroma of apple, yeast.  Sweet flavor of apple, some grape, malt, brown sugar.  Cloying sugary finish.

[Sampled in Skåne at the canoe-tasting, 2005.]

A strong triple, but very challenging with the usual triplenotes of sugar, grapes, alcohol, spices, malt and with a heavy sticky finish. Quite good, but not my style!

Pours dark orange / bronze with a cascade of carbonation and a large dense off-white head.  The aroma has candi sugar, grapes, nectarines and thick earthiness - very thick and rich.  Medium body thats thinner than expected and fairly sharp with lots of carbonation.  The taste starts with toffee / caramel malt, some medicinal characteristics and brown sugar with sharp flavors.  The finish is quite sharp and sour.  This is okay, but far from being a great tripel.

330 ml botte (in Senegal, looking a little bit beat up...)  Grape, apple, aroma.  Color of fresh apple cider, cloudy orange with traces of brown.  The flavor was fruity again with the apples.  The mouthfeel was somewhat sticky and heavy, the aftertaste cloying sweet.  I enjoyed this, but if it was any warmer here this would have been far too heavy.  Probably something better for a cold winters night.

This beer is a hazy yellow-amber with a big frothy head that leaves excellent lacing.  The aroma is of cookies, toffee, and banana chips.  The yeast provides a sour, musty scent.  The flavor is banana-bubblegum, clove, soy sauce and wood.  It has a full, creamy feel that tapers off to a dry dusty aftertaste.  It is moderately bitter and acidic and lightly sweet.  A good tripel.

330ml.  Pours a translucent, light golden with a large, cobwebbed white head.  Aroma is beery, yeasty, tripel-like.  Taste is normal at first then a sharp stab of alcohol kicks in.  Very boozy tripel.  They overdid it with the alcohol.
A good tripel, quite tasty. Sweetish finish, though it is well attenuated. A bit of alcohol comes through. Good fruity, belgian character.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2015 Golden orange,belgium hop hint of banana, strong and juicy , complex with a liitle spice, good but there are butter 10%ers 2.7

 golden amber ... thin white lacing ... soft sweet fruit ... soft rich bready yeast nose ... soft fruits ... soft candi suger .. soft yeast ... soft fruit ... 3.6

330 ml bottle. Deep golden amber colour. Tall off-white head as is typical of the style. Head clings to the glass as it falls down. Crystal clear. Apricoty malty aroma. Quite clean. Some residual sugars and a little caramel. Nice hop bitterness cuts through the malt sweetness and the alcohol.  High carbonation level and bitterness leaves a dry sensation on the tongue. Long lasting funky yeast flavours. Nice tripel.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2008 This beer pours a murky amber color with a thick, creamy head.  The head stuck around the whole time I was drinking the beer.  The smell was of alcohol, spices and some good old malty sweetness.  This is a very smooth beer and went down so easy.  I tasted citrus, rasins, malt, alcohol, spices and some sweetness.  The mouthfeel is tremendous...really sticks around quite a while.  This is quite a Belgian beer.  I am a big fan of this style, and it didnt disappoint.  This beer sat around in my basement awhile...I could always find another beer that was higher rated to try in its place.  After trying this beer for the first time, I am not only going to store another two or three of these in the basement for a while, I am going to try the eight as well.  Solid effort and one of my favorites.

.33cl bottle.   Served in a tulip.  Ive been looking forward to tasting this one.  Pours golden amber with a big creamy off-white head and lots of lacing.   Aroma is musty spice and alcohol.  Flavor hits the spot instantly.  Smooth semi-sweet triple, spicy, and an excellent alcohol bite well buried in it. Perfect hop bitterness finishes it off.   Did I mention I love triples?  This one is tasty, well crafted by Moortgat.  Almost too easy drinking for a 10%  beer.  Yum!

Bottle, 33 cl. Deep clear golden, medium to large flyffy white head with good retention. Fruity malt aroma with yeasty, earthy and spicy touch, and some floral hops. Medium bodied. Some sweetness bot a very dry finish.
Pours a nice amber colour. With a medium white head. Aroma of Cloves, Honey and slight citrus. A sweet malt taste, citrus, and hops. Boozey taste of the 10% is a nice touch.
Bottle, 33cl. Clear amber colour with a large off-white head. Aroma of apricot, peach & raisins. Alcoholic flavour , a bit spicy. Didnt like it that much...

This is a beautiful coppery brew with a foamy white head that dissipates quickly.  The mouthfeel is almost like that of a smooth milk chocolate.  I like this beer, and ercommend it to anyone who may be on the fence about trying it.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: Pours a rich golden color with a thick foamy white head. Aroma of fruit. Taste has an alcohol presents with a touch of soice and citrus, flavor is a little off.

follow up to the 10. Couldnt help but feel it was a bit darker Duvel. Still superb, not as brassingly balanced as duvel, and a bit sweeter, but man, it really did hit the spot. Drink a Duvel and that will answer any questions u have.

Poured a nice golden-yellow hue with a pure white head which had great retention/lacing.  Aroma was a fruity bouquet of bananas and subtle bubble gum notes.  Flavor seemed mild, some fruit notes but not much else.  A creamy delicate finish helped this beer a little.  Alcohol seemed hidden and spice notes associated with this style were missing.  Carbonation was minimal but the beer did have body to it.  Overall the beer was good, could have been great with a little more to the flavor.
02/2009 330ml - Copper colored liquid under light tan head of small bubbles.  Nice lacing.  Rasins and candy on nose.  Wood, malt and sweetness on palate with a strong, astringent finish.  Nice.
poured clear copper with a large frothy cream head and much visible carbonation.  floral and citris on the aroma, clove and fruit on the taste, dry palate.  enjoyable belgian.
