too much booze, not enough hopsand spice.  A recipe for a malt liquor problem, not a benadictin brew.  
But, I am sure by the time the 750 mL is done, ill be messed up.

Dark cloudy copper with a large & long-lasting head, lots of lacing. Aroma of musky hops, honey, bready yeast, cloves and some unpleasant soapyness. Taste starts out with an awkward combination of citric hoppiness and honey-like sweetness, and finishes drier with more musky hoppiness and spice. Medium/high carbonation. Decent.

Full-bodied. Good cream. Muddy amber coloration. Citric, fruity and lightly floral. Notes of clove, ginger, caramel and, perhaps, cinnamon. Medium perceivable alcohol. Well balanced: the bitter taste does not appear. Average carbonation(perfect).
Very nice.  Wonderful ripe pear/yeasty aroma.  Huge rocky head on top of a golden body.  Excellent spicey (black pepper) fruity (ripe pear) flavor.  Dry and strangely refreshing.  One of my favorite.
Light malt and yeast make up the aroma.Pours a light murky copper with a slight off white head.Slight sourness followed by some yeast in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with some yeast in the finish.
A true tripel. Very nice taste and pours with a rich head. The mouthfeel is superb and your tastebuds definitely enjoy the handcrafted beer. One of the best abbey beers around.

Drank in the Maredsous glass.  Poors a nice cloudy blond poor with a beige off-white frothy head.  Aromas of apples, peaches, allspice, bananas and caramel.  Lightly carbonated, caramel sweetened... you can taste the alcohol right off the bat but you cant feel its 10%... Long lasting fruity aftertaste...

Pours amber with a fizzy white head that persists.  Smells of old Champagne, earthy hops, yeasty and some mellow fruity hints.  Taste is hoppy with some decent malty sweet tinges.  Not as fruity as the others I tried alongside this one.  More crisp and closer to what Ive come to like in a tripel.  Palate is tingly and peppery with a nice dry finish.  Some floral hints pop in and out from time to time.  Hard to believe this ones 10% ABV given how well the alcohol was masked on the nose and palate.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2007 Bottle. Full-bodied. Good cream. Muddy amber coloration. Citric, fruity and lightly floral. Notes of clove, ginger, caramel and, maybe, cinnamon. A little perceivable alcohol. Well balanced: the bitter taste does not appear. Average carbonation (perfect).

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2011 Deafeningly fizzing golden trumpet. Sniffs of sesame and damp canvass. White suds pillowing skyward. Perilous honeyed nuttiness, licks of copper, hot velvet. Unsubtly spiritous and too much like a turbo-charged version of the 6.

750ml bottle. Pours a clear dark golden with a huge white head that lasts forever and leaves good lacing. Aroma of sweet malt and citrus whith a gentle hop bouquet. This beer has very high carbonation that tickles the tongue. Taste is citrusy and slightly metalic with an after taste  of sweet malt. Good bitterness with just a touch of alcohol warmth at the end. Overall a good triple.

Pours clear golden with a large white head. Settles into the glass leaving some nice lacing. Plain, sweet and slightly metallic aroma, with some light apricot esters too. Carbonation is prickly, with a thin alcoholic feel to it. Flavours of caramel, metal and some rough stonefruit esters.  The finish is light but warming. Nothing special at all.
Clean taste ... Long lasting white head...typical triple nose...nice biter finish.  Its not my favorite triple but Ill buy it again if Im lucky.

I will say that this one started off nicely. But I did notice that as I went on it turned somewhat bland which shocked me greatly.  I would definitely drink it again, possibly on a frequent basis mainly as the high alcohol content is always attractive.

Well, this #300 went in and out with a whimper.  Started out more promising than it ended, anyway.  Again, interchangeable with any number of other second-tier Tripels.  Get it, rate it to pad your totals, and move on.  I feel like the teacher in Ralphies daydream in A Christmas Story before coming upon his paper.  Each new middle-of-the-pack beer seems less impressive than the one before it.  Dammit, I want that A++++++++++++++++ beer!
you know:
++++++++++++++++
(clappety clappety clap)
++++++++++++

Where is it?
Much better than the 8. Smooother, less carbonated, higher alcohol. Sweeter, still very very drinkable.

750 ml Bottle. Tulip Glass.  A hazy orange amber hue.  Nice head, but dissipates relatively quickly.  Sweet orange-peach taste.  Slightly spicy/peppery to the nose and palate.   Typical body for a Triple.  And with a sharp bitter/spicy-alcohol finish.
UPDATED: OCT 24, 2008 Bright floral and citrusy aromas with a bit of apricot and an orange-gold appearance.  Taste is yeasty and citrusy with alcohol presence.  really really tasty!

33cl bottle.  Poured cloudy amber/orange with a thick frothy white head.  Left sheets of lacing.  Seemed to take on more of a bright orange glow as it warmed.  Aroma of banana Belgian yeast, bread/cookie malts, spices and alcohol.  Spicy-sweet malt flavor with banana, citrus and apple.  Finishes a bit musty with some trailing spiciness.  Medium to full bodied with lively carbonation.  No real complaints here.

Slight hazy, dark orange/golden body. Lasting big dense white head. Fruity-sweet aroma with scents of alcohol and spices. Sweet and slight acidic flavors. Distinct hopbitterness.
Dominating alcohol heath in the aftertaste. Big body, vineous mouthfeel. A powerful tripel.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2009 From Johns Liquor in Eureka, CA.  Poured cloudy dull orange into my new Duvel glass with big foamy head that settled faiirly swiiftly leaving big chunks of lacing.  Powerfull nose of yeast, flowers, and alcohol.  Mouthfeel is fizzy kind of like champagne, and taste is banana with some sweetness.  Finish  shows high alcohol content . Very nice Abbey Tripel

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2007 Poured from a 330 ml bottle into a snifter, golden with a 3/4 inch white head. Taste of citrus, yeast, spice and alcohol. A nice combination and well balanced. Overall a nice triple.
nice golden ale with mild sweetness, and a whallop of alcohol subtley underlying. almost creamy feel with nots of fruit in nose and taste.
Fizzy orange with about an inch head.  Flavor has a bit of raisin or prune in it.  Creamy mouthfeel with a strong alcohol kick at the end.

Pours hazy medium orange with a rocky white head.  Aroma is maltu of cookies and lightly hoppy of flowers and moderatly yeasty of leather and earth.  Flavor starts well balanced of prunes and candi sugar, finishes more sweet which covers the alcohol nicely.  Average clean finish.  Medium bodied, oily and creamy, livley and light alcohol in the end.
yeasty, citrus aroma and flavor with nice alcohol touch.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2007 Pours a hazy golden orange with a nice white head.  Aroma is citrusy, malts, some yeast and alcohol.  Flavor is caramel, some banana, malt, and some fruit.  Finishes with a nice alcohol warmth.  Very tasty.
Bottle.  Nice clearish orange yellow color, off white head that lasts and lasts.  Aroma of sweet yeast, taste is sweet, crisp,  palate-clearing.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2009 Bottle.  Very drinkable beer, true to the abbey tripel style.  Honestly I expected more from it based on much I liked the Maredsous 8.  Still a good beer, just not great. The alcohol seemed a little hot; but that makes sense for 10 ABV.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2007 Pours out a golden color with a strong malty banana aroma.  Tastes like champagne, has a wine like flavor, nice clean crisp.  In the end it has a classic beer character, true to an abbey tripel.  Smooth beer, enjoyable.  Absolutely no alcohol detected.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text:
aroma is very spicy, and with a backbone of malt, and yeastiness. 
flavour is banana and yeast, with some spicy undertones, but i did find the alcohol to come through a little more than i would have liked.
nice orange nice white head, lotsa spicy notes, somewhat citrusy, taste is again citrus, yeasty, somewhat sweet, and alcohol, but is still a very nice beer

bottle	citusry-malty aroma with spicy notes. .	Orange color with lots of bubbles, whitish head with bib bubbles and decent lacing. ..	Sweet, with spicy finish.  Hints of pepper and coriander. ..	Fery fizzy, medium body. .	A good/ well done trippel, but not too exciting.

Sunny amber with dense, pillowy, poofy head. Aroma of vanilla-soaked raisins, slight metal and oak. Light doughy notes  along with a (welcome) hint of butteriness/diacetyl. Slight hint of dusty hops. Full, lightly sweet initial sip, slight malty nuttiness and confidently spicy yeast notes. Subdued and classy EtOH in the flavor, finishes lightly sweet, cakey, all complemented by a perfect carbonation level. Sort of like a nice bread pudding.

Pours a hazy peach amber with a good inch of beige foam. Lots of dark yeast clumps quickly settle to the bottom of the glass. Good lacing. Bread yeast, alcohol, and fruity aroma - somewhat like the brandy-soaked fruitcake my better half makes.

Sweetish flavor of toasted and caramel and dark honey malt, with a touch of stone fruit. Very bready in the finish with some hot alcohol. Medium full body, generous carbonation. Quite drinkable.

Bottle.  Nice orangish pour with a decent white head and lacing.  Aroma hits you from the first pour, very nice and smooth, sweet, yet spicey with some citrus hints.  Flavor leaves little to be desired, well balanced, crisp and a nice finish.
Bottle. Nice big head with ok duration. Color is golden. Aroma is sweet and yeasty. Taste is sweet and fruity.

Bottle from Daniel for my christmas gift.  Thanks.  Pours out an orange color with a thick white head.  Smell is hoppy, sweet, spicy, yeasty, some hints of lemon and citrus fruits too.  Taste is sweet and refreshing, not much notice of the 10% alcohol.  A clear saviour for the night considering the absolute mess that was Goose Island Demolition.  Thanks for this one daniel, cant believe I havent drank it until now.  One of the better tripels I have consumed.

Bottle.  Slight big bubbled head with pretty nice lace and a slightly hazy golden color, but mostly clear.  Aroma of spice and yeast, as well as a bit of alcohol.  Taste is strong, laden with an alcohol burn and a slight sweetness.  This is quite tasty and hits hard.  I like it.  Fizzy and medium body with a nice dry finish that exudes some hop bitterness and a nice sweetness that fades quickly into the bitter and then into the alcohol.  This is a nice beer and well worth the quaff.
Large fizzy head from this cloudy, deep yellow ale.  Average alcohol smell, despite the 10% Etoh. Medium body.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle. Poured amber color with a huge fizzy off-white head that lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate tart fruity aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Medium fruity crisp flavor with a medium balanced finish of moderate duration with a small alcohol bite. This is a standout beer.
Bottle.  Very smooth and balanced. Nice plum and malted richness. Aftertaste is good and rich. I like this beer and I would certainly buy it again!

Bottle, Cellar Bar, St Andrews. Aroma is sherberty, hops and sour lime, touch of caramel. Pours a hazy gold, huge white head. Very carbonated in the mouth, malt, some plum and some alcohol (not as much as other strong ales). Raisiny, sugary aftertaste, coating and sweet.

Poured from a bottle. Hazy peach with a white fluffy head. Instantly recognisable Belgian aromas - spicey, yeasty, fruity and sweet.
The sweetness carries through to the flavour, with toffee/sugar taste and tropical fruits balanced by some peppery spices. 
This is a 10% brew where you taste every percent - leaves a lingering spirit sensation in the mouth that I didnt like, dragging down my rating. Not a favourite.
On tap at De Zotte. Excelent Tripel. Sweet, with sugary/caramel taste. High alcohol-content well hidden. Nice colors. Somewhat bitter in the end.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2010 330 ml bottle from BevMo:  Hazy peach color with a generous white head. Aroma is tropical fruit and light spice. Flavor starts sweet and fruity becoming peppery and lightly bitter with a dry orangy finish. Medium bodied and smooth with lively carbonation.

0.33l bottle at home. Hazy golden color with decent white head that didnt fade away completely. Very nice lacing.  Well carbonated. Light malty and hoppy aroma. Taste is sweet in the beginning and spicy-bitter in the finish. Decent triple.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a extremely large sized head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a transparent typically carbonated orange brown colored body. The weak aroma was caramel malt. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and strongly tingly at the finish with a medium vinous aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of caramel mily vinous and dough. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.
UPDATED: NOV 30, 2006 A gift from stegosaurus. Dark pour with thin head. Fruity aroma. Taste of frut pears with dry finish. It was just ok for me.

This is quite nice. refreshing and delicous yet bold and lick smacking! nice masking, and a truly good mix of flavours, a good tripel, alittle sour/kick-ish and a great sweetness. ya, im likin the trips!

Pours orange amber with a first fizzy then creamy white head that dissolves to a thin film. Aroma is powerful - quite sweet with a fruity yeastiness. Quite full with a vinious streak. It is sweeter than actually complex.

Draft at the Hopdevil in Zagreb  Poured a nice bright orange/amber colour, medium sized firm, thick white head that went away slowly. Faint nose, somewhat fruity, spicy and malty. The taste is pleasant, if unimpressive. A tad yeasty. Very sweet and chalky and balanced by a pleasant, if a bit underpronounced chewy hopiness. Maltiness, hints of lemon. Nice but unimpressive. Better than 8.

Bottled. Pours a clear amber with  a fluffy white head supported by streams of carbonation. Medium body and active carbonation. My overall impression is "Belgian Corriander Champagne" which would work out better if I liked champagne.

I was very disappointed. I thought it much too carbonated. The bubbles dominated my palate. This may have been an error by the barman because he poured it very carefully down the side rather than slushing it into the middle of the Maredsous glass. Also I think the temperature was a little too low. As I got to the end of the glass, both the carbonation and the cold eased, but it was still extremely light and I could not get the complexity others have discribed.

Bottle. Poured a large off-white fizzy head that was mostly lasting with very little lacing, cloudy, very little carbonation, and a golden hue. Nose was fruity, sweet, caramel and citrus. Flavor was very vinuous but not over the top, caramel, fruity, some hops and malt. Mouthfeel was tingly and vinuous. Light-medium body.  Good brew if one enjoys vinuous tasting brews which I happen to enjoy very much; however, there are better ones out there of this style IMO. Worthy of a try.

Bottle at Cave a Biere in Tournai (Belgium), a cloudy golden colour with a white pillowy head. Grassy hop aroma with vinuous and citrus notes. Brlliant palate, smooth and creamy, combining well with the vinuous flavours.

Bottle. Pours a dark gold color with an amber hue and a white head which lasts a long time and leaves some lacing. Sweet aroma of fruit and yeast. Initial taste is slightly fruity with a dry finish. Very little alcohol taste for being 10%.  A good beer with complex flavor, but if i had a choice, id take a duvel over this.
On tap. Hazy yellow-orange, white head. Aroma is musty, smokey, woody. Flavor is caramel, malt, alcohol. Slightly fruity. Not as complex as other tripels.

Hazy golden color, generous frothy off-white head.  Mouth-watering aroma of fresh fruits (apples, pears), yeast, sweet malts, and a hint of caramel.  Huge flavors:  fresh fruits (green apples, pears, green grapes), a yeasty breadiness, over a sweet malty base, balanced by a significant hoppiness.  Over all a HUGE beer with very intense and well-balanced flavors.  The evidence of the alcohol content presents itself only after the beer has been consumed.  Rich and satisfying palate, smooth and silky with an instantaneously dry finish.  A monstrous beer and an excellent example of the style.
Bottle 33 cl. Yeasty alcoholic aroma (sweet notes), long lasting white head. Dispite the alcohol level its still very sweet. Lots of carbonation.
A yellow/orange beer with a small hase. The aroma is a bit yeasty bud nice. The alcohol comes out quite strong. It has a strong and rich taste. The head is very white. Strong carbonation.

From a 750 ml, corked & caged bottle(that cork was a real bitch to get out!)...
Appears a transparent gold with faint haziness and tons of carbonation bubbles racing to the top of the dense, 3 finger, white head. Lots of webbing is left around the glass.
Smell is of mildly doughy, caramel, candi sugar, apricots, citrus, herbal, & earthy notes, with perhaps of touch of banana deep in the background.
Taste is sweet of melted caramel, apricot reduction, sugar, pepper, and a decent malty quality that has flashes of the citrusy hops.
Mouthfeel is of a medium bodied yet slightly chewy, sugary, cookie and spiced liquid treat.

From 750.  Pours a murky golden orange with off white head.  Nose is light fruits, apricot, yeasty and a little candy like.  Flavor follows with a little alcohol in the back.  Some off flavors like cardboard hold this one back a bit.

75cl bottle. This blonde ale poured with a lacy white head, most of which dissipated rather quickly. There is a floral malty aroma. The flavor is very yeasty and carbonated with a flat bitter finish. It is a complex beer with variable and interesting tastes, such as caramel, and citrus.

Brown bottle, 33 cl, best before date 05 2006; eye: burnt orange with amber reflections, nice beige head made up of small bubbles, nice effervescence, lots of suspended yeast, lightly hazy, lacing; nose: yeast, head diminishes odours quite a lot, citrusy, caramelized malt, clove; mouth: sugar, alcohol, caramel, finale in bitterness with a hint of alcohol but finale changes pretty much with every sip, creamy texture, mildly sweet and bitter, medium body, lightly carbonated; overall: ok

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 33 cl, meilleure avant 05 2006; oeil : orange brûlée avec des reflets ambrés, belle mousse beige formée de petites bulles, belle effervescence, pas mal de matières en suspension, légèrement voilée, opaque, dentelle; nez : levure, mousse atténue beaucoup les odeurs, citrique, malt caramélisé, clou de girofle; bouche : sucre, alcool, caramel, finale tout en amertume avec une pointe dalcool, texture crémeuse, moyennement sucrée et amère, corps moyen, légèrement carbonatée; en résumé : bien

Bottle, 33 cl. Amber-orange color. 
White head. Sweet, with fruit notes, little bitter. Tatse is very alcohol. To much. 
Personally i like the blond 6° more.

Very cloudy, yellowish orange body. Head is of white bubbles and lasts for about 30 seconds. Smells of yeast and coriander, clove spice and acid hops. Taste is strong and full, with thick malt, citrus tang, apple cinnamon, lemon and grapes. Really fine flavors. Big alcohol. Even though there wasnt much of a head, body still looks luscious, with bubbles continually rising and putting on a good show.

Clear floral citrus aroma.  Orange hazy appearance. Light sweetness up front with a very bitter finish. Medium body with a thick mouthfeel. Creamy and lively. Bitter long lasting finish. Alcohol is very present in the taste. Very delicious.
Sweet compared to the high alcohol. Malty, fruity and bitterness in the end. very good

I used to think I liked this beer, but now I dont think its all that pleasing.  Anyway, it pours a pretty deep gold color, with a good sized head, even pouring slow.  Aroma was tough for me to detect, all I was able to notice (at that time anyway) was a bit of yeast.  Taste is sweet upfront with caramel malt flavors and fruitiness competing for your attention.  However, the sweet qualities in this beer simply dont mesh well with the other flavors (and I usually like very sweet beers).  The finish is equally conflicted, with a bitterness that doesnt seem hop-related at all.  Its like it became kind of astringent when it hit my throat.  Carbonation was pretty high, and the beer was neither thick, nor thin.  This just didnt do it for me now, maybe some other point in time.
Pours bright amber into a tulip.  Offwhite micro head with very good retention.  Malt notes.  Fizzy with strong alcohol front to back. Warming.

Hazy bronze topped by a large, foamy, airy, white cap. Sweet, floral, fruity aroma with hints of richness and musty yeast. Flavors adds some subtle goodnplentys and alcohol warmth to the same aroma characters. Dry finish and earthy, floral aftertaste. Full body, creamy with just enough carbonation to balance. Well done tripel.
Amberish orange color with a white compact creamy head. Smells of honey, oranges, and clover. Dry with warming and spicy alcohol and  long dry finish.

Greet aroma. Sweet, caramel and other fruit notes, mainly lemon, herbs. Front is mild, Mid-palate is fruity with notes of cinnamon. On the finish the beer fades but then comes back and gives way to an exceptional finish. I prefered de 6°
Pours a light golden color with a nice white heaad.  The aroma is mostly yeast and some floral notes.  Flavor is also very yeasty and has a hint of spice.  Good carbonation, and rather refreshing.

Pours medium golden with a MASSIVE lasting head. WOW !!!  Aroma is yeasty and spicy. Oh how I love Belgian beer. Flavor is outstanding. Malt, yeast, and spice. Alcohol is noticible (which I like) but not overpowering. This will be a good one for my cellar.

How do you pronounce this one?   


A thick white head gives way to a beautiful colored orange beer. Aromas of apricots and tangerine citrus jump out of the glass. The beer is alive with tiny campaign like bubbles. Taste is also dominated by apricot like characteristics. Good mouth feel, with well balanced carbonization. Little to no bitterness at the end of the pallet. Crisp and clean till just the end of the aftertaste, where the only alcohol qualities assert themselves.  Very nice for a hot day, or the start of spring.

750mL bottle.  Poured into an Ommegang glass.  Hazy orange color, creamy eggshell colored head.  Immediate aromas of white wine.  Then some orange, apples, and a little spice.  Wow, very full bodied.  Caramel flavor.  Perfect amount of carbonation.  What a nice bottle.  Slightly sweet and Lots of hop bitterness in the finish that you would not expect from any abbey!

Good size white head on a clear orange/bronze body. Aroma first up of yeast then followed by orange and some spice. Full smooth taste, good carbonation, aroma follows through to the taste, citric bitterness on the finish. Enjoyable!

Pours clear amber with a large eggshell head. The aroma isnt as strong as that of most good Tripels. What is there is yeast and a touch of earthy hops. Flavor begins bready and musty, but quickly dies down to light grass and a little bit of spice. The alcohol is hidden well.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2007 Big tan head at room temp with an orangey brown color, it has a very belgian aroma. Tastes like cherry vinegar with a thin astringent taste, and it warms going down. My GF says "it tastes like leaves." Perhaps I should have chilled this product a bit before drinking.  $3/12oz

Amber color, white head and laght lacing. Nose is dusty and sweet with some musky hops and plenty of yeast. Full body and lots of umami. Flavor is sweet, nice clean malts and fig, huge body and alcohol not too strong. Lovely, full and complex yet balanced beer. Very nice belgian beer, keeps things going. A bit sweet and dark for a triple, needs more carbonation and snappy hops and bitterness, but its good either way.

Bottled. Orange colour, big fluffy white head. Aroma of alcohol and caramel. And lots of other stuff. Flavour is also full with caramel, alcohol, malts dry fruits. Another extremely welldone brew by Maredsous. These brews are, except for good session drinks also totally lovely to combine with food! Super!
Bottle, 750 ml. Looks like a tripel, smells like a tripel, tastes like a tripel. And a damn good one too, another rock solid Maredsous.

Bottled(750ml). -Dark golden coloured, huge white head, sweet and very fruity aroma with slight spicy notes and few alcohol hints. In general I didnt liked it so its not worth of 17euro that Ive paid for it.

Deep amber coloured with some carbonation and an average white head. Deep yeast sweet fruity aroma, with some minor herby touches. Full sweet body. Finish is more bitter, with a clear alcoholic touch. With some sweet fruity hints. Definitily a good beer.
Bottled. Dark golden colour with a white head. Aroma is harmonic yeast,fruit and apple. Flavour is harmonic with hidden alcohol, yeast citrus and sweetness.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2006 Bottle. Pours a murky amber with a medium white head with little lacing. Pretty light in the palate, and a little overly carbonated for me. I think it could benefit from some aging. Flavors of citrus and caramel are followed with a suitable bitterness. Alcohol is well masked.
Very nice Trip.  Id say Steward nailed the desciption on this.  I cant do any better.
Bottle. Golden muddy colour with a huge mostly lasting creamy white head. Aroma and taste of fruits, hops and spices. Good palate.
Light golden brown hue  nice white head  nose cane sugar, light spring flowers and earth  sour red fruit, alcohol, cloves, oranges taste- bubbly body  aftertaste bitter and spices

Translucent and golden amber in color with a creamy, thin, white shaded head and splendid lacing.  Bananas strive with pepper and buttered sourdough heals with some herbaceous elements to the tune of gardenias and stephanotises.  Effervescent crème strides in with hot bananas.  Clover, pepper and buttered graham crust.  Sublime proclamation of wholesome, peppery quaffs.  Spicy bakery beginnings and happy endings emit fried sugary bananas and similarly fruited meringue pies.  Creamy, quaffable performance is capped by grahams and banana oatmeal in the end.

Draught @ Redbones 7/3/06. Pours a dark orange color with a white frothy head. Lacing is well retained throughout the glass. Nose is quite fruity with lots of grape notes and some sweet caramel. Palate is clean and moderately full. Flavor is more of the fruity grapeness and caramel that was present in the nose. Finishes clean with a light touch of sweetness.

Bubbly honey color, full white head.  Very clingy and lingering.  Aroma is clear and sour.  First taste is beautiful, full of flavor, tart, tart, tart, spicy.  Aftertaste is a little overstrong-big kicker finish, but overall, I am loving these Belgium Tripels.

(bottle - corked & caged 750 ml) Dark amber color with a puffy white head. Aroma is lots of dark fruits, yeast, spices, cloves, and alcohol. Flavor is very rich and sweet with a nice yeasty and spice middle and a very sweet and slightly tangy finish. Chewy with a nice alcohol kick.
Bottle.  Pours a medium  amber with a large head.  Dark fruits dominate with raisins, prunes, dried cherries, etc.  Cloying sweetness that is followed by a large alcohol burn.
Bottle.  Pours transparent amber to gold with white head remnicent of Duvel that lingers for 15 minutes.  Nice hops aroma.  Not quite as fruity as Duvel.
golden with fine white head.  Aroma and taste of caramel & fruits. Very filling and powerfull beer (easily feel the high alcohol) Fine long and bitter (pleasant) finish! Great!

Bottle from Bev Mo in La Mesa.  Not overly impressed with this triple.  Pours a medium copper color.  Head was off white and dissipated quikly.  Nose of different citrus fruits.  The same of its taste.

Bottle: Deep orangey coloured, firm, small creamy head; fruity (oranges, orange peel) citrousy, a bit caramelly nose; sweet (fruity) and faint bitter flavour, creamy mouthfeel, quite full bodied; impressive fruity, a bit tart and bitter-sweet finish. A very pleasant night-cap !

Well, its a style I really enjoy and this was one that was somewhat "hyped." But, I was kinda let down by Maredsous 10 and feel guilty for not liking it as much as others. But, the pour was boring (for the style), orange-yellow color with a thin white head that sustained itself well and provided decent lacing... but nothing overly impressive. The aroma was sweet and malty, of definite apples and bananas. Flavor was bananas, cloves, and even some candi-sugar. The finish had a nice hop touch to it along with a dryness. Mouthfeel was typical, of course also carbonated. A nice beer, but not in the same category as Chimay White or Karmeliet.

Bottle. Clear, sparkling golden color; big white head with ample lacing. Slightly sour, honey aroma, yeast and strong distinctive Belgian smell. Strong and sweet malt profile, alcohol warming, spiced bitterness. Somewhat dry finish. Went well with vegetarian reuben sandwich with grilled apples.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2009 On tap at Capital Ale House - Downtown on 10/27/2008. Clear golden copper body with a medium creamy off-white head with belgian lace. Sweet candi sugar aroma with lots of fruit. Big candi sugar flavor, very sweet fruit and caramel. Medium body with moderate carbonation and a syrupy finish. 8/4/7/3/15 - 3.7


06/05/2006: Clear golden color with a large frothy white head. Aroma of sweet malt with light spice. Sweet piced malt flavor with some apparent alcohol. 7/3/7/3/13 - 3.3
It has a cloudy dark-golden color with a white, foamy head. An aroma of honey wafts from the glass. This is a smooth beer, though the alcohol is evident. It has a slight nutty aftertaste.

Golden orange/amber color with large white head. LOADS of sticky webby lacing.

The nose is pretty much all alcohol. Theres a little of the expected yeast but the alcohol drowns everything out for the most part.

Sweet fruitiness, complemented by a very bready yeast flavor. It dries out in the end as it warms up thanks to the alcohol character in this one.

Fluffy feeling that thins out a little toward the end. A great tripel. Definitely recommended.

Poured a gold color with a firm lasting white head with good lacing.  Aroma is of sweet fruits; banana and apricot are most prevalent.  Flavor is a little disappointing, there is a bitterness combined with an astringency that mask what might be an enjoyable beer.  A noticable hop flavor is there and seems terribly out of place.  There are some candied fruit flavors hiding in the background but are overpowered.

Pours a nice golden amber color with a large egg shell golor head.  Flavor is very fruity with a nice balance of malts.  Aroma is some what yeasty and fruity as well.  Has a nice warming effect as it goes down.  Alcohol isnt hidden very well.  Over all a nice brew indeed.
Golden body with a nice bubbly head.  Banana aroma, typical of Belgian yeasts.  Great body, smooth flow, taste is fruit intensive with some malts.  Cool ending.

Bottle.  Golden color with bubbles and big nice white head.  Yeast, soap and orange aroma.  Taste of yeast alcohol, citrus with dry finish, good carbonation and alcohol well hidden.  very drinkable.

Bière de couleur doré avec des bulles dans sa robe et un bon collet blanc.  Odeur de levure, savon et orange.  Goût de levure, dalcool et dagrumes avec un fini sec, co2 assez élevé et alcool bien dissémulé.  Descend très bien.

Bottle.
Clear orange coloured with a white head.
Aroma of fruits and spices.
Flavour of fruits and spices.
750ml corked bottle.  Clear and ruby, golden hued.  Clinging white head.  Sweet and sugary.  Toffee and apples and cookies.  Nice fruity esters.

This was one with a bit of a disconnect between the aroma and the flavor. Not that there was anything wrong with the flavor, mind you, but this had a really nice aroma. Oh, but first - orangey brown, with virtually no head. Really nice aroma - buttered toast, with hints of apple pie and pecans. Flavor is smooth and sweet, but dominated by a juicy, orangey note. Some hints of orange peel bitteness. Tres tasty.  Sampled at Noogfest2.

11.2 oz bottle.  Clear copper colored; white head quickly turns to a skin.  Nose is sweet and yeasty with cloves and spices.  Sweet, vegetal, prominent alcohol, bubblegum.  Pool water aftertaste.  Medium light, medium carb.  I just cant get past the the alcohol but still close to being very good.
I shouldve mentioned that even though I will probably not try this beer again it will always hold a special place in my beer heart.  Back before I found RateBeer (8 months ago?) my brother and I went into Pappous on Balt. Pike to pick up our usual Harp or Bass.  He spotted the Maredsous at like $15 for a 4-pack and said lets give it a go.  Stuff foamed up like a beast and did me up real good after two.  So i guess this is a farewell.

Poured a hazy copper color with a small off-white head.  The aroma was sweet and malty with candy notes.  Yeasty.  The flavor was sweety and malty with phenol yeasty notes.  Lively mouthfeel.  Medium bodied and a nice warming sensation.
Golden in color with amedium white head. Fruit and spice aroma. Spicy with a warming alcohol note.
A yeasty citrus aroma with a cloudy yellow appearance. The flavor was similar to sponge cake and lemon sour candy. Very sugary and carbonated. Another good one at NoogFest II

Julios Spring Beer Festival. Rich aroma of varied pears and white wine. Pour of hazed yellow amber. Flavor is a stingingly sweet mellow sugars ,with copious light fruit and a decent floral run. Lemons and cardamon flow well in this beer, with a delicate nose and superb balance. The alcohol isnt overwhelming and helps the beer along nicely. Light smack of dry grasses, balances well.
perfum and floral banana with lemon and menthol.  pretty decent beer that has a decent aroma as well.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2009 2006/05/15 - Pours hazy golden with a thin foamy tan head. Aroma of honey, toasted grain, and some restrained frutiiness. Taste is more intense fruity esters, notes of cantaloupe, apricot, and toasted honey malt. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy bodied and slightly sticky with lush carbonation. 
Ar 7 Ap 4 Fl 7 Mf 4 Ov 16

2009/09/19 - Pours dark golden with a mostly receding off-white head. Notes of honey, cantaloupe, white wine, pale malt, sugar, and cotton candy. Full to heavy bodied with lush carbonation. Strong and estery.
Ap 4 Ar 8 Ta 7 Mf 4 Ov 15

This tripel pours a clear golden straw color with a large white head.  Very fruity aroma, with citrus, tropical, and dark fruits all together along with the typical belgian yeast aroma.  Very rich, full-bodied flavor with plenty of floral and grassy hops and caramel malts.  There is also some citrus flavors with a slight sourness and a bit of spice.  There is lively carbonation making for a good champagne-like mouthfeel and a clean crisp aftertaste.  Overall this is a pretty good Belgian tripel.
Dark orange body with a large head. Aroma was very fruity... almost anything you could think of. Also had some sugar and very light pepper. Sticky sweet finish, tasty... good stuff.
leaves very pleasant taste in the mouth. Strong and sweet malty, alcohol linger fruit. Big Head. Pale. Big little love. Im in a dark bar. Im liking it.
Golden amber very hazy with creamy white head. Smell of a sour citrus floral malt. Very bitter tingle of malt flavor with a sweet finish.
UPDATED: APR 27, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours golden/orange with a white head,nice aroma of spices, citrus, alcohol. Flavor is sweet, citrus, alcohol, and smooth.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2007 First ratingBottle at Bishops Arms Linköping, Sweden. November, 2005.Dark color. Pretty low scent and taste, much less than expected. No hint of the high alcohol. Pretty boring actually.6/3/5/3/11=2.8Second rating March 17, 2007.(33 cl bottle at The Rover, Göteborg)Shady orange color, fluffy white head. Sweet apricot and marzipan scent. Spicy yeast and bitter taste, sweet yogurt aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness.7/3/8/4/16=3.8

330ml bottle (bb.Oct.08). Deep golden colour. Large rocky head and long lived foam. Aromatic hops and ripe fruit character. Spicy flavour with hints of orange and yeasty undertones. A robust ale with a long warming finish.

from the bottle best by 03/07. poured dark honey with a off white head that left some good lacing. aroma, honey pokes its head out first, than some sweet fruits, alcohol, a hint of yeast. flavor the alcohol comes out really nice than brown sugar and some sourness as it warms fruits. good beer

750ml bottle. Pours a fairly dark reddish orange color. Moderate foam that does not go away. Slightly sweet, yeasty aroma. Syrupy fruit notes. Flavor is yeasty right up front along with some spiciness. Light graininess with only a trace of alcohol. A little creamy. WEll hidden alcohol. Not really too exciting.

750 ml- This is the second time I had this beer, and it was definately much better this time. The first was in a small bottle. Light orange in color with a good soapy head. Hints of bananas and spices are present with each sip with a touch of hoppiness. Pleasantly surprised.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2009 Pours a clear dark gold color with a thick white head. Pleasant aroma of fruits, spices and bready yeast. The flavor also has a bread feeling with some fruits and spices, but feels blander than the aroma, bordering on boring. The body is light to medium with an oily texture and moderate carbonation. Not bad, but not great either.
Amber color, thick champoo head, some fruity flavors, apple and figs.   Finishes clean, crisp. nice one but not my favorite.

Bottle at Chaucers, in London, Ont-Hazy deep orange with a thick froth of beige head, and tight lace. Fresh peaches, yeast, bread crust, and hops with flowers in the nose. Semi sweet dried peach flavour upfront, with spicy bread, yeasty funk, and a nice bite. Creamy smooth with astringentcy in the finish. Very warming. Good.
Sweet and alcohol aroma. Certainly a very strong beer with definite alcohol flavors. The finish is very dry with some bitterness. Im not crazy about the beer but it aint bad.

Had this beer on draft.  It was very thick, & I dont think I could call it a white ale or a brown ale, it was somewhere in between.
It smelled sweet, & of coconut.  It poured golden in color & was cloudy.  Very good flavor.

Robe blonde légèrement voilée surmontée dune mousse blanche persistente. Arômes de houblon floral, de sucre candi et dépices. Saveurs de fruits confits, dalcool, de houblon amérisant, dépices et de blé.

bottled.  Thick, yet average head.  Nose of alcohol, sweet spices, and yeast. Golden & clear.  Taste is sweet with very mild alcohol bite, spices are mild too. Easy.  Finishes a bit stronger, but never harsh.
Great tripel. Pours a deep gold witn an inch-thick white head. Very nice lacing. Big floral aroma with some banana and alcohol. Nice malty taste, definitely a tripel. Very good.
Niuce aroma of bubble gum, apricot and grass.  Good use of malt to balance the alc, very subtle.  Flavours is quite fruity, with a hint of honey.

750 mL bottle. Pours golden with fizzy white head. The aroma is banana, yeast, corriander, zest, and just a touch of alcohol burn. The flavor is the standard tripel: banana, a hint of zest, a touch of hops (hallertau?), and a sweet, fruity finish. Some spices come out in the aftertaste. Not superior, but pretty good.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2009 Bottle 0,33l. Pale golden. A large tanned head that settles but does not disappear. Another Belgian beer with fruity champagne aroma. Warming feeling of alcohol. Some sediments. KI=8
Big white head, gold orange in color.  Pear on the nose and in the flavor, with hints of honey.  Yeast and light touch of hop to finish.

Aroma:Peach,pear....
Appearance:Clear orange gold,huge white head,a lot of co2 bubble...
Flavor:Sweet ,fruit,yeast,complexe flavor.....

Pours a slightly hazy golden orange with a large foamy white head that laced and retained.  Aroma of Belgian spices, yeast, banana and citrus. Very nice Tripel aroma.  Flavors of the same with more of the yeast coming through. Can tell its the same yeast the 8 had.

Orangey-amber with a big white head. Sweet, yeasty aroma with some cellar notes. Quite complex, maybe even some hay. Flavour is sweet, full of almonds, good, pleasant bitterness, very warming alcohol. Full-bodied. A well-made, strong tripple.

From a bottle into a snifter. Beer pours a slightly hazy light orange-amber color with a large, creamy, off-white, slowly diminishing and mostly lasting head. Great BL left on the glass. The aroma is lightly malty with notes of sweet toasted grain and toasted bread; hoppy with a traces of pine, herb and grapefruit and a moderate note of hay; yeasty with a light note of celler; miscellaneous components included a moderate hit of sweet grated carrot and vitamin B. The flavor was moderately bitter, heavily sweet with a long, luxurious, warm, moderately sweet, lightly bitter finish. The body is medium-to-full, the texture is watery-to-creamy, the carbonation is average and theres a pleasant heavier-than-moderate alcoholic warmth in the sweet finish.

Bottle at sharpedge...pours a murky orange and has a beautiful creamy white head (what a difference proper glassware makes).  Smell is sweet light fruity and yeast.  Flavor is remarkably malty and has some excellent spicy notes to balance the fruity sweetness.  This is a beer that has that paper aftertaste...no idea what that flavor is yet, but I hope to find out.  Alcohol is balanced very well.   Mouthfeel is fairly carbonated.

"Poured an orangey color with a thin white head that laced well. Aroma was sweet with apples and bananas coming to the front. Flavor was of bananas spices and something else not sure. Mouthfeel was a little to carbonated. Good beer, by far not as good as the chimay."
Frothy head. Clody dark yellow.  Full soft body.  Flavor leaves much to be desired.  Good malt notes are strong. Some sweet fruit, that gives way to a dry skunky, alcoholic pinch.

Kind of disappointed with this one.  Pours clear gold with a massive, thick, fluffy white head and lots of carbonation.  Aroma was a little weak; yeasty and sugary, with some apple.  The taste was mostly apples, raisins, and candy sugar with some spice.  The problem was that all the flavors seemed to be a little flat.  Good, but not great

A very good Trippel. Poured a dark golden in the glass with a creamy, white head that smelled of yeast and fruit with some alcohol notes. Taste thats spicy with a pleasant alcohol warmth. Crisp. This is brewed by the same company that makes Duvel so its little surprise that this beer is very "Duvel-ish" but with a little less carbonation. An excellent beer!!
Botttle.  Very nice peach-apple malt aroma.  Dark tan color - cloudy with moderate head.  Lightly sweet apple flavor initially with a peppery acidic finish.  Moderate carbonation.   Very nice.
Thin white head, orange colored, citrus aroma with a yeasty and fizzy finish.
Bottle. Astonishingly small white head for such a strong beer. Unclear orange body. Orange Aroma. Hops with unpleasant alcohol flavor.
Bottle 330ml. Appearance:  golden color with a white head. Aroma: citrus, malt, yeast, spice. Flavor: alcohol, yeast, spice. Sweet after-taste.
750mL bottle (in a plastic cup): Amber-red/brown color, big head-white.  Aroma of raisin, flowers.  Strong taste of perfume, fizzy, alcohol.

Thanks to Captain Cougar for this beer.  Poured an effervescent clear amber with a frothy/creamy white head which left a film on the beer.  Sweet aroma of grape juice and bitter hops.  Flavor is lightly sweet vinous grapes with some flowery hops and a light alcoholic dryness to it.  Finish is somewhat buttery and medicinal.  Fairly light, mildly fizzy body.  A pretty nice tripel.
From bottle poured into glass. Creamy, foamy, thick head. Head sticks to glass. Hints of fruit. Golden color. Sweet after-taste. Overall a delicious beer.

Draught at Tylers in Durham, NC. Slightly hazy, yellow-orange color with big bubbly white head that laced the glass. Malty, slightly metallic nose with prominent yeastiness and some alcohol. There is a bit of bubble gum in the aroma as well. The alcohol, yeast, ans caramel come out again in the flavor. The beer is not sweet, but there is a grainy-brown sugar aftertaste. Very complex, delicious beer.
Golden colored pour, frothy white head, hints of fruit in the taste.  A little dry but not bad.  It was pretty good.

Mmm yummy...this brew has that special belgian yeast banana, lemon, honey aroma. Hints of alcohol. Pours a golden orange with a monster head that leaves a lace trail. Spicey on the tongue with a banana bread body that is accented by some estery fruits, peppery alcohol and a lemon-honey finish. Fizzy and medium in the mouth with a good balance. You can feel the 10% ABV warming soon after the first few sips. A very nice enjoyable tripel.

Bottled. Sparkling dark golden, with a huge, creamy, off-white head. Aroma is banana, citrus, cloves, malts, yeast and some alcohol. A long, mild bitterness along with alcohol follows the flavor of banana, yeast, alcohol, spicyness, sweetness and some acidity. One of my favorites on Vinmonopolet, the Norwegian government-run stores that is the only legal outlets for beverages containing more than 4.75% ABV. (060105)

Big rocky off white head leaving nice lace sits on a slightly hazy golden pour. Sour yeasty aroma with alcohol in evidence. Light malt flavor accompanies the medium body. Light fruit esters of bananna and pineapple, although a yesty sourness and ?wheat malt dominate. All the malt and yeast is balanced by citrus hop flavors, followed by a sweet malty finish. Smooth, refreshing, and easily drinkable.
33cl bottle from a petrol station in Belguim.  poured yellow with a good head. Aroma is bready and yeasty. Sweet malt with belgian yeasty. Alcohol present in the finish.
Ill take some of this any day.  Smooth easy going beer.  Slightly malty and a bit sweet/ sugary.  colour was pale looked almost thin, cant detect the alcohol at all.

Bottle at Ciros. Light yellow, decent white head.  Lots of yeast and alcohol in mild but pleasing aroma.  Thin to medium mouthfeel.  Nice simple accessible but flavourful taste:  lots of yeast, light malt, and just a hint of the alcohol strength.  Some floral like notes as well. Simple and quaffable with no major flaws or characteristics that would make it stand out against others in this category.

Yellow-orange body with abundant carbonation and a thick, frothy lasting white head. Aroma of yeasty bread, leather, faint clove, roses, and sweet bananas. Doughy malt flavor with warm alcohol and notes of vanilla, pepper, and leather. Semi-sweet with some stale, woody, drying hop bitterness. Smooth, ample body. A good tripel.

Pours clear deep gold with 2-finger off-white head and nice lacing.  The aroma is flowery hopcitric, with some slight funky notes and peppery notes.  The flavor is bold, with solid peaty flowery hops and citrus plus some fruity melon and funky notes.  This one is very good.

11.2 oz capped bottle, fairly fresh: pours a slightly cloudy rose-gold with a thick marshmallow-like, white head.  Sourdough and peppery clove effervescence laced with alcohol and pale malts in the aroma.  Gritty and slightly fizzy palate with sweet honeydew melon and banana flavours.  Very drinkable with the alcohol mostly hidden behind the doughy and pale malts.  Cheers to my new co-worked, Dustin for this treat.

Pours clear oranger, with a nice thick head. Sweet fruity aroma. I smell apple, yeast, malt. Typical strong Tripel aroma. Well carbonated but not fizzy. Alcohol is hidden well in the start, but comes out in the finish. Flavor is sweet, light, and slightly spicy. A decent tripel considering the price.

11.2oz  bottle best before 07 2008. Pours a clear copper with a big, slightly off-white pillowy head. Smells of banana, clove, yeast, and some spices. Pretty well balanced with just a little bit of bitterness, and a finish of alcohol.  Doesnt taste like a 10% ABV.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Very nice tripel. Very smooth and well balanced. Fruity touches, apple. Well done, very enjoyable.

nice tripel.

smooth, bold, well-disguised alcohol content.

smooth, warm aftertaste

possibly the best tripel Ive tried

this is my 70th review and my standards have changed since my earlier tripel reviews
Had my first taste today.  Have to honestly say that I was slightly disappointed.  Very carbonated and had a pretty good flavor but after hearing great things about this one, I was expecting more.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2009 A pleasing hazy orange with a thick white head.  Well-carbonated.   Grain, alcohol, apricot in nose.  Oily, bubbly, sweet palate.  Finish lingers.  First one of this style for me, hope it is characteristic of it!

Rerate 5/3/09 this really is an excellent tripel.  Basically an after dinner drink but this one has more complexity going for it than some tripels.

I was surprised at how light this beer was, for the amount of flavor/ malt character it packed.  Nice full body.  Fruity hops were pretty mild, but fitting for the style I believe.  There was a lot of figgy, plummy fruit in the malts too.  Yum!
On Tap. Orangeish with a small, frothy head. Aromas of fruity alcohol. Sweet flavor with some fruitiness and a warming alcohol finish. Very tasty with my Sunday brunch.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2005 Amber, deep golden.
Aroma: sourish, citric, apple, malt, yeast and spices. Hoppy.
Flavor: sweet, alcoholic (in a bitter-sour way). Sticky, reminds me of Montagnarde. Dull.

33cl bottle from Auchan. Amber colour with thick off white head. Slightly syrupy mouthfeel with candy sugar sweetness. Toffee/caramel throughout. Doesnt taste its strength. Some hop on finish which gives it a dry tang. Nice enough triple
33 cl bottle. Orange colour with a very nice white head. Nice aroma of fruit and some sweetness. Great flavour but ends with a to much alcoholic finish.
Bottle: Orange colour with a heavy snowy head, nice lace. Orange, ginger, fruity, the alcohol from the triple fermentation comes through strongly but in a good way, it warms you inside.

Poured from that odd shaped little bottle into my glass, this beer has a lasting creamy white head with dense lacing.  The body is a hazy amber/bronze color.  The aroma is floral, grains, dust, light belgian spices.  The flavor is pleasant.  Fresh florals, belgian spices, caramel, subtle sourness.  Very easy drinking.  The palate is smooth and creamy.  Alcohol is hidden well.  This is pretty decent stuff.
Yep, that is it. Not as good as I was hoping for. Wanted this to a good triple, but, below average. The alcohol was right here, and I wont be back.
definitely medicinal.  underwhelmed by this.  so many better tripels. 750 ml bottle in duvel tulip
Light to amber colored, rich tasting. Tasted from bottle. Fairly good although a little light for me.
orange with a medium sized head.  mild aroma of yeast and hops.  not as yeasty as some tripels.  a little alcohol noticable.  aftertaste is a little too sweet.  almost medicinal.

Light orange with huge light clean white head and a tornado  like carbonation erupting from the center of the glass.  An expected lace nicely coats the glass as I slowly drink it.  Aroma is sharp and fruity, spicey and strong fruit with an alcohol presence.  There is also a classic yeast and spice character which come in secondiarly.  The feel is vibrant, active, and fruity.  Wine like feel and great fruit flavor.  Yeast and expected spice flavors top of this complex and very nice beer.  Found at Johns Grocery in Iowa City.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry at Ciros. Pours a cloudy orange-gold with a small off-white head. Mild, sweet & sour aroma with malt, fruit, spices and  alcohol. Malty and yeasty flavour didnt do much for me, it was quite "meh". The alcohol is too prominent in the aroma and taste. I found it just O.K.

"Its a little sticky" - HogTownHarry
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Dark gold with creamy but small head. Aroma of peach, pepper, slightly funky yeast. Good dry hoppy finish. Very good.

Mild spun sugar aroma, but remarkably light aroma for a belgian. Orange hue with the typical Belgian head. Some pear notes and huge malt backbone. Very one dimensional. I expect a wider flavor palate from a Tripel.

Bottle (330ml).  At Ciros - shared with blankboy.  Poured light amber-gold, almost murky, with a decent slightly off-white head.  Aroma of sour cider, fruity malt, pineapple, sour citrus, some spiciness, light spruce resin and alcohol - quite mild.  Taste also quite mild - noticeable alcohol hit (tingly ears), spicy, with steeped fruits, some ashy hop bitterness on warming - starts soft/sweet, ends a bit more alcohol/bitter.  Mouthfeel average body, slightly sticky and minerally.  An okay trippel, somewhat one-dimensional - the alcohol - perhaps a touch harsh, particularly in light of the superior St. Bernardus trippel that preceded it.
On tap at the Flying Saucer in Charlotte.  Golden coloring with a very fruity aroma.  Flavor was warming, yeasty, and sweet.  I liked the 6, and wasnt a big fan of the 8, but this is a  good tripel.
Classic belgian ale. Deep golden straw color with a nose of pairs. Yeasty, malty and smooth.  Yummy!!

Bottle.  Pours hazy deep gold with light carbonation that kept going for some time.  Nose of alcohol, sweet herbs, slight orange or lemon.  A little malty, bready flavor at first, finishing with sweet, warming fruit brandy.

Poured from a 330 ml bottle. Nice floral aroma with the stinging sensation of double digit ABV. The beer itself is a lovely golden orange with a thick and somewhat rocky white head with tons of lacing. The flavor is typically sweet for the style with a lot of alcohol burn that probably takes away from the fruity flavors I usually expect from this style. Still an enjoyable beer and probably one that could go for some cellaring. Maybe Ill re-rate this one next year or the year after.

Pours a cloudy medium gold with a montrous fluffy white head which lasts a long time.  Aroma is traditional tripel yeastiness, with some spices but lots of fruity esters- hints of banana with a bit of apricot.  Big light bready malt flavor with a fair amount of yeast, with some musty hints.  Really nice full body and alcohol is hidden well.  Smooth long lasting finish.
Golden hue with a substantial lingering head. Taste is light, refreshing with hints of spice and citrus. Good, but not one of the best in the style.

I had this in Madrid, I believe it was bottled but came to me already poured in the glass, and from reading others remarks this might not be what i had. Dark brown color with a nice frothy head. aroma is sweet and malthy. Flavor is quite sweet with lots of malt and some figgy dark fruitiness. Very smooth and drinkable.
Citrus, spices, original taste, difficult to clearly analyze. Excellent. Found in Belgium and some french stores.

dark golden yellow and cloudy body, with a thick creamy white head.  the aroma is strong malty sweet, some white candi sugar, yeastiness, spice, dried lemon rind, maybe a little dried pineapple too.  flavor is pretty typical tripel, strong malty sweet backbone, a little clean alcohol flavor in the middle like white rum, and some more dried tropical citrus and spices.  mild yeast funkiness too.

Malt, yeast, and light fruit aromas with a touch of alcohol.  This is a great looking beer that would no doubt scare many who didnt know better due the significant quantify of sediment floating around the glass and sitting on the bottom.  The beer is a very light brown/gold color.  The head is small but thick and remains on top of the glass.  Complex flavor.  The fruit is there immediately as well as coriander and flowers.  The alcohol is noticeable in the taste but not unpleasant or overpowering.  Chalky finish.
Bottle poured a hazy gold with an off white head. Aromas of apples, citrus, pineapple and spices. Flavors of pineapple, citrus, spices, some astringency, with a dry bitter finish.
(Bottle)  Poured a nice, thick head and deep gold color.  Lots of subtle flavors going on.  An average triple, but a very good beer.

11.2 oz bottle: Thick yet soft pillow of head across a sparkling bronze copper beer. Aroma is of a normal strength and keeps a sweet vanilla, bubblegum, and sift presence of yeast. In the flavor i found an over bearing taste of soap which was a big turn off but a little vanilla, yeast, banana, and pepper allowed me to continue the drink. A notice of warm alcohol was felt both in the mouth and throat of course because of the high percent content. Not as good as i could have wished. Best before June 2007 stamped on label.

From the 750ml bottle. Pours a clear gold with a slight orange hue and a tall long lasting white head. Fruity citrus candy sweetness up front followed by a train of belgian yeast esters. A very healthy carbonation really made the spices shine up front and dried out the finish very well and kept the body from being too syrupy.

From a 330 ml bottle. Dark gold color with a large, slightly off white head. The aroma is ripe apples with a hint of horseblanket and hay. A little bit of pineapples and cinnamon finish the nice smells. The taste has some rich apples and cinnamon. There is also some bread and dry figs. Finishes with a little cardboard. Overall, still a nice brew.

Slightly hazy, light amber colour with a 1cm white head. Barnyardy, fruity and caramel aroma. Taste is sweet and sugary, with some pepper and hop bitterness later on. Alcohol is detectable in the warming finish. Medium bodied, quite highly carbonated.  Good tripel.
draft, golden color w/ little foam.  aroma of malt and fruit, full bodied.  sweet and fruity.
Very easy drinking for me, didnt even notice the alcohol. poured a  bronze color with little head, I think ,knowing where I bought it, this is an older bottle. I really enjoyed this one.
Light spice and cake aroma which carries right over into the flavor. The flavors blended well with the ABV making for a great dessert beer. Very good.
Una de las mejores cervezas que he probado. De muy alta gradación (10%). Color dorado Y  muy agradable sabor.

750ml. Young bottle, BB date 03/2008. Pours traffic light amber with the merest haze. Rocky two-finger head composed of small and large bubbles; bigger head on subsequent pours. Clumpy, three dimensional lace. Spicy nose with cantaloupe and pistachios, banana daquiri, white rum, ripe pears, diesel.  Flavor is initially sweet and alcoholic, then minty, yeasty, grainy, and woody. Traces of chamomille and chocolate. Light, fizzy palate. Dry finish with an aftertaste that is leafy and bitter, alcohol and apple cider. Although complex, with warming the beer tastes more and more like a hefeweizen spiked with moonshine. Unlike many ratings below, I found that alcohol was the dominant characteristic.

Bière blonde dorée avec grande tête pelucheuse et vivante. Arome au goût âpre de fruit avec des accents de levure, quelques épices et pommes. Le goût est rond et animé avec un accent de céréale, un contact de gâteau aux pommes, la banane mûre, un léger dose de sucre et un goût de houblon.
Bottle.  Pours golden with rocky white head.  Somewhat spiced and malty aroma, and maybe some hints of sweet fruits.  Had more a yeasty flavor, but seemed kind of thin in body.  Really dry finish.

corked 750 best before 06 2005, pors a nice white head.  aroma is yeasty with a bit of alcohol coming through, appearance is darker than duvel, more orange and cloudier.  very, very drinkable at 10% sweet, good body with a dry finish.
750 ml 1 year from BB date.Golden pour. Big frothy head. Aroma of yeast,candied fruit,some straw characters. Alcohol not overpowering. Pretty decent.

Nice golden blond beer with big fluffy head and good livelyness. Fruit tart aroma with hints of yeast, some pices and apple. The taste is round and lively with good cereal accent, a touch of apple cake, ripe banana, a slight dosis of candy sugar and a well integrated hoppy accent. taste is turnig dry in the end.

750 ml bottle. Cloudy orange with a gigantic head. Aroma of apple, spice, candi sugars and citrus. Body is amazingly smooth and the alcohol is masked really well. Taste is dry with some faint banana as well.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2005 A Mes rate:
Standard looks. Candy floss, apples and typical Belgian ale in the nose. Very ale type flavour but a touch more rich and sweet as you would expect. Slight spicy with some marmalade on toast in there too. The alcohol comes through a little but is generally hidden quite well. Little bit too much carb for my liking but whatever. Long finish which is almost wine like. A decent strong triple. Imagine part way between a quadrupel and a tripel and you get the idea.
Golden blond in color with white head. Lot of tiny carbonation bubbles. Aroma very farmhouse like. Initial flavor is candy sugar that finishes with a little spice. Rather bland overall.

On tap at my favorite pub in Uden, NL.  Nice hazy amber color with the requisite thick white head.  Big aroma of spices, yeast, and light fruits.  The flavor is yeasty still with sweet malts, estery, more yeastiness....I like this stuff.  Yep the alcohol is there, but its not overpowering.  Its good to be back in Uden...and enjoying one of my old mainstays.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2007 Pours golden/orange with a good sized white head,nice aroma of belgian spices, citrus,  alcohol. Flavor is sweet, citrus good alcohol punch high alcohol% but does not have a hard taste, i prefer this over Duvel, good body great brew.
Hazy golden amber color with a large white frothy head.  Hint of citrus orange in the aroma with a balanced citrus and light pepper flavor.  Alcohol well hidden and warms toward the end.

Pours golden with big white head. Tart and yeasty aroma. Flavor is quite potent- mostly yeasty esters. Very sweet, but with dry carbonation bite. Tastes like straw. Finish is very dry and bland. Not bad. Alcohol not really apparent.
Bottle. Weak aroma. Golden colour, slightly hazy. At first quite alcoholic flavour, but it turns warming and pleasant. Medium sweetness and maltiness. Dry aftertaste.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2006 (Bottle 33 cl) Beautiful amber coloured beer with a tall, pretty head. Hazy and unclear. Full-bodied, rather fruity with a pleasant soft hop-touch. Extremely easy to drink in spite of the high alcohol. A very warming strong abbey beer. 060993

Draught - Gingerman. White head that dies down quicker than expected. Somewhat light & clean. Really fruity which isnt necessarily a bad thing. Tangy and refreshing. 10% is hidden extrememly well. Id happily order this again, especially compared to the 8.

Aroma very big hit of fruit and spice. Pillowy head that fades to nice lacing. Flavor is sweet but not too much so, with melon like flavors and a little musty/ peppery bit at the end. A well crafted tripel.
An amber, deep, strong, smooth lassie from the fine folks at Duvel.  Strong across all the categories--though it is tasty, it lacks much distinction in the taste department.

What starts with a light fruity tarness turns into a full sweet malty finish. Clear amber with a towering rocky white head, the sugary sweetness in the aroma belies the fruity orange essence throughout. Bitterness rises towards the later half of the swallow eventually moderating the malty sweetness at the finish. A fine tripel.

Bottle:  Suagary sweet aroma with fruit, yeast, and light tartness.  Pours a transparent orangish-gold with a white head.  Fruity and sweet up front.  Yeastiness dominates the finish with some light bitterness.
Hazy bright orange with a thick white head.  Aroma of orange zest, coriander, and yeast.  Slightly sweet orange flavor with a touch of cinnamon and other spices.  Grassy, bitter finish.

Corked and caged 750ml bottle pours a clear, light amber bodied ales with little sediment.  Decanting left a huge, rocky white head that lasts and lasts and left great lacing.  The aroma is somewhat floral and herbal, but mostly sourdough with hints of citrus.  Initial palate is lightly sweet and develops a tangy, orange-grapefruit citrus flavors with hints of pepper and cloves.  This is a solidly refreshing, effervescent and highly carbonated ale with a moderately sweet aftertaste and hint of warming alcohol.   Quite nice....
Golden colour with a small white head. malty and spicy aroma with hints of fruit. Flavor is malty with notes of yeast and some fruit.

Moderately spicy, musty tangerine aroma with low but perceptible herbal, floral hop character.  Opaque yellow-gold with pillowy white head that recedes to a persistent cover with decent lacing.  Spiced orange-citrus fruit flavour is peppery and moderately sweet with some suggestions of alcoholic strength.  Fair bitterness in the dry finish and aftertaste.  Medium-light body with fairly strong carbonation.  Tulip glass, just above fridge temp.  Bottle (Half Time, Mar. 2005).

33 cl bottle.  Unending white foam cascades over the thickly laced, tiny-bubbled bright hazy copper-amber body, gorgeous...zesty, sour lemon, bretty-cobwebby nose...pleasant balance of sweet caramel, sour orange, alcohol pepperiness late in the mix...easy drinking, pleasurable tripel.

a striking yellow-orange, like an extract of broom bristles and mango sherbert. if its tight weave of aged ivory foam was a blanket, it would warm a wet walrus on an ice floe-- its that thick and snug. its ghosts and goblins of lace dribbled in slow incantations. i abused the bottle a bit to jumpstart some of the locked-on yeast visible inside. to be honest, in a smoky bar room setting, the aroma was harder to raise than a company of riflemen for the afghan conflict. i could almost see the aroma as well as sniff it. i guessed and then tenuously confirmed the big crusty golden malts, lightly musty citrus and white wine. easier to commit to the notebook was its carbonation-- like a sprinter, fiery at the starting gun, but tiring quickly. not a sweet triple, but strong, full bodied, with a lot of oaky white wine flavors. a generous measure of yeast speaks with a melon-fruit accent. like trying to speed-read a great novel, im sure i missed many nuances. still,  i hope i caught the drift of it: a nice tale of careful brewing that  ill eagerly revisit.
Very nice and smooth triple.  Dark brown, a bit muddy in apperance.  Flavor is caramel, nuts and some hops.  Rather fizzy but this dissipates quickly.

Thick-looking and umber in the glass, but with a light, white, and diminishing head.  Some lacing.  Aromas are woodsy, red wine, and hops.  The palate of this beer is full, lively, and excellent served cold to retain carbonation.  It is an acidic beer, with flavors in the hops and malt families.  Also some floral notes, like violets, on the finish.  A complex (and strong) beer.  Very tasty.

2004 bottle (750mL) at the Downtown Liquors Trippel tasting, 3/24/05.  Pours a warm-toned orange-peach color with moderate-sized, well-retained white head.  Lightly cloudy.  Aroma displays some hops bitterness, Belgian biscuit malt, dry, mossy earthiness and some alcohol.  Flavor is strange, to say the least, to my palate.  Not anything like any other trippel Ive tried, let alone a traditional Belgian trippel.  Very dry, mossy, fuzzy, yeastiness, with a dry, bready/biscuity malt that hides any sweetness.  I think I taste hops bitterness at first, and after a couple more sips, the notion is confirmed.  Yes, quite unmistakeably hoppy and moderately bitter as a result.  A bit of nuttiness from the hops, light alcohol and spiciness on the end, dry as per the start.  As it breathes, the robust carbonation dies off and there is some dry toffee-like notes, probably just a bit of the malt sweetness peeking out from the biscuit or aromatic malt.  My palate does grow accustomed to the beer as I drink it and though Im not a huge fan of bitter dryness, and biscuity astringency, the beer is not watery or thin.  Alcohol does not run wild, despite this being one of the strongest trippels Ive tried thus far.  A bit of musty, corky flavored yeast lingers on, with nutty hops bitterness noteable as well.

Gourgeous appearing apricot nectar color with an everlasting egg white head.  Aroms is yeasty with fruity esters and hops, no anouncement of the big ABV in the aroma.  Lovely flavor of Beldian goodness with some significant hop bitterness on the front end followed by a big fruity (apple) finish; yeast too.  Finishes dry and spicy.  I am constantly amazed by the breadth and depth of Belgian breweries.  Yum.

Shiny orange colour with a good head.  Hoppy and fruity aroma with some alcohol. Sugary and a bit rubbery flavour with some hops and clearly present alcohol. Somewhat soapy on the palate. All in all, not much bitterness.

On tap at In De Blaauwe Hand, Nijmegen NL.
A sweet tripel. Hazy gold (!) in colour, sparkling beer. Not a quaffing beer, but one to sit back and read the papers with. Enjoyable.

Pours slightly murky dark yellow to light brown in color.  Big fluffy off-white head.  Fruity, spicy, yeasty aroma.  Big on flavor with notes of caramel, butterscotch, spice, and very little hops.  Hard to tell it is 10% alcohol.  Very smooth and drinkable.
dark ale colour. Deep flavour, like a brandy. Smooth, with what? 10%? reaction. Good malts and spice and wheat and Belgium yeast. Citrus orange pineapple, cloves,ginger, banana. Someone acidic

750 ml caged and corked bottle, best before 08/05/06. Pours hazy bright golden orange with lots of floating yeast chunks, decent cream colored lasting head that leaves good lacing. Fruity and spicy aromas. Fruity butter scotch and pepper flavors, very dry and crisp finish. Full bodied with a full but crisp mouthfeel, alcohol well hidden and very drinkable.

Had this beer at the scottsdale big beer fest.
I must have had a bad bottle as this was not good at all. It had the aroma of a wet alcohol soaked dish rag with the flavor to match and I had to pour the rest of the glass out.
I will buy a bottle if I see one just to try again but this one was bad!

A very enjoyable brew.  Not too overpowering but not weak in the least.  Pours clean and with plenty of head (watch out, Ms. Lovelace).  A drink to savor slowly.  Let the alcohol do its job and getcha good and cheerful.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Has a clouded orangish color with small white head.  Smell is of yeast/malts.  Taste is of the yeast/malt and finishes a bit fizzy with some alcohol flavor.  Overall a good Tripel, but nothing special.

this tripel poured a light orange with a big 2 inch frumpy head.after the head calmed a bit,i got nice webbing and lacing.i also  get lots of tiny little bubbles rushing to the top of the trappist galss.the aroma gives off the average belgian yeast smell.the frist sip gave me hints of carbonation,yeast,malts,and some fruit.not to bad but nothing special.

Bottled (BB 01/2007)
Bright bronze (after bottom yeast added, a bit hazy) with champagne bubbles and big cloudy head, lots of lace. Fruity, slightly skunked hop aroma. Bitterish, herbal golden ale character. Starts with alcoholic kick, then mellows to fruity flavor and finally aftertaste is alcoholic and warming.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2008 (Bottled, 0.75l) Hazy orange-golden with a medium, tight and lacy head. Pale-malty, slightly grainy-syrupy aroma with some Duvel-like yeasty-vegetably hints and alcohol smoothly present. Strongly malt-emphasized, fruity but not sweet, flavor with moderate acidity and pretty well hidden alcohol for the ABV. No hops to speak of, but some peppery spiciness. Medium to full body with soft and foamy carbonation. Ok, but quite straightforward, and slightly too acidic for me. Only slightly smoother with yeast, as there’s not much of it.
(Bottled, was 7-4-7-4-15=3.7) Very hazy yellow-orange color with a huge head. Very fruity, pleasant and sweetish aroma. Fruity and balanced flavor turns into alcoholic sweetness, then sourish and bitter in the finish. Peppery, warm aftertaste. Medium to full-bodied, pleasantly alcoholic and warming, slicky palate with balanced, a bit hard carbonation. A pleasant, full and warming triple that doesnt try to hide the alcohol, but to make it enjoyable. Not exactly a summer terrace triple, but great for enlightening a dark december evening after a hard day at work :)

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2004 33cl bottle, aged one year, sediment slightly disturbed by my random carelessness.

Pours with a slight cidery translucence (thanks to me), goldy orange, with fine persistent bubbles which aspire to a thin and diminishing head. But who cares what it looks like, lets try it.

Aroma slightly sweet and fruity, yeast. Tasting some biting grassy hop bitterness countered by solid sugary backbone, takes its time winding down on the center of my tongue and palate. Nice of you to visit.

The controlled hop dryness is one feature that I notice in good tripel (as if Im some expert) and this one does it for me although Id like to have more hints of pineapple or gooseberry or whatever tart/sweet fruits get into these sometimes. Bornem Tripel aint bad that way.

This beer was not excessively alcohol-y for me although I cool anything to at least at cellar temp and as wine freaks will tell you this makes the alco seem less "hot".
Dark color with one creamy foam and swells. Body much alcohol fort and malt, extremely solid. Scent of wheat.
Poured orange with a large off white head. Light malt aroma. Touch of grapes with mild hops. Lightly bitter. Slightly cloudy. Good.

A hazy dark gold, layer of sediment at the bottom of the bottle. Big foamy beige head that quickly disapates. The first scent remins me of Worchestershire sauce(!), Rich fruit dessert, almonds, alcohol. Sweet chewey malts, cotton candy dipped in brandy. Very tasty and a great dessert beer for cold winter nights such as this.

Clear amber/orange color with big white head. Aroma has Belgian esters, spice, and alcohol. Taste has the same characteristics, soem malt, breadiness, and finished dry with lingering alcohol. Another nice ber from this brewery.

Bottle at the  Syracuse Holiday Brewfest Dec.04 2004. Dark brown with reddish hues. Aroma of fruits, raisins, coriander and alcohol. Sweet malts and spices, coriander and anise, rich bodied with nice alcohol burn. Best of show,

Beautiful golden color with excellent frothy white head. Aroma of green raisens and spice, alcohol and yeast. Full bodied and silky in the mouth. Malty with some exotic fruit, maybe mango or pineapple. Very good.

750 ml bottle - Whole Foods - Austin, Tx. Pours a dark murky orange with a thick, ever present white head with good lacing. Aroma has alcohol notes, with some date fruitiness. Flavor has some some sweet, malty accents reminding me of toffee with a bit of a chocolately back end. Smoth palate - 10% ABV is hidden quite well and it goes down ever so smoothly. A very decent Tripel.

Deep golden, off white lasting head. Yeasty aroma with red apples, coriander, wheat. Good carbonation. Malty sweet flavour wih a discrete touch of coriander, wheat and yeast. Smooth palate. Overall excellent mild tripel.

Glowing orange bubbly body topped with a typically huge belgian head that leaves thick clinging lace.  Sweet floral yeasty and spice aroma.  Body is well carbonated, but soft; sweet malts, herbs, pepper, fruit.  Light hops and dry at the end.  Alcohol was well hidden.

750mL, 1yr old. Initially gushing, though not more than 100mL is lost. Body is hazy shining golden with orange hints. Beautiful color actually. Head is creamy, foamy, 1 inch tall and lasting. Lemon skin, leather particles and high level of yeastiness hits up the nose. Notes of light grassy hops, herbs, ginger, X cereals bread. Big hoppy suggestions in the mid-palate provide a rather big grassy and tart bitterness, but are quickly letting place to a peppery yeasty and sweet finish. Good apples, petals and honey flavors. Great alcohol disposition, always apparent in subtlety. Could be a bit mellower as a tripel though, this comes out sharp edged. Still very good and an obvious cousin to their Duvel, if not as elegant and sweeter.

Bought in the Bottle from the excellent "Beers of Europe" shop near Kings Lynn

This is a strong, mid/light brown beer. With a strong taste but not to strong an Alcohol taste despite its 10%. Quite a dry aftertaste & reminisant of Duval.

very typical tripel.  good beer, but not spectacular.  somewhat light for a tripel, lots of alcohol presence.  i wish it had a yeastier/spicier aroma and flavor to really make it a standout tripel, but its really just average.  i will gladly drink it again, however....

Very sweet aroma and a sticky sweet finish.  In between, it poured a hazy orange with a solid head.  Its a warm drink with plenty of alcohol presence.  Spicy and sweet... a lot of different flavors here.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2011 Bottled.  A yeasty alcohol aroma with spices and banana notes.  The colour is a hazy copper and there is a big white head, although this doesnt last as long as its stable mate Duvel.  The taste is gritty and peppery with warming spicy clove like alcohol.  Nice stuff.  Typical tripel.  Score 3.7Subsequent ratings scored 3.5 and 3.7. Average becomes 3.6
Cider, alcohol, caramel, cookie dough aroma.  Sweet with alcohol, the taste works well somehow, and the mouthfeel is great.

Thank God I found some Belgians in Portugal.Nice golden orange,creamy head.Fruity,malty nose and I would also say a spice note to it.Good combo of flavors as the fruit/spice  turned out to be nicely done.Not unlike a spiced apple atr Christmas time.

Bottled, Stockholm Beer Festival. 
Orange colour. Sugary and yeasty, a bit raw, probably too young. Smallish notes of fruits - lemon and apples. Big disappointment.

Sampled at Halls Beer Tavern in Paris, France.

Light Brown.

Lovely aroma. Sweet, like sugars, big caramel and other fruit notes, mainly lemon, herbs, apples and watermelon seeds.

Front is mild, slightly spicy with notes of white peppers. Mid-palate is fruity with notes of cinnamon, apples and plums. On the finish the beer fades but then comes back and gives way to an exceptional finish with notes of nuts, toffee and cherries. 

Moorgats beers though not phenomenal, are usually pretty impressive, especially for such a large brewery.
An o.k. tripel, cloves and fruits in the taste, but that is a bit hidden behind the alcohol.

Poured yellowish orange with thin white head...smelled fruity with pears and apples then a little tart as it warmed (citrus)...tasted at was horrified at first...horrible abrasive sweetness with and equally abrasive alcohol finish...so shocked was I by this Tripel that I set it down and walked off...I actually forgot about it for about 30 minutes...definately at room temp now more than ever, I tasted again...beer is cool...all of the nasty aggressiveness was gone...smooth pears and lemons, then pepper, then a little sweetness from the alcohol...dry finish...this is definately a 55-60 degree drinker...less than that makes this beer a 2.8...

Bright, candy-toned orangish hue, hazy and highly carbonated, with a head that starts big and tall, but pops and explodes into million crystalline bubbles before disappearing for good.
