Aroma: a bit vacant, and Im surprised, can this be so? Fruity, sweet, but laying inordinately low, with quiet hops and a pervading flatness in the feel, altogether. Humph.
Taste: thick fruit personality on the palate, citrus, orange,pineapples, tasty, tangy, but lacking a certain zing, from hops, from anything. Full of malt and yeast, lacking a lightness I find in better tripels, thats always matched by abundant spicy, fruity kick. Feels sticky, leaden, thick, does not dance delightfully upon the tongue, no matter how strongly I wish that it would.
No, this isnt working, and I cant figure out whats wrong with it, for I was so anticipating happiness in this glass. 
Toward the end, Im not as disappointed as I was at the start, but its still such a departure from what Id expect from a tripel. Maybe its the 10% creeping in?
Still, I cant believe its not better than what Im tasting...if anyone has a better bottle, call me up and Ill come right on over!

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2004 thanks kevin! / bomber (my bottle is nothing like the bottle in the pic as of this date) duvel tulip glass / big white airy then marshmallowy head. seemingly thick body, golden straw colour. the flavor is  vinous, florally, and bittersweet. the palate is a bit sharp for me. reminds me of an abbey in its champagne spritziness and exotic beer-like bittering and malts, but theres something lacking. its a good beer, though. from memory, i think i prefer corsendonk. on a second, and delayed, thought, i prefer--in some sense-- two brothers bare tree weiss wine 2003. hmm.
Hazy golden color, light sweet alcoholic aroma and taste, full body, light sweet dry alcoholic finish.

Bottle Pours a medium amber with a large foamy off-white head. Nice sturdy lacing too.  Aroma is nice spicy and sweet. Cloves, apples.  Flavor is a complex combo of the above, and yeast, wood.  Feel is quite thick and smooth and the trailer is a a woody, slightly yeast hint.  A nice tripel.

Fruity, citrusy, slightly sweet aroma. Hazy golden orange color, with lots of floaties in it, despite trying to decant on the pour. Went ahead and just dumped the whole bottle in the glass, lots of yeast chunks at the bottom. Good carbonation and big fluffy white head. Tart, dry flavor. Citrusy. Big alcohol flavor, almost too big. If the fruityness could be turned up and the alcohol turned down, this would be one downright refreshing beer!
Quite nice. Orange color. Sweet aroma. nice spiciness on the tongue. nice strong alcohol as well.  buzzy buzzy.

Bottle boguht in Belgium. Pours bright gold with a fluffy white head. Malty, alcoholic aroma with spice. Flavour is powerful, heavy on the alcohol sweet and malty with a little spice. Its a really nice beer.

Golden and cloudy color, big white head. Fruity, pretty mild aroma for 10%. Flavor is also fruity with some apple in there, alcohol comes up somehow. Strong alcohol makes body to be full. Little bit of too alcoholic for my taste. Nice lace.

Pours a highly effervescent gold bosy underneath a big, foamy white head.  Aroma very bready and yeasty, with some spice and bubblegum as well.  Flavor is well-balanced, with an initial malty sweetness followed by bitter, flowery hops.  Even for a 10%er, the alcohol is quite noticeable.  Finishes dry and peppery.

Appearance: amber/red color, full rocky white head, and plentiful highly bubbling carbonation. Head retention is good and it has a sticky lace. 
Aroma: malty, fruity, bubblegum, spicy, astringent and a light grassy aroma hop. Initial whiff is similar to a wee heavy. 
Taste and mouthfeel: a sweet start with a medium body and creamy. A light well balanced hop bitterness that finishes peppery, crisp and fresh.

IMHO: I like this beer. It is well balanced and maintains a good balance of flavors and mouthfeel throughout. Complex, but not overwhelming.
UPDATED: APR 23, 2005 Lots of head in the pour.  Taste is a little sharp at first but after the first couple sips goes down very smoothly.  Leaves a very nice aftertaste
drink has almond raisin, grass, and burnt marshmallow.  An absolute find.  Wonderful!
UPDATED: MAY 11, 2005 tan color with a fluffy white head. aroma of alcohol and prune or raisin. bitter smoked spicy fruit flavor. has a peppery note that melds well with a chewy earthy finish.

Bottle. Thick dense head. Nose has alot of malt, banana, and some wheat. Taste is spicy with some anise, black pepper, banana, and clove. On a sweetness scale of 1-10, this gets a seven. Very gassy. Finish is like the taste, but with a brown liquid sugar bite. This isnt my cup of tea. Or beer for that matter.

Yeasty and orange aromas, sweet smelling. SLides over the tongue, sweet, and hangs on the tongue for a bit, with just a hint of sharpness on the back of the mouth.  Starts with a large head, dissipating into a small head that sticks to the glass. Dark gold in color, very slightly cloudy.

Pours a translucent lemony gold with a VERY fluffy white head.  Smells strongly of wheat and malt, and has that slightly pungent/sweet scent that champagne yeasts tend to leave behind.  Buttery sweet and flowery on the tongue with just a sting of hoppiness, and an alcoholic afterbite.
Golden with large head. Sweet, cereals, little grassy, alcohol. Full and sticky mouthfeel.

Cloudy, golden appearnce with a small head.  Peppery edge in an aroma otherwise dominated by yeast and fruit.  Full-bodied and nicely carbonated, the flavor tends to vacillate:  sweet  and malty at first, then hoppy, then returning to a sweet, somewhat fruity, somewhat spicy taste.  Long-lasting finish with the alcohol catching up fast.

(33 cl bottle, now available in Norway). Deep golden to amber colour, large head. Very nice aroma of dried and ripe fresh fruits and herbs, yeast, malts, oak and pipe tobacco. Flavour is spicy with an alcoholic warmth (no surprise at 10% ABV), elements of dried fruits, medicinal herbs and brown candy sugar. Herbal aftertaste. A very good beer that packs a real punch.

Small bottle
Estery and yeasty aroma  with noticeable alcohol - 
citrus notes if you get some yeast in.
Hazy gold, low foamy lacing head.
Fruit, light citrus tastenotes with 
a bitter yeasty edge.
Ends on a alcoholic burn.
Medium body.
Wasnt too thrilled with this one.

Pours an Amber Ale Colour with an Abundant White Frothy Head. The Aroma is not particularly special but ever present and kinda corny and kinda yeasty. The Flavour is  classic  Belgium Fruity and Fizzy and Yeasty and Big. The Sweet Flavour of fine Malts are very apparant. Other than the light amber colour you could be drinking a Chimay Grand Reserve and not even know it. This is one very good thirst quenching drink. For the price this may be my new Belgium Classic Abby Ale. CHEERS!

Best Before Date 08.05.06, Sampled July 2004
Pours with a fluffy off white head that sits atop a well carbonated hazy orange gold beer.  The aroma is yeasty, spicy and sharp with notes of grass, soft vanilla, and herbs.  The taste is sweet up front and in the finish as well.  The middle though, is sharp with a carbonic bite and a foaming tongue.  The flavors I get from this beer run the gamut; from vanilla to hay, cider, yeasty/ bready, herbs, and alcohol.  As this beer warms up a bit it begins to develop some funky complexity in the nose; a funky farmhouse cheese seems to have been suddenly dipped in my beer.  The alcohol starts to become quite apparent in the nose as well.  Visually this beer leaves some nice Belgian lacing as I work my way through the first glass of this 750ml bottle.  This is quite an enjoyable Triple, I would highly recommend it to any Triple or Belgian beer lovers.  If I would have to find a fault, I would say that it is just not quite complex enough to make it world class, but this is a rather weak complaint.

(750 ml bottle)  Pours a golden amber color with a huge, long-lasting, frothy, offwhite head.  Has a nose of heavy yeast, light alcohol, banana, and butter.  Creamy mouthfeel with a stickier finish.  The alcohol in this one will warm you up.  Has flavors of caramel, yeast, and alcohol with an apple aftertaste.
I taste it after i taste the best trapists.Pretty strong beer and have a nice taste but after 2-3 slips you can feel the alchol in yor mouth.Not the best one for sure but nice.
Pours a dirty gold with nice, lasting head and good legs.  A perfect looking beer.  Aroma is of yeast, malt, and dry cracked wheat.  Taste is dry and bitter, with toasted malts coming through.
Honey colored, pours with a moderate white head.  Sweet aroma of light candi sugar and yeast.  Well made, but not much different than many other triples.  Flavor is pretty sweet.  Finish sweet.

33 cl bottle. Served in Maredsous glass. 

Dark gold. Decent head. Powerful, dark citrusy aroma. The taste is dominated by  citrus and alcohol. Long, warming, markedly dry finish.
Dark golden color with thick head.  Holy crap... theres a ton of yeast floating around.  Strong aroma of yeast and alcohol.  Good taste of bread and malt.  The alcohol is quite powerful.  Tasty!
Gold Coloring.  Good Head.  Varied Greatly from the 8.  This had a nice floral/sweet aroma... citrus.  Lots of yeast floating....very enjoyable....alcohol was quickly noticable.

Golden/orange color with a fairly thick head. Nice malt scent comes through along with a citrus and wine-like aroma.
Full-bodied, with a mildly sweet palate and a dry finish.
Good solid Belgian Tripel.  Definitely develops well as it warms.  Yeasty, aroma and flavor.  A little high in sediment.  Not too much carbonation.  Dark brown, hazy.

Bottle pours golden, nice white rocky head, with ample carbonation and attractive lacing.   Sweet malts, earthiness, and floral notes invade the nose.   Slight alcohol tinge as well.   Forwardly sweet, but not cloying like other Tripels.   Also getting some fruity flavors, apple and figs.   Finishes clean, crisp, and without any harshness or a 10% ABV.   Fantastic lacing, slowly diminishing head. &nbsp One of my favorite Tripels!

On draft at Toronado.  05.22.04  Golden pour, large, white head, much lace.  Clove and banana, bubblegum.  Eh, not remarkable, although quite tasty.  Losts of alcohol on finish and certainly a cloying quality to it.  Not all I had hoped but who cares?  What a great night at the Toronado!
Amber with a frothy white head.  Aroma was of floral and spice mix that was pleasant.  Meedium body with some fizz.  Flavor was quite good.  Floral, spice, citric.  Very enjoyable.

Big and full nose of sweet fruits, gentle spices, and candi sugar.  Deep gold body with an incredible, frothy head.  Heavily sweet, lightly acidc flavor becomes a moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter finish with a drying alcohol presence.  Medium-full body, creamy texture, lively carbonation.  The bottom line is: almost everything I want out of a tripel.

Bottled.
Hazy and orange.
Spicy and somewhat yeasty aroma.
Warm and fullbodied. flavour from spicies. A little thin and short taste though.
Golden body, big fluffy white head. The aroma is quite fruity, with big spicy notes. Sweetness all around, typical for the style. Medium almost syrupy body with very assertive carbonation. Not bad.

Bottled: Dark golden coloured. Off white huge and lasting head. Spices, sweetness, fruit and malt in the aroma. NOtes of alcahol. Dry, light sweet fruityness in the flavour. Some spices and a special alcahol fatness Ive not tried before. Finishes sweet and malty with a light alcaholbite.

Hazy, small white head. Aroma lets you know that this is a strong beer, the alcohol comes through quite a lot. Flavor is fruity and malty, but also with some alcohol. Not as good as many other belgians.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2016 2016-07-23. Hazy orange body with a modest foamy white head. 3+ Aroma of sweet biscuity malt, light alcohol. Flavour is lightly alcoholic and bitter. Average plus  bodied palate, good carbonation. Enjoyable typical example of the style. 7/3-4/7/3/15-16 

2004-XX-XX Slightly hazy amber orange body with a beautiful fluffy white head. Aroma is pleasant but distractingly alcoholic. Slightly sweet malty flavour profile with slight hints of peppery spice and citrus, which are overrun by a strong alcoholic finish. A nice beer that could be much better with better disguised alcohol. 6/4/7/3/16 3.6

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2005 Bottle.  Hazy golden orange color.  Aroma is flowery with soft fruit and alcohol.  At first I served it way too cold, and the carbonation seemed too much.  It eventually mellows and has a nice flowery/bready malt taste with a good amount of hops in the finish.

Malty with notes of burnt toast, caramel, caramelized fruit, beets, sugar, and spices. Brilliant hazy amber (like butterscotch) with creamy lacing off-white head. Medium chewy body with medium-high carbonation. Silky. Starts sweet and sugary, with mild acidity and no bitterness. Fruity and sugary malts remain to finish, with musky grains and alcohol ending. Some bitterness comes along in aftertaste - a little drying, but for the most part, its a sweet and carbonic mixture. Definite alcohol presence. Pretty complex flavor. A very nice beer.

BBD 11/2005. 33cl.  I remember trying this one in Belgium, and was not struck by it, too much alcohol and not enough good flavor says my notes.  Stateside: Gushed a bit, and poured with lots of yeast adrift.  Bronze colored, had to force the head a bit, decent lace.  Yeasty aroma, not getting malt or hops in the nose, smells a bit metallic or oxidized.  Decent flavor, but rather short and simple with an alcoholic heat at the end(which I dont like much).  Not bitter, but it burns and lingers. Besides the alcohol it would drink well(on the light side).  Just not that interesting and at 10%ABV Id hope to be overrun with complexity. Id rather have a Duvel.

A friend brought this back from belgium for me and another buddy to try. I have not had it since, but it left an impression on me. Pours golden yellow with strong floral aroma. Yeasty and clean smelling. Large foamy head. Flavor is complex. Robust and delicious. Bananas, fruit, spices, citrus, tartness and did I mention yeast? This is a great tripel.
Yellow/golden in color with good head retention.  Aroma is malty with a hint of spice and yeast.  Sweet flavor with a crisp finish.  Pretty tasty triple.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2004 No date on the cork on this one but the Best By Date is 16 01 06. Cloudy amber with splashes of red. Medium foamy white head. Aroma is spice, yeast, malt, fruit and candy sugar. Some flowery notes as well. Some citrus towards the end. There is an above average carbonation feeling to the palate. Finish is slightly dry. Good stuff!

Clear gold, big poofy head.  Nose spicy, slightly metallic, mildly bready.  Flavor is somewhat citrusy, mostly orange.  Lots of candy sugars.  Continues with the metallic notes, not really that pleasant.  Yeasty and a bit lemony.  Really dont like the metallic flavor on this one.  May have to rerate later, as I may have gotten a less than spectacular bottle.

Aroma: No hop aroma, esters apparent. Metallic aroma present that fades. Malty aroma comes through more once the beer has warmed a little.

Appearance: Slight cloudiness. Light orange color. Decent head retention with persistent lacing.

Flavor: Spicy Belgian yeast notes apparent with malty flavor in the background. No hop flavor, but flavor is very complex with different taste sensations noted after each sip. Hints of berries evident and pleasing to the palate once beer warms a bit. Candi sugar sweetness noted in the finish.

Mouthfeel: Well balanced mouthfeel, with 10% alcohol well hidden. The alcohol becomes a little more noticeable as it warms but it still adds a nice warmth and is not overpowering. Thickness in the mouth is medium/high. 

Overall: Rather complex and well-made beer that I would have again in heartbeat. Very drinkable despite high alcohol level as it is well hidden. Very good example of the style.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2011 This is a solid tripel that for some reason I tend to forget about. +++Sampled from an 11.2 oz brown bottle this beer pours a cloudy golden-apricot color with a large white head that produces excellent lacing. There is a sweet, fruity aroma with lingering tangy sugar. There is a yeasty tang to the flavor with some light citrusy sweetness and a strong table sugar element.The finish is a bit sharp and is long with tangy malts, ripe fruits and sugar.  Fairly full bodied.  A bit boozy. I have had this on draft as well and found the draft to be very unremarkable. Well done.

Belgian Triples in general are my favorite style of beer. The Maredsous 10 is a classic example of the style reflecting it's own unique house character. Upon smelling the beer I can close my eyes and feel like I am standing outside of the Moortgat brewery breathing in the fresh country air. The beer taste as fresh as the soft well water used to brew it, with the ever so pleasant suble malt flavors, a slight fruity sweetness, and golden color all mask the boisterous 10% alcohol.

This tripel starts out mostly spicy, with the very carbonated and expansive mouthfeel breaking up the sweetness, but when the spiciness and carbonation relax, the beer finishes on a moderately sweet note in flavor and on the palate; The aroma is lightly spicy; Dark golden color and quite clear; White head is somewhat creamy and is fed by a steady supply of carbonation bubbles, so retention is good, and extensive lacing completely covers the inside of the glass

The beer pours with a head akin to an icecream float which disssipates after a few minutes.  The aroma has a hint of lemon.  The taste is a mix of orange with some lemon and has a slight astrigence to it.

(750ml bottle, best by 1/16/06) Very cloudy amber body with big, rocky, beige head.  Aroma is mild sweet, herbal, light orange and lemon.  Taste is herbal, spicy, some orange, light honey, finishing herbal.  Medium body, hides the alcohol very well.  Excellent tripel.

330ml bottle.  A hazy golden-orange ale that pours with a large, dense, white head that lasts and leaves thick lacing.  Continuous stream of small bubbles.  Lightly herbal hop aroma, with notes of fruit (pear and apple, maybe) and some alcohol.  Medium body with a lively mouthfeel that moderates.  Initial sweetness has a fruity and honeyish character.  Becomes increasingly dry and crisp.  A grassy hop bitterness and straw- and bread-like maltiness meets the alcohol at the finish to end with a peppery bite.  Not bad, but the flavour is lacking something extra, particularly when you consider the 10% abv.
pours a nice golden orange with a nice creamy head that has little retention.  a nice floral aroma.  the taste of alchohol compliements the maltiness bery nicely.

Gold with a frothy white head crazy lots of lace. Aroma is lightly hopped, herby(thyme?) and earthy. Dull smells overall not displeasing. Yeasty flavours, spicey and alcohol warmth. Too simple for a beer of this magnitude. Very sweet finish but also chalky and resiny.
Deep clear amber color (sediment settled out on bottom of bottle).  Little head, excellent lace.  Very smooth, hoppy spice, sweet finish.  One of my favorite Abbey Tripels.

Cloudy orange in colour with an initially large head.  Aromas are orange, yeast and spices - not bad.  Flavours are good, too - orange, especially orange peel bitterness with spiciness to follow.  To finish there is lots of warming, rather than burning alcohol.  Has a good sparkle, full of flavour and lots of bitterness.

Bottle  Poured a yellow golden beer with a nice head with great retention. Aroma of floral malts with a hint of sweetness. Taste is very sweet with some very subtle spices coming out at the end. Body is above average and the alcohol is very discreet which is an enjoyable thing for beer with such high-level of ABV. Overall, not the best of tripel that Ive had the chance to drank but a very good one nonetheless.

Bottle. Big yeast and slightly fruity aroma. This is a golden bear with a huge white head and is very carbonated - a little too much so. Yeast dominates the flavor, but there's a bit of a malt backbone before the alcoholic warming hits. Very dry. Not my favorite Tripel, but I wouldn't complain if is was served.
Clodu yellow with a awesome head. Fruity aroma and some alcohol notes. Decent beer. Nice alcohol burn.

clear lighter golden, nice creamy white head, that is lasting, but lacing is poor. aroma is very floral and perfumey, and very sweet..just a tiny hint of alcohol. flavor is sugary sweet overall, but extremely musty and earthy. there is cotton candy sweetness in the finish, alcohol is well-hidden overall, but you can feel the effects in your mouth...not too shabby.
Coloudy yellow with an awesome white rocky head. Fruity aroma with candi and alcohol notes. Rich malty flavor with fruity notes and a little alcohol burn. this is Duvel on acid. Decent and warming.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle, poured slightly cloudy, orangey-amber with a billowy white head that lingered well and left plentiful lacing.  Aroma is typically complex belgian - sweet and fruity with prominent yeast and spice notes.  Rich, sweet flavor, like spice bread with orange marmelade and a somewhat astringent tart-yeasty finish.  Medium bodied and well carbonated.  What's not to like?  Another nice belgian ale!
Footy and toe-like. Clear appearance with a mild head. Fluffy flavor and a little over-carbonated. Tastes thick and malty and very candied.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2004 Fresh, sweet and fruity aroma, with some honeyish malt, citrus, faint banana, melon and nectarine, along with some light touches of doughy yeast and peppery alcohol.  Golden amber color with a captivating swirl of yeast in the center and a subsiding, fine head.  Flavor is malty, honeyish and sweet, but blending nicely with the plentiful yeast esters and possessing a lush floral backdrop.  Finish is long, languorous, lightly alcoholic and warming.  Lively, effervescent yet creamy mouthfeel, certainly full-bodied but this is likely the most drinkable Tripel I have yet sampled.  No sooner had it warmed sufficiently than it seemed to simply disappear.

330mL bottle. Big, frothy, long-lasting head leaves a fair amount of lacing. Hazy amber...looks quite nice in the Maredsous glass I obtained from the gift pack. Strong yeast aroma, banana, clove. Spicy, smooth, finish is moderately hoppy with a warm alcohol touch.
Cloudy yellow in the glass with a very thin head.  Aroma of appleas, oak, sweet and fruit.  Very warming with clove, bananna, vanilla and a little citrus.

Hazy orange and average white head, mostly small bubbles. Some yeast and vanilla in the aroma, plus apple. A full bodied triple, loads of malt, very sweet with plenty of vanilla. Lacking a bit in spice, somewhat one dimensional. This used to be my favorite style, but now I just find this to be too sweet for tastes. Even still, this is a good triple, big for the style (like Golden Monkey), lacking a bit in subtlety though.
Nice orange colour with thick white head. Yeasty aroma of apples, sugar, citrus and alcohol. Flavour of yeast, citrus and oranges. Quite alcoholic finish.
creamy orange citrus aroma, light orange with a tight head, orange creaminess with notes of candi sugar and a bitter finish

Orange/brown color,lots of small yeasties suspended throughout this brew.The head was foamy white and short lived but managed to leave a decent lace behind.The aroma was Fruity and sweet with a slight sourish side,citrusy and floral as hell.Nice malt taste then fruit comes on in a nice way,citrusy and mildly spicy with a decent fruity sweet after taste.The finish is nicely done and highly drinkable with the alcohol being hardly noticeable.Very much well worth trying this brew if you can.
Great aroma, very smooth feel and a great taste.  To look at this one in the glass was to look upon another wonderful belgian beer.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2010 Feb, 2004 Bottle Conditioned. BBE 05/05  Full bodied and quite pleasant. Alcohol is evident, but not overpowering. The sweetness is restrained and balanced with a wheaty spice.  A quality beer that just doesnt do much. [3.1]
Dec, 2010 Bottle from MonoPrix, Paris. Yeasty, sweet, some sharp tingle, almost sour, good malty sweetness. This is a fairly typical strong pale ale with a robust yeast. There is an awareness of alcohol about it.  Once you discover how easy it is to brew this stuff at home, your admiration for it diminishes. You either like these yeasty strong pale ales, or you love them. I quite like them, but Im rarely overwhelmed. This is a fairly straightforward example. It gets you pissed, and its inoffensive. [3.3]

Bottle pours a hazy burnt orange amber with a small head for a Tripel and lace sheets.  The aroma is bread like yeasty, slightly fruity, and a touch of Belgian spice notes.  The flavor is banana sweetness, bread like yeast, a hint of vanilla, pretty warming and peppery - but not bad for a 10% ABV and just very smooth!  The body is rich with a cleansing palate sensation.  This beer is a sensation.  I like it very well.

Honey color with scads of white swinkles in the final pour. Tall light white head with chunks of lace. Heavy aromas of stewed apples and raisins. Musty wine alcohol also in the nose. Yeast laden sweet malt from the first time the liquid hit the lips. Smooth with a light spritzy bite. Finish is very light and really does not call one back. Floral hops preasent in the middle and a mild hops bitterness and acidity. Alcohol bite is a bit strong in this one. Seem like an abbey malt liqour.

Pale golden yellow color with mega floating yeasties suspended within, thin puffy whitish head fades quickly leaving an ever present skim and fluffy collar, lace in tiny spots. Aroma is quite dull and light of dark citrusy tones of orange and lemon. Underlying yeastiness and very dulled spice are noted. Phenolic notes emerge as it warms. Taste is very smooth and calm, well rounded and leveled citrus thats dulled down by alot, some orange, lemon, green grapes, mango, banana, and pineapple all kinda blend and make for a one of those squishy things, but not in a juicy manner, more of dull popcicle-like flavor. A strange but appealing dryness floats off the palate at the finish which is kinda interesting and nice. Feel is medium bodied with a unsharp carbonation, very easy going and mild; smooth over all with a yeasty weird smoothness that adds just a faint nudge of spice and helps dry thing out a bit at the finish. A nice little triple, I liked its mellowness, but the flavors and aroma could use a bit of a boost.

Big, warm, malt aroma with hints of peaches and plenty of alcohol in the nose.  Deep golden hue with a rocky white head that thins quickly without much lace.  Complex mouth of alcohol, malt and fruit.  A bitter hop character cuts through the sweet body and balances it nicely.

Underated.Very nice tripel(which was expected due to the history on this one)Pretty hazy orange/phat frothy head/great lace.Smells nice and yeasty,spicy,fruity.The taste is so nice,teases of apricot and pear.The malts shine while the hops balance.Nice lively mouthfeel(co2/hops)Better than the collective rating IMO.A must try for belgian beer lovers.10% is a nice complement to this awesome tripel.

Pours a lightly hazy orange with a huge rocky, pillowy, and well-lacing white head.  Toasty citrus aroma with some bready yeastiness to it.  Body is semi-sweet and dry with a pleasant malty complexity to it.  Good, subtle hop balance as well.  Hides its alcohol very well. A very nice abbey triple.  Thanks mixamatt!

Nice bouquet of faint floral and spicy hops.  Excellent head, rocky on top with large bubbles underneath,  with minimal carbonation.  Great lacing.  Color is a clear golden orange.  Wow, very smooth and well balanced.  Very easy drinking.  A light toffee/butterscotch flavor with a nice alcohol punch.  Finish is smooth and very warming.  Not much bitterness though.  A top quality triple.  Not that complex in flavor but very well balanced and very easy drinking.  Good stuff!

750 ml. brown Belgian bottle. Freshness date of 08/05/06 on the label, so it's good to go until May 8th, 2006. Duvels' little bother, but not so little afterall. Poured out a orangey-straw color, with a dense meringue-like head. It stayed around for the entire ride. More than decent lacing on this beer. Aromas are of dried apricots, slight citrus smell too. Probably from corriander more than anything else. Slight phenolic character also. Peppery alcohol and bready yeast flavors make for an interesting combination. Biscuit flavors and slight dryness abound. Finishes dry & crisp. A decent triple, but no Duvel. Not too shabby for my 300th review on this website, huh?

Very nice tripel, golden in color, huge fluffly white lacy head, fruity nose, hints of alcohol in the flavors, as well as different kinds of fruits, you get that warming feeling as you drink it, slightly dry & bitter finish, overall a pretty very tripel

Tasted in Toronto from LCBO. Tasted in Maredsous chalice at 8C. Colour is a golden-orange, cloudy with a white fluffy but thin head.  Aroma has hints of alcohol, fruit, flowers and a slightly bitter hop note.  The flavour is sweet, with a slight orange taste and a light and subtle background flavour of pear or apricot..  Carbonated and yeasty feel on the tongue. Slightly bitter finish.  Warming feeling from the alcohol.
Murky copper color. Sweet, sour, and spice aroma. Flavor of spice, sweet/sour and some yeast. Somewhat dry, tingly mouthfeel.
Light copper color with a huge, fluffy, ice cream-like head. Spicy sweet and sour aroma. Sweet/sour flavor, full of lemon, bubblegum, spice and alcohol. Nice bubbly, fairly dry palate.

Slightly hazy orange/gold color with an huge fluffy white head. The aroma was full of grass, spices, sour orange, and some funk. The flavor had some grass, lemon, spice, and alcohol. The feel is very spritzy and moderately dry.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2003 Nice clear orange with  a large fizzy white head... lots of lacing.   Big sweet and spicey aroma of ginger, prange peel, and alcohol.  Taste is blander than the aroma, some orange and pine, but just overshadowed by alcohol.

750 ml. bottle drank just prior to a St. Bernardus Tripel.  Hazy yellow golden color with a classic white foaming, clinging head.  Attractive aroma, apple, yeasty, cellared.  Smooth palate, good all-around mouthfeel the product of carbonation and alcoholic bite.  The alcohol is there but well hidden; still, there is not the full flush of flavor that I would have expected from the aroma.  Fruit and yeast in a happy but timid dance.  Enjoyable and worth trying again.
This stuff was great.  A nice fruity aroma, with a bit of a cheesy flavor, that follows into the aroma when you are tasting.  A luscious feel in the mouth and quite soothing to the senses.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2005 tonights best of tasting: great head, brussels lace and color. beat out duvel and st bernardus.  flowery and herby with suberb nectar in the background. Leffe blonde on steroids. 
Rerated - either had an exceptionally good bottle the first go round, or maybe was just too enthusiastic.  Great beer, but not a 4.6
Cloudy golden ale.  The head on this was huge.  Not much aroma.  Not to yeasty.  A bit fruity.  A light beer with good malt flavor.  Excellent.

Nice, in that it is not overly sweet, but I find it thinned out a bit too much by the alcohol.  I don't at all mind a boozy beer, but as with all liquor, too much alcohol can rob flavor.  That phenomenon is at work here.
Foggy golden hues with alcohol nose, taste of honey apricots and smooth alcohol.  Only distraction is the carbonation over-load, otherwise very nice (the colder the nicer)
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Deep golden color out of the bottle with a big fizzy head that left great lace.  Very spicey, almost hot with pepper and coriander.  Very lively carbonation on the tounge.  Musty sweetness under the spice of apricot, plum, raisen with an orange rind finish.  Excellent sipping beer.

An amber colored, practically still, beer.  An inch thick head forms on the initial pour, but quickly (15 sec) vanishes.  The aroma is comprised of caramel, sweet apples, butterschnaaps, and coffee cake.  Sweet, thick, and almost boring.  Apples, bread and little else.  Something I was really looking forward to (mostly because it was new), but this didn't really deliver on any account.  Too bad.
This beer has a light yellow body - hue with a bitter initial flavor and a heavy body.

Crystal clear, light golden ale. Very large, everlasting, rocky head. Crazy lacing.
Nose of coriander, orange peel and yeast.
Well-balanced with flavors of candy sugar, bitter hops and alcohol.
Full-bodied with a syrupy mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Medium-length, bitter, astringent finish.

Beautiful gold colour.  Large initial head and lasting white foam and lacing.  Initial strong aroma of candy, followed by lasting yeast.  Humble sweetness and hop mixture.  Light but long lasting alcohol/hop aftertaste.  A classy smooth beer deserving of a higher rating.

Spicy yeast aroma with alcohol. Pours golden yellow, clear (which I didn't expect), head is foamy and white, lacing is good. Belgian spiciness in the flavour. Alcohol and smooth sweetness in the finish. Not really complex but quite drinkable none the less.
Bottled. Nice solid average tripel. Tasted what it should be. Not sweet enough for me. Very drinkable however.

I sampled this beer a few months ago after drinking numerous other beers.  I thought I'd give my taste buds a rest beofre sampling the Trippel again.   After a second try I believe my rating would have been identical.   Average Belgian alcohol aroma, adequate golden color, nice lacing head, and yeasty flavor.
Dark blonde beer with a long lasting frothy head, and an intense alcoholic nose.  A refreshing strongly bitter fruit flavour.  A good Belgian triple.
Sweet. Very sweet. As it warms more flavors begin to surface. I do taste the grapefruit here. No bubblegum though.
Nice golden appearance.  Sweet citrus aroma and flavor.  A high quality Belgian.
From the Sharp Edge European Beerfest:  Sweet citrus aroma, with a light plesent flavor.  A very good tripel.

This one really grew on me.  Sort of a coppery gold color, with a beautiful, huge, rocky white head that just kept going.  Smelled like a barnyard, which is what a good Belgie should smell like.  The flavor was initially surprisingly thin.  As it warmed up (I've got to break down and get a thermometer at some point), flavors begin to explode all over the place.  The malts rose up and asserted themselves in a honey smoothness, along with a suprisingly true sour grapefruit flavor, with some bubblegum.  As I swirled in the bit with a nice pour of yeast, the flavors became even more exotic, beckoning of overripe oranges, loam, and strangely enough, potato vodka.  The 10% had remained surprisingly hidden until the ethanol blast at the end.  Neat beer.
yeasty aroma, taste sour sweet interesting yeast characterlight mouthfeel hidden alcohol, finnishes more sweet than sour

My first real-time rating, for various reasons I have only just got a computer of my own and after spending a day trying to make it work I am relaxing with a Maredsous and watching Fox News to keep me in a permanent state of paranoia. Bottle conditioned, initial good head but soon sinks to a thin covering, moderate condition. Aromas of honey, malt and hops, First taste seems bland but is followed by an explosion of hops which took me completely by surprise. More honey and malt fills the mouth but the hoppiness keeps on going into the finish becoming dry and resinous. I normally dislike tripels but this, Achel and Karmeliet are starting to change my mind. OOh the alcohol is starting to kick in and Brit Hume is starting to sound witty and incisive.
A sweet and strong trippel, reminded me a lot of Unibroue's La Fin du Monde.  Some subtle spices and fruity notes amid huge flavors of malty sweetness and alcohol.

Absolutely gorgeous. Bright polished-copper body streams bubbles to feed the large, light fluff of a head. Extremely sticky, it leaves chunks on the side of the glass. The spicy nose hints of decaying leaves and oranges. Flavor is relatively light. Lightly sweet up front. Fairly dry finish, leaves me thinking of bread dough.

Tall and fluffy marshmallow head.  Amber-orange in color.  Highly carbonated and effervescent (I blew the cork out accidently with very little coaxing).  Smells and tastes like all of my favorite belgians.  Spicey, yeasty, citrusy.  Oddly though, the head of the beer has a distinct metallic taste which does not exist in the liquid.  Strong mouthfeel.
Bottled. Deep golden. Big on toffee. Malty and sweet, lightly fruity. Rather bitter grassy finish.

An unclear dark orange beer with a very fine creamy head. The aroma is very sweet and fruity. The flavor is powerful, sweet, fruity but in a special way, probably because of the spice blend, its hard to be specific - it contains orange and some peber and others. A nice powerful goodnight beer. It ends on a woody dryness and a slight bitterness - with the dryness sticking with you.
Cloudy golden colour. Fruity aroma. The flavour is very sweet and slightly alcoholic.
Nice spicey, pepper? Quite good. Pretty strong but most of the alcohol is very well hidden. No head but nice color.

Nice beer.  Very yeasy and rich for a golden-colored ale.  A little too much head, but nothing horrible.  Quite strong, but I didtn really notice that at first.  Much more depth than Iexpected from a beer its color and tone.

Grape, yeast and koriander nose. Orange with a light brown little layer of a head leaving laces. Super fizzy that makes it super pricky. Peppery and almost like mustard. Also allspice and nutty. Complex - good.

Beautiful nose - yeasty, apricots. Deep gold color and a tall fluffy head. Orangy maltiness predominates the fairly long flavor profile. A kinda nutty finish (cashews?). Full body, rather complex and well-balanced.

(Bottle) Orange amber colour with a fair sized white head. Spiced raisins, alcohol nose. Flavours of raisins and spice. Surprizingly no alcohol bur from the high ABV. I found it to be much like 1837 very mellow finish. Alcohol hidden very well!
Smells better than 8%.  A lighter look as well.  Its flavor rox.  Some of my friends like to give a mild shake to stir up the bottom good stuff.. I would luv to try it on tap
Heavy carbonation,a note of floral and spice and sugar starts ends with a slight alcohol burn. Bottle conditioned hopefully age will do it well!
Amber colour, good head, thin but persistent. Peaches and apple in the aroma. Well balanced sweetness in the flavour, with fruity (peach again) and yeasty traces. Light hoppy finish. Nice tripel.
Clear bronzlor with a light head turning to atmosperic lacing..Bready/yeast applie pie aroma..Fizzy carbination greets the tongue as yeasty apple flavors swim around...Basic yeasty triple.

Massive "tripel" head of large bubbled foam.  Aroma of yeast and dried flowers.  You can tell by the slow bubble rise that this is a thick beer.  Colors is a little more orange than most tripels I have sampled.  Flavor is sweet malts upfront with a earthy finish.  Very thick feel in the mouth with carbonation tickling the tounge.  Very good, best described as a heavy tripel.

Again, I've decided to a vertical test. But I'm presented with a problem: my old bottle not only has no BBdate, is supposed to be brewed at Denée (were the monastery is) and is called Brassin du Centenaire/Eeuwfeestbrouwsel. That was a more fancy name than the down-to-earth 'Tripel 10'!
The points above are from the newer version.
Colour: 10: pale orangey-amber; thick head, slightly yellowish, slowly collapsing/ Cent: dark chestnut, disparate head with thick, lonely bubbles, no carbonation [4/5] Nose: 10: first some fresh summer weeds, then coloured malt/ Cent: portwine, walnuts, cardboard and maple syrup [9/10] Taste: 10: bone-dry, candi-sugar flavour, a bit of orange rind/ Cent: Alcohol by Jove, and higher alcohols as well. Very vineous, oily even. Retronasal explosion of very ripe, sugared fruits. [9/10]
Mouthfeel: 10: unlike the dryness suggests, very full-bodied. After a few sips, a bitterness creeps in, slowly building up in the back of the mouth/ Cent: rather thin-bodied, but alcohols and oilyness. All that fruit takes some time to dissipate [5/5] Overall: 10: DAMN, another Westmalle tripel copy. Technically perfect, interest pffft/ Cent: WOW [18/20]
No doubt - I've tasted two totally different beers, even when they are or were top of the same range. And by all what's holy, I preferred the 'Centenaire'!!

A fine brew which I enjoyed with Dasilky1 and Drunkasaskunk, lots of carbonation and head. Powerful fuel like alcohol quality.  Hops are blended well with the flavorful fruits which cometogether for a nice finish. Yet another solid brew I have had the pleasure of enjoying.

DaSilky1 was ever so gracious to split a bottle of this between myself and 21iceman40. This one poured an orangey/peach color with a massive white head. The aroma was strongly dominated by alcohol, fruitiness, citrus and yeast. The taste was a mix of a bittering yeasty front followed by a malty fruity mix of peach, orange, malt and sugar almost. Very sweet, but yet mildly dry ending, not overwhelming by any means. Citrusy tartness from the hops attack the palate in the beginning and give way to a nice malty ending. The bittering is a bit much here as is the yeast. The sweetening malt is what saves this beer from being below average.

Way overcarbonated!!  One-Third beer equals Two-Thirds foam.  Alchohol flavors, somewhat banana esters, slight spiciness with a light body.  Thought the triple would be heavier.  The aroma is somewhat overwhelming.  This is an interesting beer but not what I expected.
Lots of alcohol.  A bit on the thin side, perhaps?  If you're not ready and you put this in your mouth, you'll make an ugly face -- but focus your attention first and it's rather tasty.
Amber color; frothy head, disappearing quickly. Some malt aroma; liquor taste, sweetish, alcoholic.

Hazy gold w/ some orange. Big, fluffy, soft, ice cream-like head. Lots of carbonation. Powerful yeasty, spicy nose w/ some alcohol notes. Light, very spritzy feel. Slightly tingly & numbing. Taste is sweet, fruity & yeasty w/ a potent alcholic finish & mild bitterness.

Clear gold color, looks great. Steady stream of tiny bubbles ascending up to handsome rocky white head.Lacing abounds.Bready aroma out front.Yeasty, fruity honey flavors, wwwith ssome vanilla and or licorice in the finish.Medium bodied.Alcohol is well hidden.Very nice beer. Oh wait, its brewed by Duvel!Kool.

  Best before 08/2005
UPDATED: FEB 12, 2003 Bottle.  Golden color with a foamy white head.  Soft, candy, and spicy flavors.  A light floating beer but also more dry than I would like.
Mild hoppy fruity pear aroma.Clear medium blond appearance.Clean yeasty fruity flavor and finish.Very refreshing for 10%.

Very carbonated.  Pours a hazy yellow with a good deal of head.  Very sweet fruity flavor mixed with alcohol and a malt/bread finish.  Good, but a bit too sweet and lacking on the more robust yeast/malt notes.

Fruity apple like aroma. Pours with lots of head (not unlike other Moortgats).  Deep yellow, hazy color.  The flavor is complex: Spicy, kind of peppery with lots of fruitiness.   Has a good "back of the tounge medium hops" [tm] finish.  Made quite a foamy mess out of my glass in the end.  I like it less than many other belgians and belgian style beers.
caramel and malty flavour, very rich sweet malty palate
Sweet nose with touches of apples; spicey with notable alcohol. Was a bit too effervescent, getting in the way of what seemed a sweet flavor, with touches of green apples.

The boittle gave a strong "fizzzzzzz" when opened, and the beer foamed up immediately, spilling a bit over the lip of the bottle. Poured into a beautiful honey-gold colour with a strong foamy head. Aroma of fruity yeast. Very sweet flavour with hints of peach, orange and malt and a bit of spice on the edges. The finish has a touch of hops, but is otherwise uneventful.
Nice golden colour.  Heavier sweeter tripel.  Not as dry as Chimay or Westmalle, a bit thicker.  I like.

Poured clean has a nice golden colour. LOTS OF CARBONATION, I dont like it when you open a bottle and it fizzes like crazy. Sweet and packs a punch. With bitter notes that are muted. Very sharp. If only the ONTARIO LCBO would get in a wider variety of brews from around the world like you see in the US it would be wonderful. End of my rant. This ale is great.

Sweet, happy aroma with slight touch of bitterness. Deep brew, deep and complex. Deep as dark clouds from hurricane storm. Alcohol was melted together with maltiness very nicely. It might be too sweet for some.
Hazy golden orange, large white head. Intense bead. Tangy malt nose.Effervescent citrus yeasty malt taste.

Hazy deep gold, soft but insistent-looking carbonation, thin bumpy head.  Aroma: alcohol, dried peaches, white pepper, slightly musty.  Carbonation is kind of harsh on first sip, but later in the glass settles into a more rational level.  Sweet body moderated by firm, but by no means obtrusive, alcoholic dryness.  Pepper, mushrooms, almost Wonder Bready malts at the beginning give way to a thin line of hops separating the sweeter, fruitier (peach, bramley apple) finish.  Balanced, muscular without bodyslamming you.  Moortgats pale beers are always nicely done, its a shame about the 8.

Sparkling, light hazed golden color.  Big, rocky white head.  Aroma is yeast with a touch of banana and alcohol.  Body is spritzy and sweet, with a prevalent alcohol bite.  Yeast, a and a sweet fruitiness make up the majority of the body with a subtle organic bitter hoppiness making an appearance in the finish.  Not a bad triple, but not a standout of the style.
hard to believe a beer this strong could be so boring. no real character of its own - not as good as the maredsous cheese but that´s something to be discussed at a different website
Malty aroma, barely apparent EtOH.  Very warming on the back of the throat, but other than that the alcohol is quite tamed.  Well hopped yet sweet.  Way too carbonated.
Way overcarbonated! The first obstacle was getting through the foam and into the beer. Spicy clover flavor, lighter than expected. Definitely a sweet aftertaste.
I agree with austinpowers that the abv, didnt seem as strong as indicated.  However I thought the flavor was pretty enjoyable.  It was spicey, subtle, and smooth with a nice mix of fruit notes.

For 10% abv, this actually tastes more like 8%.  Excessively carbonated.  Strong floral and spice notes that defy explanation.  I loved the Maredsous 8 but cant appreciate the Maredsous 10 nearly as much.
Strong fruity alcoholic aroma, nice white head and a deep golden pour. Malty sweet finish and the carbonation is just about perfect for a belgian. Lovely beer.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2003 Surprisingly, other than the appealing cloudy yellow appearance, my first impression was of the carbonation. This particular bottle was way overcarbonated, as if the brewery accidentally dumped some extra yeast in the bottle. However, after the initial carbonation shock subsided I began to notice the sweet swell of fruity malt that is distinctly Belgian. There is a sweet side to this beer that really settles nice on the palate while the cloves add interest to the overall flavor. My rating increased dramatically as the bottle warmed so I suggest to anyone giving this a poor rating to give it a chance closer to room temp. Cheers.

Medium gold color, very large head. Full bodied Belgian Triple. Very malty, somewhat sweet. Some hop spiciness. Full bodied, nice flavor. Some candy-sugar sweetness evident. Re-fermented in bottle. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet. No alcohol bite, despite a 10% alcohol by volume
(on tap) refreshing, fruity aroma. Blonde golden colour.Malty, fruity taste. Good.
Intensely strong yeast, malt, citrus and spice aroma. Cloudy peach, big vanilla head. Incredible malt, bread and orange liqueur flavour. Complex, great tongue tingle. A fine Belgian Strong!
Murky amber colour, generous head, strong, yeasty, fruity(bananas) aroma, quite warming and quite big.

750ML bottle best before 23 08 02 drank on 17 09 02:  Pours a hazy orange with a super fizzy head.  Light fruit, pepper  and alcohol aroma.  Slightly sweet taste that ends quickly and dry.  Fizzy mouthfeel to a fault.

different bottle than I remember.  golden colour, nice fluffy head leaving lace as you drink.  yeasty, citrusy aroma.  sweet malt, fruitiness, a little hops, and a nice yeasty alcoholic bite at the end.
I did not like this at all.  It was recommended at my beer store, but after having Ommegang earlier, this beer seemed simple and hoppy wih too much of a rubbing alcohol bite.
Like the spice and the not overly done alcohol flavor.  Nice malt and an easy drink.  Becoming more available and worth a try.

Aroma is light, estery and yeasty--a little like bread dough...Color is a hazy peach-gold...head is not thick but is dense with cracks as in pack sea-ice---clingy lace...Taste features healthy sweet malt base with a candied-fruit quality offset by light but sharp hopping and healthy carbonation---quite effervescent...Finish tastes slightly of cinnamon...Full-bodied brew, again buoyed by the carbonation, which helps make this surprisingly refreshing...Overall, this reminds me of a refined fruit cider...It lacks some complexity in its profile, but is still a very tasty, fruity, and spritely tripple.
This is a decent brew that was a little too flowery for the thin=ckness of the brew.

This beer is the definition of golden.  Nose is floral and fruity with some spicy clove notes.  Starts slightly sweet and ends with a little bite.  The alcohol is more apparent than with other tripels.  Good but nothing really outstanding.
Dark blond with a big head. Flowery hop aroma. Sweetish start that lasts. It is a nice beer.
Big rocky head, golden color, slightly hazy with yeast. Typical fruity/spicy tripel nose. Rather soft sweet fruity start with a spicy finish. Alcohol comes through just a bit. Not bad at all.
UPDATED: MAR 18, 2005 Great Belgian ale! Very natural taste not too complex a little yeasty but not overbearing.  Recommended
While i love the maredsous 8, this one here fell short of expectation. Golden color, some spice, some fruitiness, alcohol and fiziness. Not great.
Low level Belgian ale, but it makes up for some of it in price.  Strong alcohol taste.
Apple bread and spices…Citrus bitterness and a lot of alcohol…There are better examples…
A very good tripple.  Slightly darker than most, but with a very large head.  Slight bitter aftertaste,  but otherwise excellent!
Malt, citrus and hops in the aroma. Sweet taste with citrus, alcohol and some hopbitterness. Yeasty. Slight hopbitter finish. Nice beer, but not too complex. A bit too yeasty.

This is a great triple. I dont know where they got the picture for this beer from - hope Im rating the right one. Very nicely balanced flavor. Not too much of any of the common traits of triples. Usually a safe bet for guests.

Clear gold orange with huge rocky ice-cream-sundae like, peaked, long lasting head (best head so far of my 200 ratings). Passionfruit, hops and a touch of citric sour horse stable yeast aromas. Medium body. Smooth soft bitter-sweet palate. Flavours include fresh fruit and some of that 10% comes through but its not overpowering. Bitter dry finish. Lingering sweet but harsh bitter aftertaste takes a point or two from otherwise what would be an excellent beer.
Great color, and a good tasting trippel.
nice malty aroma, with a large bubles of carbonation in the head. nice clean taste a big finish of hops with unique combination of citris and spicy.
golden color, sweet and bitter. A little spicy.
Quite disappointing, given the encouraging bottle shape and national origin.

cloudy golden yellow,
sweet malt flavours dominate with a citrusy finish.  left a surprisingly bitter aftertaste.
not as complex as other tripels or even the maredsous 8.

Though not as good as the Maredsous 8, the double version, this tripel is pretty good. Smooth taste indeed, but i dont know what delbomber drank, because the 10 is definitely not dark red. Thats more the 8. The 10 is a good triple, but there are a lot of better triples. I miss some spicyness in this version, which makes other triples so attractive.

Amber in color, generous beige head and nice lace. Malt dominates the nose, citrusy and somewhat sweet. Begins malt sweet, the middle is light, ends with an astringent bite, dry, lightly hopped, a quite drinkable beer.

Very fruity aroma from an extremely frothy head. Is this champagne or beer? Light cloudiness in a golden body showing a plethera of bubbling. Flavor has a light spicy bite with sweetness followed by a drier, slightly bitter finish. Overall a very nice barley champagne.
Nice fruity aroma.  Sweetness in the body is balanced well with the alcohol.
Best beer Ive ever had!!!!!!!!

Towering white head of foam over a limpid light brass-orange brew.
Nervous hoppy aroma but lacking general fruitiness and quality.
Bitter flavor with good middle-palate, but the finish remains unpleasantly bitter, the bitterness marks this beer, to the exclusion of much else.  So, its not my cup a tea!

Nice slightly sweet, fruity aroma.  The color is cloudy, golden with a very frothy head.  Just looking at it, there appears to be a LOT of carbonation, and first taste confirms it.  Its sweet, with a little taste of medicine or herbs maybe...or spice.  Hard to pinpoint because the alcohol takes over at that point til the finish.  A good warmer, but maybe too much so.  I liked it but I agree that it needs more balance between flavor and alcohol content.  I would like to try the 8.
Nice trippel. Wonderful aroma, sharp taste with strange overtones (really difficult to place... something herbal). Alcohol content does not overpower the taste.
Nothing really stands out.  An average B.S.A.  The Mared. 8 was alot better.

750ml bottle. Cloudy peach with a frothy white head and heavy carbonation. Aroma of pineapple, cloves, yeast and dishwashing liquid. Hugely effervescent body loaded with alcohol and a sugared edge. Immediate warm fuzziness warms the throat. Hoppy aftertaste, very spicy and herbal. Mellows a bit while sitting where the honeyed sweetness tries in vain to overtake the alcohol. Adding the yeast tempers the alcohol taste a bit, but it remains distracting. Salty taste at times. Finishes with a cotton candy dry sweetness and less alcohol thankfully. A struggle to finish a big bottle, with the alcohol not being well integrated. Still a good beer just needs some balance.
This beer wishes it were Chimay.  I liked the fruitiness it had but the alcohol left an annoying taste in my mouth.  Chimay has these smooth transitions from start to finish.  Maredsous does not.
UPDATED: MAR 29, 2003 Shit, for such a high alcoholoc beer, it manages to maintain some balance, fruity, slightly sweet,, with some warming alcohol, not bad.
Pfff, a good brewery, a good beer, but not one you would remember.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2006 33cl bottle. Head is initially large, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is hazy light amber, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain/bread), lightly hoppy (herbs), moderately yeasty (mold, cobwebs), with a note of alcohol. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately to heavily bitter, yeasty. Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Big, yeasty beer that could really use some brighter, fresher hops for aromatic interest.  Rather coating, yeasty finish that isnt too pleasant.  A little over the top in some ways, too understated in others.  A rather confused beer.  Not that fond of it, despite it being more too style than a great many labeled as "tripel".

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2004 Light peach and orange aroma. Dark golden color, large white head, very good lace. Strange light for such a heavy beer. Light sweet, orange, bitter, a alcohol burn in the very end of the finish. I think the most tasteless 10% beer I've ever had.
Nice Tripel
Sweet and tangy, almost smooth with a fruit nose and taste.  Malty with a touch of brown sugar, this dark red beer is good, but not great.

Sweet and spicy. Nice and strong, malty, with some fruit flavors to it. Not very complex but excellent flavor. My only complaint is the very prevalent alcohol taste, otherwise this would have easily rated over a 4.5

Very effervescent, big bubbled but rocky and sustained head. Strong, yeasty and spicy nose with appreciable hops. The first time Ive smelled kind bud in a Belgian beer -- its unmistakable.  Strong, smokey, and well balanced by deep malt hues, this is complex, and without excessive residual sugars. Maredsous 10 is drinkable, pleasant and punchy. Drink it when youre beer doesnt have to be your bread...
A nice adition to the moordgat brewerys complement
I like high ABV bier, and this one is quite nice. Not as complex as other triples and the mouth feel is not as chewwy as Ild prefer. Alot like Bornem Tripple.
Extremely high abv (10%) for such an easy drinking brew.  Typical Belgian flavor from the spicy yeast, but a surprising malty accent.  Very enjoyable, but not one of the top tier Belgian ales.
OK,  alcohol content makes for a warm feeling.  Not as flavorful as some.

Interesting malt aroma with hints
at peaches and apples, and a little
spiciness (perhaps also a hint at Saaz hops?
not sure).  More of the same in the flavor,
with a spiciness due to the yeast
characteristics.  Fairly drinkable for a beer
of this strength.  Moderate complexity.
Moderately cloudy (chill haze?) dark
golden color.  No head.

I was disappointed, especially
coming from the brewers of
Duvel. Nothing special, except
the high alcohol content (10% abv).
UPDATED: MAR 11, 2003 cloudy orange colour, giant creamy head with a beautiful lace, apricot, honey and alcohol in the nose, very sweet and smooth with a long bitter fruity and sugary finish
